Description: It must be possible to configure the UPS power rating.The UPS power rating must only be configurable when the UPS is in Off Operation or Maintenance Bypass, and if UPS is in NPI mode. As standard a GVL UPS is always a 500 kW.

Setting for the UPS power rating. Range:300, 400, 500 kWDefault value: 500 kW Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies:  Setting is only configurable when the UPS is in Off Operation or Maintenance Bypass, and if UPS is in NPI test mode.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: UPS power rating - setting has been changed

Requirement: Ability to read all product data from an adjacent product
Description: The Services Applications shall be able to read and write all data (settings, measurements, alarms, firmware...) of an adjacent parallel product from an alternate product.The FSR can then connect its laptop to a product and perform the Services activities without having to move the cable from a UPS to the other one. Specific care shall be taken to identify clearly the product concerned by the data on the Services Applications screen.

Requirement: Trashed - Readability and understandability of event logs
Description: Service log files to be more easily understandable by the FSRs ( based on feedback from VM and VX )

The UPS must include at bypass backfeed protection to ensure that no power is fed back to the bypass input terminals from the UPS output in the case where no bypass voltage source is present and a bypass static switch thyristor short-circuit.

If the bypass input voltage is detected as within tolerance on all three phases there is no need to do bypass backfeed protection. Only if the bypass input voltage is below limit, or a phase is missing, the bypass backfeed protection must be active.The voltage across the SCRs of the static bypass switch must monitored by means of voltage measurements on both sides of the SCRs.- If a voltage difference can be measured, the SCRs are not shorted.- If a low voltage or no voltage is measured, the SCR is potentially shorted, except if UPS is in static bypass operation.{Image: DF2843DA-6750-49C0-808A-872E0C7D9971.bmp}It will not be possible to detect if all three SCRs are shorted using the above method, as the bypass voltage will be seen as within tolerance.

Requirement: Bypass backfeed protection behavior using a breaker
Description: The bypass backfeed protection must be done via a breaker, which can be opened by the UPS automatically but must be closed manually.  The purpose of the bypass backfeed protection function is to prevent hazardous voltage from appearing "upstream" due to a shorted SCR in the Static Bypass Switch - SBS.Two conditions must be fulfilled before backfeed protection is activated:Condition no. 1:The voltage across the SCR’s are monitored by means of voltage measurements on both side of the SCR's.• If a voltage difference can be measured, the SCR's are not shorted.• If there on the other hand, only a low voltage is measured, or no voltage at all, there is a potential danger that a SCR is shorted (except of course the UPS is in static bypass operation).The voltage level must be set at +/- 33V. Voltage must be below the specified level for at least 5 sec. If this is the case, condition number 1 is met.Since it is very unlikely (under normal conditions), that more than one SCR is shorted, the situations where there are measured voltages below the specified level in all three phases, is perceived as an OK situation, where there is a perfect bypass mains which is 100% in phase with the output voltage of the UPS.Condition no. 2:In order to avoid the backfeed protection to activate in situations in which a energized bypass mains is connected, a voltage quality measurement must be done. The bypass mains must be monitored and reported out of tolerance at low or high voltage (-50% or +15%) or if a phase is missing.Only in case bypass mains is out of tolerance condition number 2 is met (no reason to protect against backfeed if a bypass mains is connected).If both condition 1 and 2 have been fulfilled for 5 seconds or more, the backfeed protection must be activated.
The current status (open/closed) of the bypass backfeed contactor/breaker must be available to the user in the event log.

Requirement: Status of bypass backfeed breaker in power flow and mimic diagram
Description: The current status (open/closed) of the bypass backfeed breaker, if present, must be shown in the power flow and mimic diagram (display and UPS Tuner) like other breakers in the system.

Requirement: User must be able to disable bypass backfeed protection
Description: It must be possible for the user to disable bypass backfeed protection via UPS Tuner in the case it is not installed.Bypass backfeed protection must be enabled by default and the user must be made aware of, and agree to, the risk of disabling bypass backfeed protection (confirmation needed by the user in UPS Tuner).When bypass backfeed protection is disabled no alarms must be shown from the status monitoring of the bypass backfeed breaker.

Requirement: Combined SSIB or UIB and bypass backfeed breaker must be supported
Description: The UPS must support a setup where the bypass backfeed breaker is either combined with SSIB or UIB. The power flow and mimic diagram must not show a separate bypass backfeed breaker in this case.

Setting to disable the bypass backfeed protection.Possible values:Bypass backfeed breaker not present,Separate bypass backfeed breaker,Combined UIB and bypass backfeed breaker,Combined SSIB and bypass backfeed breaker. Default value:Separate bypass backfeed breaker
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Bypass backfeed protection - setting has been changed
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The bypass backfeed protection trip has been activated.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The bypass backfeed protection trip has been de-activated
Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Bypass backfeed breaker is open
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Bypass backfeed breaker is closed
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The bypass backfeed breaker trip is working correctly

Requirement: Bypass backfeed breaker did not trip correctly
Description: Type: AlarmSeverity: CriticalCorrective Action Text: Check bypass backfeed breaker trip circuitDescription: Bypass backfeed breaker was tripped but AUX contact reports status as closed, and a voltage is measured between the bypass backfeed breaker and the static bypass switch thyristors.

Requirement: Bypass backfeed breaker status indication is not working correctly
Description: Type: AlarmSeverity: CriticalCorrective Action Text: Check bypass backfeed breaker AUX contact and wiringDescription: Bypass backfeed breaker was tripped but AUX contact reports status as closed, and no voltage is measured between the bypass backfeed breaker and the static bypass switch thyristors.

Requirement: Bypass backfeed breaker did not trip correctly or status indication is not working correctly
Description: Type: AlarmSeverity: CriticalCorrective Action Text: Check bypass backfeed breaker trip circuit, and AUX contact and wiringDescription: Bypass backfeed breaker was tripped and AUX contact reports status as open, but a voltage is measured between the bypass backfeed breaker and the static bypass switch thyristors.
Status of the bypass backfeed breaker.Possible values: Open/closed
The UPS must include a function for the user to manually test that the bypass backfeed protection is working correctly.

Requirement: User command to manually trip bypass backfeed breaker
Description: A command to manually trip the bypass backfeed breaker must be available in UPS Tuner

Requirement: Preconditions for being able to manually test bypass backfeed protection
Description: To be able to perform a manual trip of the bypass backfeed breaker, the following preconditions must be fulfilled:- Bypass backfeed breaker is activated (on).- Bypass input voltage is within tolerance.- UPS is in normal operation.

Requirement: Test procedure of bypass backfeed protection
Description: - When UPS is in normal operation and the bypass backfeed breaker is closed, the user must command the bypass backfeed breaker to trip via UPS Tuner. - The UPS must send a bypass trip signal to the bypass backfeed breaker. - The UPS must check the voltage measured at the point between the bypass backfeed breaker and the static bypass switch thyristors, and the status reported by the AUX switch on the bypass backfeed breaker.
Command to manually trip the bypass backfeed breaker via UPS Tuner

Requirement: Bypass backfeed breaker manual trip activated
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The bypass backfeed breaker trip has been activated manually
The UPS must include a mains backfeed protection to ensure that no power is fed back to the mains input terminals from the UPS.

Requirement: Mains backfeed protection using a contactor
Description: Primary Actor(s)-          UPSStakeholders and InterestsUPS              : Wants to ensure that no power is fed back into the mains input grid by the UPS in a malfunction scenario.Pre conditionsUPS has been properly installed.Post conditionsNo power is accidentally fed back into the mains grid.Main success scenario 1. Mains input voltage and frequency are within limits (refer to product spec).  2. Mains input backfeed contactor is turned on.  3. Mains input voltage or frequency is no longer within limits (refer to product spec).  4. Mains input backfeed contactor turns off after a given delay (refer to product spec) isolating the mains input grid from the UPS.Alternative scenariosTBDSpecial requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA
The current status (open/closed) of the mains backfeed contactor must be available to the user in the event log.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Input contactor has been opened.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Input contactor has been closed.

The UPS must be able to detect if EPO is activated and react accordingly:- by tripping the required breakers (handled by EPO hardware circuit).- by either turning off the inverter or transfering to static bypass depending on the configuration done by the user.The user must be notified of EPO activation/deactivation via an alarm and an event in the event log.

Primary Actor(s)- User.Stakeholders and InterestsUser : Transfer UPS system to emergency off.Pre conditionsUPS system must be supplied with power.Post conditionsAll power sources is disconnected and the UPS is either off operation or forced static bypass operation depending on the system configuration setting: "Transfer to static bypass on EPO" setting.Main success scenario 1. UPS not in off operation and not in maintenance bypass  2. User pushes the EPO button.  3. UPS enters forced static bypass Operation ("Transfer to static bypass on EPO" setting is enabled) and stays in forced static bypass operation as long as EPO is active  4. EPO hardware circuit will trip all required breakers.  5. User deactivates EPO button  6. UPS stays in forced static bypass operation. Alternative scenariosScenario 1: 1. UPS not in off operation and not in maintenance bypass  2. User pushes the EPO button.  3. UPS enters off operation ("Transfer to static bypass on EPO" setting is disabled) and stays here as long as EPO is active.  4. EPO hardware circuit will trip all required breakers.  5. User deactivates EPO button  6. UPS stays in off operationScenario 2: 1. The UPS is in off operation and does not supply the load  2. User pushes the EPO button.  3. The UPS stays in off operation ("Transfer to static bypass on EPO" setting is enabled) and stays in off operation as long as EPO is active.  4. EPO hardware circuit will trip all required breakers.Scenario 3: 1. The UPS is in maintenance bypass operation  2. User pushes the EPO button.  3. The UPS stays in maintenance bypass operation (no matter if "Transfer to static bypass on EPO" setting is enabled or disabled)  4. EPO hardware circuit will trip all required breakers. Scenario 4: 1. UPS not in off operation and not in maintenance bypass  2. User pushes the EPO button.  3. UPS enters off operation ("Transfer to static bypass on EPO" setting is enabled but no bypass is available), and stays in off operation as long as EPO is active  4. EPO hardware circuit will trip all required breakers.  5. User deactivates EPO button  6. UPS stays in off operationSpecial requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issues
The user must be notified of EPO activation/deactivation via an alarm and an event in the event log.

Requirement: Output relay indicating if EPO is active
Description: It must also be possible for the user to configure an output relay to activate if EPO is active.

Requirement: Transfer to static bypass on EPO setting
Description: Setting for if the UPS must enter forced static bypass operation when an EPO is detected active. If this is set, the UPS will go to forced static bypass operation, else it will turn off the inverter. Possible values:Enable / Disable Default value:Disable Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: Setting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.
Setting to configure an output relay to indicate that the EPO is activated.Range: Enable/disableDefault value: Disable

Requirement: Transfer to static bypass on EPO - setting changed
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Transfer to static bypass on EPO - setting has been changed.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: An emergency power off (EPO) switch is no longer activated.
Type: AlarmSeverity: CriticalCorrective Action Text: Deactivate the emergency power off (EPO) switch.Description: An emergency power off (EPO) switch is activated.

Requirement: EPO activated - output relay - setting changed
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: EPO activated - output relay - setting has been changed

An inverter autostart mode must be available in the UPS. The UPS must have the possibility to start automatically when input voltage returns,  after a shutdown due to drained battery. The function will turn on the output voltage of the UPS.The function can be enabled or disabled by the user, and is only possible in a single UPS system and not available in a parallel UPS system. It is however allowed for parallel frequency converters with no energy storage connected.If the input voltage fails and the system has to run battery untill the battery is drained, the UPS will switch to bypass if bypass is available (in a dual mains system). When input voltage is reestablished, the UPS will switch to normal operation. This functionality can NOT be disabled.If instead the bypass input was not available, the UPS turns off the output voltage when the battery is drained. In this case the user has two possibilities when the input voltage returns.1.      If autostart function is disabled, the output voltage will stay off, until the user commands the UPS to start.2.      If autostart is enabled, the UPS will turn on the output voltage.The conditions for the UPS to automatically turn on the output are:1.      Autostart is enabled2.      When input voltage returns, the event prior to this must have been shutdown due to drained battery.3.      If the UPS went to bypass after running on battery, and the bypass input disappeared afterwards, the UPS will start automatically.

Requirement: Auto start on inverter must be user configurable
Description: It must be possible for the user to enable and disable the auto start on inverter feature via a setting.
In the GVL product ""drained battery"" in the Auto start definition is defined asEither:Low DC shutdown activated.or:High current on battery terminals AND low DC warning activated.

Primary Actor(s)-          UPS-          UserStakeholders and InterestsUser              : Wants supply for his load after shutdownPre conditionsUPS has been properly installed and shutdown due to depleted battery after a power outage and the load has been without power.Post conditionsUPS delivers a correct output voltage.Main success scenario 1. Mains 1 voltage is restored after outage.  2. Auto start is enabled.  3. UPS checks for Mains 1 availability, and if it’s within voltage/freq. quality limits.  4. Mains 1 is determined as available.  5. After 10 seconds UPS goes into normal operationAlternative scenarios For a parallel system (only valid if all UPS units in the parallel system are configured as frequency coverters without energy storage)   Scenario 1: 1. Mains 1 voltage is restored after outage.   2. Auto start is enabled. Mains 1 is determined as available.   3. UPS checks for Mains 1 availability, and if it’s within voltage/freq. quality limits.  4. System checks if the minimum number of UPS units are available - ready to turn on and supply the load. (The minimum number of UPS units required is a setting).  5. The minimum number of UPS units are available.  6. After 10 seconds UPS goes into normal operation and the parallel system enters inverter operation. Scenario 2: 1. Mains 1 voltage is restored after outage.   2. Auto start is enabled. Mains 1 is determined as available.   3. UPS checks for Mains 1 availability, and if it’s within voltage/freq. quality limits.  4. System checks if the minimum number of UPS units are available - ready to turn on and supply the load. (The minimum number of UPS units required is a setting).  5. The minimum number of UPS units are not available.  6. The system stays off. System indicates that not enough UPS units are available.  7. Another UPS requests auto start on inverter.  8. The minimum number of UPS units are available.  9. System checks if the minimum number of UPS units are available - ready to turn on and supply the load.  10. After 10 seconds both UPS units enter normal operation and the parallel system enters inverter operation.  Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Setting to enable auto start mode. Range: Enable/disable. Default value is Disabled Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: Autostart is not allowed/possible in a parallel UPS system. It is however allowed for parallel frequency converters with no energy storage connected.

Requirement: System started by inverter auto start function
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The inverter auto start function has restarted the UPS, and turned the inverters on.

Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Inverter auto start enable - setting has been changed

The Power Module fans must be controlled at suitable speed, so that the Power Module is adequately cooled while the energy consumption and noise of the fans are kept low. The speed must be determined based on the load on the Power Module and the ambient temperature.

The static bypass switch fans must be controlled at suitable speed, so that the static bypass switch is adequately cooled while the energy consumption and noise of the fans are kept low. The speed must be determined based on the output current and the ambient temperature.
The UPS must monitor its fans and report to the user if a fan is inoperable or not working correctly via an alarm and an event in the event log.

Requirement: Dry contact output indicating fan inoperable
Description: It must be possible to configure dry contact output to indicate that one or more fans in the UPS are inoperable.
If a module (SBS or PM) has redundant fans, and one fan fails in a module, the other fan must increase it speed to maximum.

Requirement: Fan inoperable - dry contact output setting
Description: Setting to assign a customer configurable dry contact output to indicate that one or more fans in the UPS are inoperable.Range: Enable/disableDefault value: Disable
Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Power module has one or more inoperable fans. Fan redundancy is lost.  Instance must indicate which power module
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: All static bypass switch fans are OK.
Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Static bypass switch has one or more inoperable fans. Fan redundancy is lost.

Requirement: Fan inoperable - output relay - setting changed
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Fan inoperable - output relay - setting has been changed

The UPS must include fault tolerance on power module level.This means, that a power module must be isolated from the rest of the UPS system and shut down should it be required, for example due to a surveillance detected fault. The remaining power module must then continue in inverter operation and supply conditioned power to the load, if the conditions allow it.

The behavior of the UPS, in case of a power module shutdown, must depend on the output load on the UPS, and whether or not the fault leading to the shutdown of a power module causes an output voltage waveform fault on the UPS. If a fault in a power module leads to an output voltage waveform fault, the UPS must always transfer to forced static bypass. The given power module must then be isolated and shut down. If the load can be supplied by the remaining power module, the UPS must return to inverter operation after a couple of seconds. If not, the UPS must remain in forced static bypass. If the power module fault does not result in an output voltage waveform fault, the UPS must stay in inverter operation if the load can be supplied by the remaining power module. If not, the UPS must eventually transfer to forced static bypass, when the overload timer has timed out.

Primary Actor(s)-          User.Stakeholders and InterestsUser              : .Pre conditionsUPS has two fully operational power modules.Post conditionsUPS must supply the load from inverter via the remaining power module, or transfer to forced static bypass if necessary.Main success scenario1.      The UPS is in inverter operation and supplies the load.2.      One power module detects a surveillance fault, and is shut down and isolated with no impact on the output voltage.3.      The UPS alarms the user about the inoperable power module.4.      The remaining power module can supply enough power the load.5.      The UPS continues in inverter operation.Alternative scenariosScenario 1:1.      The UPS is in inverter operation and supplies the load.2.      One power module detects a surveillance fault, and is shut down and isolated with no impact on the output voltage.3.      The UPS alarms the user about the inoperable power module.4.      The remaining power module cannot supply enough power to the output load.5.      The UPS enters overload and transfers to forced static bypass at the end of the overload timer.Scenario 2:1.      The UPS is in inverter operation and supplies the load.2.      One power module detects a surveillance fault, and is shut down and isolated.3.      The power module shutdown leads to an output voltage out of tolerance4.      The UPS transfers to forced static bypass5.      The UPS alarms the user about the inoperable power module.6.      The output voltage becomes within tolerance again7.      The remaining power module can supply enough power to the output load.8.      The UPS transfers to inverter operationScenario 3:1.      The UPS is in inverter operation and supplies the load.2.      One power module detects a surveillance fault, and is shut down and isolated.3.      The power module shutdown leads to an output voltage out of tolerance4.      The UPS transfers to forced static bypass5.      The UPS alarms the user about the inoperable power module.6.      The output voltage becomes within tolerance again7.      The remaining power module cannot supply enough power to the output load.8.      The UPS stays in forced static bypass Scenario 4:1.      The UPS is in inverter operation and supplies the load, with one inoperable power module2.      The inoperable power module is able to operate again (fault in power module disappears).3.      The UPS clears the alarm about the inoperable power module.4.      The previously inoperable power module is started up again and transferred to inverter operation with no impact on the output voltage. Scenario 5:1.      The UPS is in forced static bypass due to an inoperable power module, and the remaining power module is not able to carry the output load.2.      The inoperable power module is able to operate again (fault in power module disappears).3.      The UPS clears the alarm about the inoperable power module.4.      The UPS detects that it is now able to supply the load from inverter again5.      The UPS transfers to inverter operationScenario 6:1.      The UPS is in inverter operation and supplies the load, with one inoperable power module2.      The second power module detects a surveillance fault, and is shut down and isolated.3.      The UPS transfers to forced static bypass4.      The UPS alarms the user about the inoperable power module.

If one or more power modules become inoperable, the remaining power module(s) must dynamically increase their power rating if possible, so that the UPS is still able to deliver as much power as possible.This is possible if the UPS is a firmware derated version.For example, a 60kW UPS with two 50kW power modules is able to deliver 30kW per power module under nominal conditions, but if one power module becomes inoperable the power delivered by the remaining power module can be increased, so that the UPS is still able to deliver 50kW.Any difference in supported battery voltage ranges of the different power modules must be taken into account when increasing the power.

If one or more power modules become inoperable, the remaining power module(s) must dynamically increase their available charge power if possible, so that the UPS is still able to deliver as much charge power as possible.Under nominal conditions the power modules will share the charge power, but if a power module becomes inoperable, the remaining power module(s) must increase the available charge power to compensate for the charge power lost because of the inoperable power module.

If the UPS is in a state where power module fault tolerance is active (a power module is shut down and the remaining power module is supplying the load from inverter), the user must be notified about this via alarms and events in the event log. Details about which power module is inoperable and the cause must be available.

The calculation of the output load percentage must be based on the power available from the operational power modules in the UPS.This means that if a power module becomes inoperable, the total available UPS power must be adjusted down according to the power lost due to the inoperable power module.

It must be possible for the UPS to operate in inverter operation with one power module in normal operation while another is in battery operation. In this case the UPS operation mode must be shown as battery operation.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text:Description: Power module is operable.Event instance indicates which power module
Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: Replace power module or contact Schneider ElectricDescription: Power module is inoperable.Event instance indicates which power module

Requirement: Power modules of different power ratings
Description: The power module fault tolerance must be able to support a setup, where the power modules in the UPS are not of the same power rating.

The UPS must support power module redundancy (N+1) together with scalability.The power module redundancy option must be controlled via a setting available in display and UPS Tuner. If a scalable UPS is configured for N+1 all power modules present in the UPS must still be used for power, but if the load on the UPS is above what can be supplied by N number of power modules, a power module redundancy alarm must be posted. Scalability with N+1 – examples:- If a scalable UPS with 6 power modules (available power rating is 300 kW) is configured for N+1, the available power rating must still be 300 kW. - If the output load on a scalable N+1 UPS with 6 power modules (available power rating is 300 kW) increases above 250 kW a power module redundancy lost alarm must be posted but the UPS must continue in inverter operation (no overload). - If a power module becomes inoperable in a scalable N+1 UPS with 8 power modules, the available power rating must be decreased from 400 kW to 350 kW, and if the output load is above 300 kW, a power module redundancy lost alarm must be posted but the UPS must continue in inverter operation (no overload). - If a power module is removed from a scalable N+1 UPS with 6 power modules, the available power rating must be decreased from 300 kW to 250 kW, and if the output load is above 200 kW, a power module redundancy lost alarm must be posted but the UPS must continue in inverter operation (no overload).
It must be possible for the user to configure if the UPS has power module redundancy (N+1) or not (N+0) via the display and UPS Tuner.

Requirement: Notify user via alarm is power module redundancy is lost
Description: If the power module redundancy is lost the user must be notified via an alarm.The redundancy can be lost either because a power module becomes inoperable, or because the output load increases above what the N number of power modules can supply.
Setting for configuring the number of redundant power modules in the UPS (internal redundancy).Range: N+0, N+1.Default value: N+0.

Requirement: Internal power module redundancy - setting changed
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Internal power module redundancy - setting has been changed

ECO mode allows the UPS to be configured to use requested static bypass operation (load supplied though bypass) as the preferred operation mode when circumstances allow it, either always or tied to a calendar.

ECOnversion mode allows the system to supply the active part of the load through the bypass. The inverter is kept running in parallel with the bypass source and supplies the reactive part of the load.The input power factor of the UPS is, regardless of the load power factor, maintained close to unity as the reactive part of load is significantly reduced in the UPS input current.In case if an interruption to the utility/mains supply, the inverter immediately maintains the output voltage so that breaks or drops during this transfer are practically eliminated.ECOnversion mode is designed to reach classification 1 which is significantly better than performance of “classical” ECO mode.·        Main flow of power is through bypass path => High efficiency·        Inverter is kept on => Reduced drop of output voltage at mains failure·        Regulation of input current => ”Diesel friendly”, no harmonics or VARs·        Regulation of DC bus => Allows battery recharge in ECOnversion·        Novel control method of bypass SCRs => Tolerant to mains short circuits
The efficiency when in ECOnversion mode must be 98% or higher.
ECOnversion mode must fulfill performance classification 2 (VFD-SS-211).

When operating in ECO Mode the bypass utility will receive whatever power factor and harmonic currents the load generates. This is not the case when operating in ECOnversion Mode. Here the inverter operating in parallel with bypass is able to correct system power factor ensuring power drawn from mains at unity power factor.  It must be possible to select a suppression/compensation of harmonic currents. This enables the inverter to operate as an active filter removing most of the harmonics current content of the connected load. In practice the system is able to suppress 3’, 5’ and 7’ harmonics since these are typically carrying the significantly largest part of the total harmonic content.It must be possible for the user to enable and disable the ECOnversion harmonics compensation.

A minimum output load of 5% on each phase is required before the UPS is allowed to transfer to ECOnversion. The load must be active power (KW not KVA). When in ECOnversion, the UPS must transfer back to inverter operation if the output load drops below 3%, on one of the phases.

Requirement: Notify user if UPS output load is too low to allow ECOnversion
Description: User must be notified via an alarm if UPS configured for, and is ready to transfer to ECOnversion but it is not allowed because the output load is below the minimum threshold.

It must be possible for the user to schedule when the UPS must be in high efficiency mode.It must be possible to either never or always be in high efficiency mode, or to be in high efficiency mode according to a defined schedule. The schedule must offer 7 separate configurable start and stop times (intervals), each with a weekday (Monday...Sunday) and a time of day in hours (HH) associated. Each of these 7 intervals can be enabled and disabled separately.

It must be possible to configure if the ECO Mode feature is available for the customer or not. The preferred high efficiency mode to use is ECOnversion, which is always available for the customer. Only if there is a specific wish from the customer to use ECO Mode, it can be made available by the FSR via this configuration.

Requirement: Disable high efficiency mode via input contact
Description: It must be possible to disable high efficiency mode via a configurable input contact.If this input contact is activated, the UPS is prevented from entering high efficiency mode or will exit any active high efficiency mode.

Requirement: High efficiency mode in parallel operation
Description: The high efficiency modes must be available in a parallel UPS setup.

Requirement: Prevent transfer to high efficiency mode if battery test is running
Description: To avoid that the UPS system automatically to high efficiency mode while the UPS is in the middle of a battery test ('battery runtime calibration test' or 'battery self-test'), any transfers to high efficiency mode must be temporarily disabled while the battery test is running.

Requirement: Notified operation mode change to high efficiency mode
Description: The user must be notified via the HMI and UPS Tuner if the UPS is about to change to high efficiency mode.If the UPS is configured to use high efficiency mode but is awaiting a timeout before it will transfer to high efficiency mode, the user must be made aware that UPS is about to transfer to high efficiency mode.

Requirement: Exit high efficiency mode based on bypass UTHD
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure the UPS to exit high efficiency mode if the bypass UTHD is above a certain configurable level.The UPS must not transfer to high efficiency mode before the bypass UTHD is below the configured level.If the UPS is not able to transfer to high efficiency mode due to the bypass UTHD is above the configured level, the user must be notified via an alarm.The bypass UTHD measurement used for determining if high efficiency mode is allowed or not must be made available to the user (for example via the display).

Primary Actor(s)-          User.Stakeholders and InterestsUser              : Wants to minimize power loss in the system by using static bypass as the preferred operation mode.Pre conditionsECO mode is enabled.Post conditionsMain success scenario 1. The UPS has been in inverter operation for at least 10 seconds.  2. The UPS checks that Mains 2 is within tolerance and that bypass is available.  3. The UPS  checks that ECO mode is allowed*.  4. The UPS changes to requested static bypass operation and indicates it is due to ECO mode.Alternative scenariosScenario 1: 1. The UPS is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.  2. Mains 2 becomes out of tolerance or bypass is no longer available.    3. The UPS changes to inverter operation immediately.Scenario 2: 1. The UPS is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.  2. ECO mode is disabled or no longer allowed*.    3. The UPS changes to inverter operation immediately.Scenario 3: 1. The UPS is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode and ECO mode is set as always allowed*.  2. The user pushes the inverter on button.    3. The UPS changes to inverter operation immediately.  4. When the UPS has been in inverter operation for at least 10 seconds it will return to requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.Scenario 4: 1. The UPS is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode and ECO mode is set as only allowed at a specific time and day of the week*.  2. The user pushes the inverter on button.    3. The UPS changes to inverter operation immediately.  4. The UPS will return to requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode when it reaches the next calendar time interval where ECO mode is allowed*.Scenario 5: 1. The UPS is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.  2. The UPS has a severe fault that requires it to enter forced static bypass operation (not output overload).    3. The UPS changes to forced static bypass operation and stays there as long as the fault is present.Scenario 6: 1. The UPS is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.  2. The UPS output is overloaded.    3. The UPS changes to inverter operation and overload timer starts counting.Scenario 7: 1. The UPS is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.  2. Mains input becomes out of tolerance but the bypass input is still within tolerance.    3. The UPS stays in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.Scenario 8: 1. The UPS is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.  2. The UPS has a severe fault that requires it to enter forced static bypass operation (not output overload).  3. The UPS changes to forced static bypass operation  4. The severe fault is no longer present.  5. UPS transfers to inverter operation.  6. After 10 seconds the UPS returns to requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.Scenario 9: 1. The UPS is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.  2. Mains 2 becomes out of tolerance or bypass is no longer available.  3. The UPS changes to inverter operation immediately.  4. Mains 2 becomes within tolerance and bypass is available  5. After 10 seconds the UPS returns to requested static bypass operation due to ECO modeScenario 10: 1. The UPS is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.  2. Mains 1 and Mains 2 become out of tolerance.  3. The UPS changes to inverter operation (battery operation) immediately.  4. Mains 2 becomes within tolerance and bypass is available  5. After 10 seconds the UPS returns to requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.Scenario 11: 1. The UPS is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.  2. EPO is activated  3. The UPS changes to off operation  4. EPO is deactivated  5. The user pushes the inverter on button.    6. The UPS changes to inverter operation  7. After 10 seconds the UPS returns to requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.Scenario 12 (high efficiency mode disabled by system): 1. The UPS is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode. 2. Mains 2 becomes out of tolerance or bypass is no longer available 3. The UPS changes to inverter operation 4. Mains 2 becomes within tolerance and bypass is available 5. After 10 seconds the UPS returns to requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode 6. Step 2 to 5 repeats 10 times within a 24 hours interval (the number of times is configurable, 10 is the default value).  7. Mains 2 becomes out of tolerance or bypass is no longer available 8. The UPS changes to inverter operation 9. The UPS disables high efficiency mode. 10. The user is informed that high efficiency mode has been disabled by system via either an alarm or an event depending on the configuration. 11. Mains 2 becomes within tolerance and bypass is available 12. The UPS stays in inverter operation. 13. The user re-enables high efficiency mode. 14. After 10 seconds the UPS returns to requested static bypass operation due to ECO modeSpecial requirements*ECO mode allowed: It can be configured when it is allowed to enter ECO mode. ECO mode can be set as never allowed, always allowed, or only allowed at a specific time and day of the week (calender time interval).It is required that the battery is operational to be able to enter ECO Mode or ECOnversion.The following battery related conditions can prevent the UPS from entering ECO Mode and ECOnversion...- Battery voltage below shutdown level- Battery voltage below warning level- Battery voltage collapse- Invalid battery configuration- Battery capacity is below acceptable level (the nominal available battery capacity is below the minimum level according to the current UPS output load)- External battery monitor fault (only if an external battery monitor is present)- Battery room ventilation fault- Flywheel inoperable (only if flywheel is present)- Modular battery fuse blown (only if modular batteries are present)- No batteries connected- Battery boost SCR not closedTechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Primary Actor(s)-          User.Stakeholders and InterestsUser              : Wants to minimize power loss in the system by using static bypass as the preferred operation mode.Pre conditionsECO mode is enabled.Post conditionsMain success scenario 1. The parallel master UPS has been in inverter operation for at least 10 seconds.  2. The parallel master UPS checks that Mains 2 is within tolerance and that bypass is available.  3. The parallel master UPS checks that ECO mode is allowed* both for itself and for all parallel slave UPS units.  4. The system changes to requested static bypass operation and indicates it is due to ECO mode.Alternative scenariosScenario 1: 1. The parallel system is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.  2. Mains 2 becomes out of tolerance or bypass is no longer available on one or more parallel UPS units.    3. The parallel system changes to inverter operation immediately.Scenario 2: 1. The parallel system is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.  2. ECO mode is disabled or no longer allowed* on one or more of the parallel UPS units.    3. The parallel system changes to inverter operation immediately.Scenario 3: 1. The parallel system is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode and ECO mode is set as always allowed*.  2. The user pushes the inverter on button on one parallel UPS.    3. The parallel system changes to inverter operation immediately.  4. When the parallel system has been in inverter operation for at least 10 seconds it will return to requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.Scenario 4: 1. The parallel system is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode and ECO mode is set as only allowed at a specific time and day of the week*.  2. The user pushes the inverter on button on one parallel UPS.    3. The parallel system changes to inverter operation immediately.  4. The parallel system will return to requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode when it reaches the next calendar time interval where ECO mode is allowed*.Scenario 5a: 1. The parallel system is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.  2. One parallel UPS has a severe fault that requires it to enter forced static bypass operation.    3. The remaining parallel UPS units can carry the load.  4. The parallel system changes to inverter operation immediately and the UPS with a severe fault transfers to static bypass standby.Scenario 5b: 1. The parallel system is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.  2. One parallel UPS has a severe fault that requires it to enter forced static bypass operation.    3. The remaining parallel UPS units cannot carry the load.  4. The parallel system changes to forced static bypass operation and stays there as long as the fault is present.Scenario 6: 1. The parallel system is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.  2. The parallel system output is overloaded.    3. The parallel system changes to inverter operation and overload timer starts counting.Scenario 7: 1. The parallel system is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.  2. Mains input becomes out of tolerance on one or more parallel UPS units  but the bypass input is still within tolerance on all parallel UPS units.    3. The parallel system stays in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.Scenario 8: 1. The parallel system is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.  2. One parallel UPS has a severe fault that requires it to enter forced static bypass operation.  3. The remaining parallel UPS units cannot carry the load.  4. The parallel system changes to forced static bypass operation and stays there as long as the fault is present.  5. The severe fault is no longer present.  6. The parallel system transfers to inverter operation.  7. After 10 seconds the parallel system returns to requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.Scenario 9: 1. The parallel system is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.  2. Mains 2 becomes out of tolerance or bypass is no longer available on one or more parallel UPS units**.  3. The parallel system changes to inverter operation immediately.  4. Mains 2 becomes within tolerance and bypass is available on all parallel UPS units.  5. After 10 seconds the parallel system returns to requested static bypass operation due to ECO modeScenario 10: 1. The parallel system is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.  2. Mains 1 and Mains 2 become out of tolerance on one or more parallel UPS units.  3. The parallel system changes to inverter operation immediately.  4. Mains 2 becomes within tolerance and bypass is available on all parallel UPS units.   5. After 10 seconds the parallel system returns to requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.Special requirements*ECO mode allowed: It can be configured when it is allowed to enter ECO mode. ECO mode can be set as never allowed, always allowed, or only allowed at a specific time and day of the week (calender time interval).It is required that the battery is operational to be able to enter ECO Mode or ECOnversion.The following battery related conditions can prevent the UPS from entering ECO Mode and ECOnversion...- Battery voltage below shutdown level- Battery voltage below warning level- Battery voltage collapse- Invalid battery configuration- Battery capacity is below acceptable level (the nominal available battery capacity is below the minimum level according to the current UPS output load)- External battery monitor fault (only if an external battery monitor is present)- Battery room ventilation fault- Flywheel inoperable (only if flywheel is present)- Modular battery fuse blown (only if modular batteries are present)- No batteries connected- Battery boost SCR not closed** Note that depending on the actual implementation in the given product it might not be possible to detect if one or more parallel UPS units no longer have the mains 2 source available in this scenario. The reason is that the output of the other parallel UPS unit(s) still having mains 2 source available will feed energy backwards through the static bypass switch of the parallel UPS units no longer having the mains 2 source, and it will look like there still is a mains 2 source. Only if all the parallel UPS units no longer have the mains 2 source available, it will be detectable and the parallel system will change to inverter operation. Technology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Select if ECO Mode shall be available in the UPS.This setting is used to allow the FSE to setup whether or not the customer can select to use the ECO Mode feature. Note: ECOnversion is always available for the customer to select.  Possible values: Enable/Disable.Default value: Disable Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: Setting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.

Selection of when to be in High Efficiency Mode (ECO Mode or ECOnversion). Possible to select "Always", "Never" or "Scheduled" (start and stop time of day, day(s) of the week. Repeatable event possible (ex. every Sunday)). Default value: "Always". Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies:Setting only valid/available if high efficiency mode (ECO Mode / ECOnversion) is set to ECO Mode or ECOnversion.Setting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.

Requirement: High efficiency mode setup warning pop-up
Description: If the ECO Mode / ECOnversion setup is changed by the user via the display, the display must show a warning with the text:"ECO Mode / ECOnversion settings changed. Please confirm."

This setting configures time of day and weekday for when to be in High Efficiency Mode (ECO Mode / ECOnversion).. It is possible to setup 7 separate start and stop times (intervals), each with a weekday (Monday...Sunday) and a time of day in hours (HH) associated.Each of the 7 intervals can be enabled and disabled separately. Default value of weekday: Monday.Default value of time of day: 00h.Default value of interval enable: Disabled. Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: * Setting only valid/available if High Efficiency Mode (ECO Mode / ECOnversion) is set to ECO Mode or ECOnversion, and high efficiency mode setup (ECO Mode / ECOnversion) is set to "scheduled".  * It is not allowed to have an interval with no day set, or put in another way, a start day or stop day can never be set to 0.     * When configuring the up to 7 different intervals, it should somehow in the user interface be ensured that these intervals do not overlap each other. This is to avoid confusion and guide the user.  * Setting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.

Selection if the harmonics compensation feature in ECOnversion shall be enabled or not. Possible to select ""Enable"" or ""Disable"". Default value: ""Disable"". Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies:Setting only valid/available if high efficiency mode (ECO Mode / ECOnversion) is set to ECOnversionSetting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.

Requirement: UPS output load is too low to allow ECOnversion
Description: Type: AlarmSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: Increase UPS output load or disable ECOnversionDescription: UPS output load is too low to allow ECOnversion
The UPS must always support power module scalability meaning it must possible for the customer to buy an UPS that is not prepopulated with all power models, and then add more power modules later on.
It must be possible for the user to configure if the UPS is scalable or not via a setting in UPS Tuner.REJECTED: Scalablity must always be enabled.

Requirement: Internal PM N+1 not allowed for a scalable UPS
Description: Internal power module redundancy must not be allowed for the scalable UPS SKU.

Requirement: Power rating shown to the user in a scalable UPS
Description: In a scalable UPS, the UPS power rating shown to the user in display, UPS Tuner and NMC, must not be a fixed value based on the nominal UPS power rating. Instead, the shown UPS power rating must be updated dynamically depending on the actual number of power modules populated in the UPS.

Requirement: UPS power rating shown in display top bar
Description: The top bar of the display screens shows 'Galaxy VL' and the power rating of the UPS.As the power rating of a scalable UPS is dynamic, the shown power rating in the display must also change dynamically depending on the number of power modules present in the UPS.
Setting to configure if the UPS is scalable or not Range: Enable/disableDefault value: Disable
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Scalable UPS - setting has been changed
List of supported UPS power module types:Valid model numbers are0G-PM50KD - Power Module 50KW at 400V

Requirement: Prevent startup at illegal power configuration
Description: If an illegal UPS power configuration is detected during power-up, the UPS must warn the user via an alarm and an event in the event log, and it must not be possible to turn on the UPS (UPS must stay in off operation).Child requirements list the illegal configurations to be checked.
The UPS must check, that the power frame type/size is correct according to the given UPS standard power configuration. If it is not correct an alarm and event must be posted.

Requirement: UPS power rating exceeds frame power rating
Description: The UPS must check that the configured UPS power rating is equal to or below the power rating of the power frame. If it is not correct an alarm and event must be posted.

Requirement: Warn about limitations in current power configuration
Description: If a limitation, due to the present UPS power configuration, is detected, the UPS must warn the user via an alarm and an event in the event log. It must still possible to turn on the UPS, but the functionality will be limited depending on the given configuration.Child requirements list the power configurations to be checked.

If no power module(s) are detected present in the UPS, the user must be warned via an alarm and an event in the event log.  Power module(s) must be indicated as inoperable and any operation modes requirering the power module(s) must be unavailable.

The UPS must check, that the power module type(s) present in the UPS is/are correct according to the given UPS standard power configuration. If it is not correct an alarm and event must be posted.If an unsupported module type (power module) is inserted/detected while the UPS is powered and running, it must not force the UPS to shut down or turn off, but the UPS must still warn the user via an alarm and an event in the event log. The unsupported module must not become operable.

Requirement: Available power larger than configured UPS power rating
Description: If the available power (from inverter i.e. power modules) is larger than the configured UPS power rating, the user must be warned via an alarm and an event in the event log.Only the number power modules required for the configured UPS power rating must be enabled and operational. Any additional power modules must not be allowed to operate actively.Example: UPS is configured to a power rating of 400kW, which requires 8x50kW power modules, but 9x50kW power modules are installed in the UPS. Then only 8 power modules must be allowed to operate.  REJECTED: GVL UPS is always scalable, so no alarm needed if available power is larger than configured UPS power rating as UPS power rating is always 500kW.

The UPS must store the frame type as defined in manufacturing.It must be configured in manufacturing of the product.It must be configurable by FSR (UPS Tuner) if the memory is located in a replaceable part

The UPS must support single and dual mains configuration, meaning that any power flow diagram shown to the user must illustrate the correct mains configuration.
It must be possible for the user to configure if the UPS has single or dual mains.It must be logged in the event log if the setting is changed by the user.
Setting to confgure if the UPS is single or dual mains.Range: Single mains / dual mains.Default value: Single mains. Setting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Single/dual mains - setting has been changed
The UPS must support both 3 and 4 wire AC wiring systems (with or without neutral)

Requirement: Only show phase-phase voltage measurements when UPS is configured for 3-wire
Description: When UPS is configured for 3-wire operation only the phase-phase, and no phase-neutral, voltage measurements for input, bypass and output muste be shown in display.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: AC wiring configuration - setting has been changed
The purpose of the neutral bonding contactor is to connect the neutral to earth when activated.

Requirement: Configurable if neutral bonding contactor is present or not
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure if a neutral bonding contactor is present or not in the product.Only if configured as present the UPS must control, and expect status feedback from, the neutral bonding contactor.

Requirement: Monitoring af neutral bonding contactor status
Description: The UPS must monitor the status (open/closed) of the neutral bonding contactor and report this in the event log.

Requirement: Notify user if neutral bonding contactor is not working correctly
Description: The user must be notified via an alarm if the neutral bonding contactor is not activated when it is supposed to, or is activated when it is supposed to be deactivated.
The bonding contactor must be closed within 200 ms after the conditions to close it has been fulfilled.
Battery operation bonded:- UPS must close bonding contactor in battery operation only.

Battery operation bonded:- A parallel UPS must close its neutral bonding contactor in battery operation and inverter standby. - All other parallel UPS units in the parallel system must close the neutral bonding contactor if one or more UPS units (with UOB closed) are in battery operation or inverter standby.- If a parallel UPS is isolated from the remaining system (UOB open) it must control its neutral bonding contactor independently of the parallel system:-- The UPS with UOB open must only close the neutral bonding contactor when it is in battery operation.  -- The parallel system must ignore the status of the UPS with UOB open when it comes to controlling the neutral bonding contactor.- During self-test with UOB closed, the UPS must determine the status of other parallel UPS units and their bonding contactor status before it enters any operation mode.
Setting for whether or not a neutral bonding contactor is present in the UPS. Possible values:Present / Not present Default value:Not present
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Bonding contactor activated
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Bonding contactor deactivated

Type: AlarmSeverity: CriticalCorrective Action Text: Check bonding contactor connectionDescription: Input relay monitoring the status of the bonding contactor reports that it is open although it should be closed

Requirement: Bonding contactor not opened correctly - cleared
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Input relay monitoring the status of the bonding contactor reports that it is closed although it should be open, is not longer present

Type: AlarmSeverity: CriticalCorrective Action Text: Check bonding contactor connectionDescription: Input relay monitoring the status of the bonding contactor reports that it is closed although it should be open

Requirement: Neutral bonding contactor present - setting changed
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Neutral bonding contactor present - setting changed

When an UPS is supplied by a generator source on the input, the strength of the source during a load step (e.g. the UPS changing from battery to normal operation) can vary.If the source is not able to handle the speed of the load change, then the source frequency will decrease risking that the UPS returns to battery operation caused by low input frequency.In order to avoid this, the UPS must ramp in the input current over a certain time, when going from battery to normal operation.
It must be possible for the user to configure the input ramp-in time (between 1 to 300 seconds).

If the configured input ramp-in time is not long enough to support the given generator source, an adaptive input ramp-in feature must step into action.The adaptive current ramp-in checks for the following scenario during ramp-in…Input frequency is dropping below 45Hz.If the scenario is present, the PFC input ramp-in time must automatically be changed to the value of 40 seconds and the ramp-in must be completed at this speed. After this, the ramp-in time must automatically be reset to the configured value.If the user configurable ramp-in time is set to a value above 40 seconds, the adaptive ramp-in must be disabled (the adaptive ramp-in time is set to the same value as the configured ramp-in time).
The setting for the ramp-in time must automatically be kept the same for all UPS units in a parallel system.

Setting for the input ramp-in timeRange: 1 second to 300 seconds.Default value: 10 seconds.  Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies:If the UPS energy storage is not set to batteries (if supported by the specific product), the input ramp-in time must always be 1 second and not configurable .
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Input ramp-in time - setting has been changed.

Requirement: Input ramp-in time changed by system
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Input ramp-in time has been changed temporarily by the system.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Input ramp-in has been completed.

The UPS must check the phase rotation on the input.and notify the user if it is incorrect via an alarm and event in the event log.- If an incorrect phase rotation is detected on the mains input at startup, the UPS must be able to turn on and supply the load in normal operation.- If an incorrect phase rotation is detected on the mains input during normal operation, the UPS must continue in normal operation.- If an incorrect phase rotation is detected on the bypass input, the UPS must no longer be able to transfer to static bypass.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The phase rotation on input is fine.
Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: Check input. Please contact Schneider Electric.Description: The phase rotation on input is incorrect.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The phase rotation on bypass is fine.
Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: Check bypass. Please contact Schneider Electric.Description: The phase rotation on bypass is incorrect.

The user must be able to configure the UPS system voltage.The system voltage must only be configurable when the UPS AND the System are in Off Operation or Maintenance Bypass.The allowed values for the UPS system voltage must be based on the configured system voltage range.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: System voltage - setting has been changed
It must be possible to configure the system voltage range of the UPS (400V/480V).This range must then be used to decide which system voltages are allowed to be configured by the user.

Setting for the nominal system voltage range. Range: "Voltage range 400", "Voltage range 480" Default value: "Voltage range 400"Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: Setting is only configurable when the UPS AND the System are in Off Operation or Maintenance Bypass.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: System voltage range - setting has been changed
The UPS must be able to handle an overload on the output, so that it can operate on inverter at a certain overload for a given time before it transfers to static bypass or turns off.
The UPS must support the following overload intervals:>100% to <125%?125% to <150%?150% The allowed overload time for each inteval will be different.

When in output overload, the UPS must increment a timer. When this timer runs out, the UPS must either transfer to static bypass or turn inverter off and drop the load, depending on the circumstances.The timeout value of the overload timer will be different for each of the overload intervals, and can also differ depending on the operation mode of the UPS (battery or normal operation). The exact overload timeout values are defined for each given UPS product.The overload timer must count down when an overload is removed (load < 100%), so that the UPS cannot be overloaded again for the full overload time, right after an overload has been removed.
The user must be notified via an alarm and an entry in the event log in case of an inverter overload.

Requirement: Output relay indicating if inverter overload is active
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure an output relay to activate if inverter overload is active.

The user must be warned if the UPS output load is getting close to an user configurable overload level via a warning alarm and a configurable output relay. There must be a built-in hysteresis so that the warning alarm and a configurable output relay are activated at the configured overload level but cleared/deactivated again when the output load level is 3% lower than the configured overload level.

Requirement: Output relay indicating if output overload warning is active
Description: It must also be possible for the user to configure an output relay to activate if output overload warning is active.
Behavior scenarios specific to single UPS.

Requirement: Overload Higher Than 150% - Bypass not available
Description: Primary Actor(s)-          User.Stakeholders and InterestsUPS              : To protect hardware from damage and overheat.     Pre conditionsUPS system in inverter on operation, Bypass not available Post conditionsOutput voltage is reduced or load is disconnected. Main success scenario1. UPS is in normal operation or battery operation2. UPS is overloaded, with load just above 150%.3. UPS reports system overloaded.4. UPS reduces load to 150% by reducing output voltage.5. UPS reduces load to 100% by reducing output voltage, when the overload time has elapsed.6. Load is disconnected after a certain time limit, if an output voltage fault is detected. Alternative scenario 11. UPS is in normal operation or battery operation2. UPS is overloaded, with load significantly higher than 150%.3. UPS reports system overloaded.4. UPS reduces load to 150% by reducing output voltage.5. Load is disconnected after a certain time limit, if an output voltage fault is detected. Alternative scenario 2 (principle sequence description if load changes while overloaded)1. UPS is in normal operation or battery operation2. UPS is overloaded, with load just above 150%.3. UPS reports system overloaded.4. UPS reduces load to 150% by reducing output voltage.5. The connected load is reduced to below 125% and above 100% when a percentage of the total allowed overload time at max 150% load has elapsed.6. The remaining overload time at is now calculated to be the remaining percentage of the total allowed overload time at max 125% load. 7. UPS reduces load to 100% by reducing output voltage, when the remaining overload time has elapsed.8. Load is disconnected after a certain time limit, if an output voltage fault is detected.  Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Requirement: Overload Between 125% And 150% - Bypass not available
Description: Primary Actor(s)-          User.Stakeholders and InterestsUPS              : To protect hardware from damage and overheat.  Pre conditionsUPS system in inverter on operation, Bypass not availablePost conditionsOutput voltage is reduced or load is disconnected. Main success scenario1. UPS is in normal operation or battery operation2. UPS is overloaded, with load above 125% and below 150%.3. UPS report system overloaded.4. UPS reduces load to 100% by reducing output voltage, when the overload time has elapsed.5. Load is disconnected after a certain time limit, if an output voltage fault is detected.Alternative scenario 1 (principle sequence description if load changes while overloaded)1. UPS is in normal operation or battery operation2. UPS is overloaded, with load above 125% and below 150%.3. UPS report system overloaded.4. The connected load is reduced to below 125% and above 100% when a percentage of the total allowed overload time at max 150% load has elapsed.5. The remaining overload time at is now calculated to be the remaining percentage of the total allowed overload time at max 125% load.6. UPS reduces load to 100% by reducing output voltage, when the remaining overload time has elapsed.7. Load is disconnected after a certain time limit, if an output voltage fault is detected.Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

The UPS must monitor the bypass backfeed breaker and notify the user via an alarm and an event in the event log, if the breaker is not reported as opened after it has been tripped.- After the bypass backfeed breaker has been tripped, the UPS must check the voltage measured at the point between the bypass backfeed breaker and the static bypass switch thyristors, and the status reported by the AUX switch on the bypass backfeed breaker. - If the status reported by the AUX contact on the bypass backfeed breaker is 'open' and no voltage is measured, the bypass backfeed protection is working correctly.{Image: D13E219C-AAF2-4CB6-9CC2-E0377908BCAC.bmp}- If the status reported by the AUX contact on the bypass backfeed breaker is 'closed' and a voltage is measured, the bypass backfeed protection is NOT working correctly and an alarm must be posted. The bypass backfeed breaker did not trip (not open).{Image: BF79112E-F398-4762-8C36-01797308C3F2.bmp}- If the status reported by the AUX contact on the bypass backfeed breaker is 'closed' and no voltage is measured, the bypass backfeed protection is NOT working correctly and an alarm must be posted. The bypass backfeed breaker did trip but the AUX switch is not working correctly.{Image: 3B5D53B0-4474-4730-9B57-83D192D1030E.bmp}- If the status reported by the AUX contact on the bypass backfeed breaker is 'open' and a voltage is measured, the bypass backfeed protection is NOT working correctly and an alarm must be posted. Either the bypass backfeed breaker is actually not open (breaker did not trip and AUX switch is not working correctly), or the static bypass switch thyristor(s) is/are shorted.{Image: 08A478AE-2E23-4B23-BA16-3B05BA2D4B86.bmp}
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: All Power module fans are OK. Instance must indicate which power module

Requirement: Bonding contactor not closed correctly - cleared
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Input relay monitoring the status of the bonding contactor reports that it is open although it should be closed, is not longer present
UPS must provide a certain set of basic identification parameters.

Setting for the nominal system voltage. Range: 380/400/415/440/480V Default value: 400V Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies:- Setting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup. Setting is only configurable when the UPS AND the System are in Off Operation or Maintenance Bypass.- The voltage values available (range of this setting) must depend on the value of the system voltage range setting.  System voltage range 400V: Available system voltage settings are 380/400/415/440V  System voltage range 480V: Available system voltage settings are 480V
The UPS must store the commercial reference (SKU) numberIt must be configurable by FSR (UPS Tuner).

Requirement: Available power lower than configured UPS power rating
Description: If the available power (from inverter i.e. power modules) is lower than the configured UPS power rating, the user must be warned via an alarm and an event in the event log.UPS cannot supply more power to the load than the available power, when in inverter operation.Example: UPS is configured to a power rating of 400kW, which requires 8x50kW power modules, but only 7x50kW power modules are installed in the UPS. The UPS will be fully operational but the available power (from inverter) will only be 350kW.REJECTED: GVL UPS is always scalable, so no alarm needed if available power is lower than configured UPS power rating

- The scalable options sold are 200kW-500kW, 300kW-500kW and 400kW-500kW. - In a scalable UPS only one power module must be expected to always be present, meaning no alarms must be shown even if there are less than 4 power modules present in the UPS (below 200kW). - The nominal power rating of the UPS must decide the maximum allowed number of power modules to be present. The nominal power rating must always be fixed at 500kW, so maximum allowed number of power modules must always be 10. - Any number of power modules between the minimum allowed number and the maximum allowed number must be optional in a scalable UPS. - As long as the number of present power modules in the UPS, no matter their physical location, is equal to or above 1 and equal to or below 10, no alarms for incorrect number of power modules must be shown.- If an optional power module is removed (not present) from the scalable UPS, no alarms must be shown for the removed power module. If communication is lost to an optional power module that is present it must still be alarmed. Only if an optional power module is removed physically no alarms must be shown. - As soon as a power module is detected as present, any alarms related to this power module must be shown to the user. - If no power modules are detected present in a scalable UPS, it must be alarmed to the user that no power modules are available in the UPS.

Setting to indicate the AC wiring of the UPS.Range:""3-wire""""4-wire or 3-wire solid grounded"" Default value: ""4-wire or 3-wire solid grounded"" Two options are available:""3-wire"": 3p+gnd/earth without internal bonding""4-wire or 3-wire solid grounded"": 3p+n+gnd/earth or 3p+gnd/earth with solid groundingSetting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup. Setting is only configurable when the UPS AND the System are in Off Operation or Maintenance Bypass

Select which High Efficiency Mode (ECO Mode or ECOnversion) the UPS shall use.  Possible values: Disable, ECO Mode, ECOnversion, Disabled by system.Default value: Disable Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies:- ECO Mode is only available if the ECO Mode enable setting is set to enable.- Setting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.- The value "Disabled by system" cannot be configured by the user but only by the system.
