Description: Primary Actor(s)-          User.Stakeholders and InterestsUPS              : To protect hardware from damage and overheat.     Pre conditionsUPS system in inverter on operation, Bypass out of tolerance (voltage and/or frequency out of tolerance, UPS is synchronized to Mains 2)Post conditionsOutput voltage is reduced or Forced static bypass operation overloaded. Main success scenario1. UPS is in normal operation or battery operation2. UPS is overloaded, with load above 125% and below 150%.3. UPS report system overloaded.4. UPS reduces load to 100% by reducing output voltage, when the overload time has elapsed.5. UPS into forced static bypass operation, if an output voltage fault is detected.Alternative scenario 1 (principle sequence description if load changes while overloaded)1. UPS is in normal operation or battery operation2. UPS is overloaded, with load above 125% and below 150%.3. UPS report system overloaded.4. The connected load is reduced to below 125% and above 100% when a percentage of the total allowed overload time at max150% load has elapsed.5. The remaining overload time at is now calculated to be the remaining percentage of the total allowed overload time at max125% load.6. UPS reduces load to 100% by reducing output voltage, when the remaining overload time has elapsed.7. UPS into forced static bypass operation, if an output voltage fault is detected. Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Requirement: Overload Between 100% And 125% - Bypass out of tolerance
Description: Primary Actor(s)-          User.Stakeholders and InterestsUPS              : To protect hardware from damage and overheat.Pre conditionsUPS system in inverter on operation, Bypass out of tolerance (voltage and/or frequency out of tolerance, UPS is synchronized to Mains 2)Post conditionsOutput voltage is reduced or Forced static bypass operation overloaded. Main success scenario1. UPS is overloaded, with load just above 100%.2. UPS report system overloaded.3. UPS reduces load to 100% by reducing output voltage, when the overload time has elapsed.Alternative scenario1. UPS is overloaded, with just below 125% load.2. UPS report system overloaded.3. UPS reduces load to 100% by reducing output voltage, when the overload time has elapsed.4. UPS into forced static bypass operation, if an output voltage fault is detected. Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Primary Actor(s)-          User.Stakeholders and InterestsUPS              : Possible return to nominal output voltage or return to inverter operation.     Pre conditionsUPS system overloaded in inverter on operation or in forced static bypass operation.Post conditionsInverter on operation, no overload.Main success scenario 1. UPS in inverter on operation overloaded  2. UPS load is reduced to below 100%.  3. UPS no longer overloaded.  4. Overload counter is counted down to zero.Alternative scenarios 1. UPS in forced static bypass operation overloaded.  2. UPS load is reduced to below 100%.  3. UPS into inverter on operation.  4. UPS no longer overloaded.  5. Overload counter is counted down to zero.Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA
Behavior scenarios specific to parallel UPS system.

Requirement: Overload Between 100% And 125% - Bypass not available
Description: Primary Actor(s)-          User.Stakeholders and InterestsParallel UPS system   : To protect hardware from damage and overheat.   Pre conditionsParallel UPS system in inverter on operation - bypass unavailablePost conditionsParallel system output voltage reduced or Inverter off.Main success scenario 1. Parallel system is overloaded with load just above 100% system load.  2. UPS report parallel system and UPS overload.  3. Individual UPS reduce load to 100% kW or current after overload time by reducing output voltage.Alternative scenarios 1. Parallel system is overloaded with just below 125% system load.  2. UPS reduce load to 100% kW or current after overload time by reducing output voltage.  3. Load is disconnected, due to output voltage fault in each UPS.  4. Parallel system turns off and drops the load.Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Primary Actor(s)-          User.Stakeholders and InterestsParallel UPS system   : To protect hardware from damage and overheat.   Pre conditionsParallel UPS system in inverter on operation - bypass availablePost conditionsParallel system in forced static bypass operation or inverter off.Main success scenario 1. Parallel system is overloaded with load between 100% and 125% system load.  2. UPS report parallel system and UPS overload.  3. Parallel system into forced static bypass operation after overload time (refer to ???).Alternative scenarios 1. Bypass mains unavailable on one or more UPS’s of parallel system.  2. Parallel system is overloaded, with load between 100% and 125% system load.  3. UPS report parallel system and UPS overload.  4. Parallel system into forced static bypass operation after overload time (refer to ???).  5. Load increase on UPS unit with bypass mains available.  6. Bypass input fuse fault.  7. Parallel system turns off and drops the load.Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

It must be possible for the user, via the display and UPS Tuner, to adjust the output voltage of the UPS up to +/- 3% to compensate for different cable lengths.

Setting for adjusting the output voltage to compensate for different cable lenghts. Default value: 0%Range: -3.0% to 3.0%Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: Setting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Output voltage compensation - setting has been changed.

It must be prevented that the UPS toggles in and out of forced static bypass operation continuously within a short time period. Therfore, if the UPS enters forced static bypass operation 10 times within 75 seconds, it must be locked in forced static bypass operation.The user must be able to unlock the system again by activating the on button (allowing the system to return to inverter operation)

Requirement: User must be notified if UPS is locked in bypass
Description: The user must be notified if the UPS has been locked in forced static bypass operation due to the bypass toggle handling.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The system is no longer locked in bypass operation.

Type: AlarmSeverity: CriticalCorrective Action Text: The system has toggled between inverter operation and bypass operation more than 10 times within 75 seconds. Please press inverter ON button to transfer back to normal operation.Description: The system is locked in bypass operation.

Requirement: Transfer to forced static bypass with bypass out of tolerance
Description: The UPS must be able to transfer to forced static bypass operation even if the bypass input is out of tolerance with regards to voltage and frequency, or if the inverter is not synchronized to the bypass input.

Requirement: Transfer to static bypass with a break
Description: The UPS must be able to transfer to forced static bypass operation with a break in the output voltage if the inverter is not synchronized to the bypass input.

Requirement: Transfer to static bypass when bypass is out of tolerance must be configurable
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure if the UPS shall transfer to forced static bypass with bypass out of tolerance, or it shall instead turn off the output.This setting determines if the UPS is alowed to transfer to, and stay in forced static bypass operation, when bypass is out of tolerance, meaning that the RMS voltage is above or below the output tolerance set by the user

Requirement: Transfer break time to static bypass must be configurable
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure the break time when transferring to static bypass with a break.

Requirement: User initiated transfer to static bypass with break must be confirmed
Description: If the transfer to static bypass with a break is requested by the user, a warning must be displayed to allow the user to confirm the transfer.

Setting to configure break duration in ms. when shifting to an asynchronous bypass.  Range: 8 to 1000 msDefault: 10 msRequired check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: Setting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.

Requirement: Transfer to static bypass with bypass out of tolerance setting
Description: Setting to allow transfer to static bypass even if bypass is out of tolerance. Range Yes/noDefault value: Yes Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: Setting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.

Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Off button has been pushed while inverter is on and with no bypass available. User has either confirmed that the UPS turns off the power to the load or transfers to static bypass with a break, or chosen to continue in inverter operation.

Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: Confirm or abort using the displayDescription: Off button has been pushed while inverter is on and with no bypass available. User must confirm that the UPS turns off the power to the load or transfers to static bypass with a break.

Requirement: Bypass open transition time - setting changed
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Bypass open transition time - setting has been changed

Requirement: Transfer to static bypass with bypass out of tolerance - setting changed
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Transfer to static bypass with bypass out of tolerance - setting has been changed
The UPS must automatically transfer to forced static bypass (emergency bypass) should the core control of the UPS stop responding and/or reboot.
The UPS must transfer to emergency bypass within 5 ms. or faster after the core control has stopped responding.

Requirement: Emergency bypass not allowed in parallel system
Description: When the UPS is part of a parallel UPS system it must not be able to transfer to emergency bypass. All transfers in and out of static bypass must be controlled by the parallel master.

Primary Actor(s)-          UPS.Stakeholders and InterestsUPS              : Behavior when watchdog is active.Pre conditionsThe UPS is either in off, normal or bypass operation and batteries are connected.Post conditionsUPS must supply conditioned power to load if possible.Main success scenario 1. UPS is in inverter operation or requested static bypass operation or ECO mode or ECOnversion mode (the bypass input voltage is within configured bypass voltage tolerance on all three phases).  2. Watchdog is triggered on UPS core control (controller not responding).  3. UPS is transferred to emergency static bypass operation.  4. UPS core control will try to restart.  5. If UPS core control restart is successful UPS will return to inverter operation. Alternative scenariosScenario 1a: 1. UPS is in inverter operation. 2. The bypass input voltage is below configured bypass voltage tolerance on all three phases (UPS configured to allow transfer to static bypass with bypass out of tolerance) 3. Watchdog is triggered on UPS core control (controller not responding). 4. UPS is transferred to emergency static bypass operation.  5. UPS core control will try to restart.  6. If UPS core control restart is successful UPS will return to inverter operation.Scenario 1b: 1. UPS is in inverter operation. 2. The bypass input voltage is below configured bypass voltage tolerance on all three phases (UPS configured to not allow transfer to static bypass with bypass out of tolerance) 3. Watchdog is triggered on UPS core control (controller not responding). 4. UPS is transferred to off operation.  5. UPS core control will try to restart.  6. If UPS core control restart is successful UPS will stay in off operation.Scenario 2: 1. UPS is in forced static bypass operation.  2. Watchdog is triggered on UPS core control (controller not responding).   3. UPS is transferred to emergency static bypass operation.  4. UPS core control will try to restart.  5. If UPS core control restart is successful UPS will return to inverter operation if possible else it will return to forced static bypass operation. Scenario 3: 1. UPS is in off operation.  2. Watchdog is triggered on UPS core control (controller not responding)  3. UPS stays in off operation  and does not transfer to emergency static bypass operation.  4. UPS core control will try to restart.  5. If UPS core control restart is successful UPS will stay in off operation. Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Requirement: General status of static bypasss switch
Description: A general status of the static bypass switch must be available to the user as alarms and events. The status must be reported as either:- OK: The SBS is fully operational- Warning: The SBS is fully operational but needs a technical check.- Inoperable: The SBS is inoperable, meaning the UPS cannot transfer to static bypass.

Requirement: Operation mode of SBSC must be reported to user
Description: The UPS must report the current operation mode of the SBSC to the user via events in the event log.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Static bypass switch is OK and working correctly
Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: Description: Please contact Schneider Electric.Description: The static bypass switch needs a technical check but is still fully operational.

Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: Description: Please contact Schneider Electric.Description: Static bypass switch is inoperable. UPS is prevented from going into static bypass operation.

Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: Description: NADescription: The backfeed contactor is closed and the SCR's are off: Static bypass switch is ready to activate if requested.

The SBS must be able to monitor the bypass input and the output, and detect if these are not within the defined tolerances. The following parameters must be monitored:- Voltage - RMS for each phase L1, L2 and L3 of  bypass input and output- Frequency of  bypass input and output- Voltage - DC on output.

Requirement: Out of tolerance detection must be logged
Description: The user must be notified via events in the event log and alarms in the alarm list, if a voltage is detected as being out of tolerance by the voltage quality detection.

DetectionHigh Threshold1Recovery ThresholdOn delayOff delayDC failure on output90 / 50 V70 / 40 V5ms500ms 1 When system is configurated as 220Vp_n, 230Vp_n, 240Vp_n, 255Vp_n and 277Vp_n mode, the DC high threshold is 90V and the recovery is 70V.When system is 115Vp_n, 120p_n and 127Vp_n, the threshold is 70V and the recovery is 40V.

The UPS must check whether the SBS hardware and firmware are compatible with the rest of the UPS system, and the user must be notified via alarms/events if this is not the case.Furthermore, the SBSC firmware version must be stored in the UPS event log to improve debugging and diagnostics possibilities.

Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: Description:Description: Hardware version of the SBSC is compatible.

Requirement: Energy storage type must be configurable
Description: The user must be able to configure which type (battery, flywheel, ultra capacitors etc. depending on what is supported by the UPS) of energy storage is connected to the UPS.

The user must be informed about the general battery status (OK or inoperable) via an event and an alarm.The conditions for activating the ""battery is not working correctly"" alarm should be the same as for indicating battery inoperable in the UPS mimic. Meaning one or more of the below conditions are true (depending on which features are available/enabled in the product):- Battery voltage out of tolerance (high and low)- Battery voltage collapse- Battery configuration invalid- Battery capacity is below minimum acceptable level- Battery room ventilation inoperable- External battery monitoring detected fault- Battery fuse blown or battery relay is not working correctly- Battery not connected
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Battery is working correctly.
Type: AlarmSeverity: CriticalCorrective Action Text: Please contact Schneider Electric.Description: A battery is not working correctly.

The user must be able to configure the UPS to support different battery configurations.The following parameters must be configurable by the user:- Battery type (VRLA, Ni-Cd, Li-Ion etc. depending on what is supported by the UPS).- Battery block capacity (Ah)*.- Number of cells in battery- Number of batteries in series- Number of battery strings*.*It must be possible to set this individually for each battery breaker present in the system. If the battery breaker is open (or set as not present), the total Ah connected through this given battery breaker can then be subtracted from the total Ah connected to the UPS.The UPS must notify the user, using alarms and the event log, if the battery configuration done is invalid.

Requirement: Support for battery with and without a midpoint
Description: It must be possible for the UPS to support both a battery configuration with and without a midpiont (split or single battery).The user must be able to configure if the battery connected to the UPS has a midpoint or not.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The battery configuration is correct..

Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: Check and correct battery settings.Description: The configuration of the settings for number of batteries in series, number of cells in battery and nominal cell voltage does not match the battery voltage range of the UPS.

Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Number of battery strings - setting has been changed

Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Number of cells in battery - setting has been changed
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Battery block capacity - setting has been changed
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Battery type - setting has been changed

Requirement: Number of batteries in series - setting changed
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Number of batteries in series - setting has been changed
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Battery midpoint present - setting has been changed
Setting to configure if the battery has a midpoint or not.Range: Present / not presentDefault value: Not presentSetting is only configurable when the UPS is in Off Operation or Maintenance Bypass

Setting for the number of parallel battery strings present (one individual setting for each battery breaker in the system). Lead-acid:Range: 1 to 8Default value: 1Ni-Cd:Range: 1 to 32Default value: 1Li-ion:Range: 1 to 32Default value: 1Setting must only be configurable when the UPS is in Off Operation or Maintenance Bypass
Setting for the battery type.Range: VRLA, open cell, Li-Ion, NiCdDefault value: VRLA Setting must only be configurable when the UPS is in Off Operation or Maintenance Bypass

Setting for the battery block capacity in Ah (one individual setting for each battery breaker in the system). Range: 0 to 4000Default value: 0Li-ion:Range: 0 to 400Default value: 0

Requirement: Number of cells in battery setting
Description: Setting for the number of cells in batteryLead-acid:Range:  1-12 cellsDefault: 6 cellsNi-Cd:Range: 1-10 cellsDefault: 6 cellsLi-ion:Range: 1-21 cellsDefault: 8 cells Setting must only be configurable when the UPS is in Off Operation or Maintenance Bypass

Requirement: Battery configuration based on standard battery cabinet SKU
Description: For an UPS using standard battery cabinets, it must be possible for the user to configure the basic battery settings based on the battery SKU number via UPS Tuner.  The user must only be required to configure:- How many battery breakers are present- How many battery cabinets are connected to each present battery breaker- The battery cabinet SKU number of the conneceted battery cabinets (all connected battery cabinets must have the same SKU number).The battery settings must be configured automatically by the UPS based on the above settings. Only Li-ion standard battery cabinet SKUs must be supported in GVL (no VRLA standard battery cabinet SKUs exist).

Requirement: Fixed basic battery settings for standard battery cabinet SKUs
Description: REJECTED AND REPLACED BY WHAT40152.

It must be possible for the FSR to configure the UPS to use a custom battery. In a custom battery setup, it must be possible to manually configure all the basic battery settings, which are automatically set in a SKU-based battery configuration (see list of these settings in the table in WHAT41061 - "Fixed basic battery settings for standard battery cabinet SKUs").In addition to the basic settings from the SKU-based battery configuration, the following settings must also be available for a custom battery configuration (also see the list of requirements traced to this requirement under the "Traceability" tab):{Image: 47BC4A7B-EE0C-4099-B5A1-CC2B0072E6EE.bmp}

Requirement: Settings to be available in both SKU-based and custom battery configuration
Description: Some battery settings must always be available for the user to configure, no matter if a SKU-based or custom battery configuration is selected:{Image: 0CF50838-E66E-4182-AB2C-6CF4DABA98AC.bmp}(also see the list of requirements traced to this requirement under the "Traceability" tab).

Requirement: Switch between SKU-based and custom battery configuration
Description: If the user switches from a custom battery configuration to a SKU-based battery configuration, the UPS must remember the custom battery configuration and not overwrite it with the settings from the SKU-based battery configuration.This way, the user can switch from a custom battery configuration to a SKU-based battery configuration, and back to a custom battery configuration again, without loosing the settings originally done in the custom battery configuration.As soon as the user wants to change any of the settings that are automatically set in a SKU-based battery configuration, the user must use a custom battery configuration instead.

The UPS must validate that the entered combination of settings for a custom battery configuration is correct and supported by the UPS.If the configuration is not supported, the user must be notified via an alarm and an event in the event log, and the invalid settings must be indicated in the battery configuration screen(s).
The UPS must monitor the voltage of the connected energy storage, and report to the user if it is out of tolerance using alarms and the event log.

The UPS must monitor the battery voltage, and detect if it arises above a defined high warning level and a defined high shutdown level.If the battery voltage arises above the warning level, the charger must be turned off, and not turned on again untill the battery voltage is below the warning level.It must be reported to the user, via alarms and events, both in the case where the battery voltage reaches the warning level and in case it reaches the shutdown level.
The battery high voltage warning level must be:Lead-acid:2.53 V/cellNiCd:1.8 V/cell
The battery high voltage shutdown level must be a fixed value at 750 V.

If the energy storage is not available, for example due to a faulty battery or an open battery breaker, when the UPS transfers to battery operation, the UPS must be able to detect this fast enough to transfer to forced static bypass (if available) without dropping the load.To enable this, the UPS must monitor the battery voltage, and detect if it suddenly collapses (drops be low a defined level).It must be reported to the user, via alarms and events, if the battery voltage collapses.
The battery voltage collapse level must be at 0.55*nominal battery voltage.The battery voltage collapse clear condition level must be at 0.605*nominal battery voltage (corresponds to 10% hysteresis).

Requirement: User configurable low battery shutdown level
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure the low battery shutdown level for the UPS.The low battery shutdown level must be based on the lowest value (configurable) at a discharge CA rate of 3 and above, and then dynamically increased as the discharge CA rate is lowered.The low battery warning level must be calculated based on the low battery shutdown level with an offset of 0.1V/cell. {Image: E54825DA-B2F1-4579-8E07-EEDF31F05B86.bmp}In the figure above the value for low battery shutdown level has been set to 1.65V/cell.

Setting for low battery shutdown level (at 3C) setting in volt/cell. Lead-acid:Range:  1.60 - 1.75 volt/cellDefault: 1.60 volt/cellNiCd:Range: 0.5-1.1 V/cellDefault: 1.00V/cellLi-ion:Range 2.0-3.2 V/cellDefault:  3.0V/cell

Description: Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: Check battery voltage and battery settings.Description: The battery voltage is above high warning level.

Requirement: Battery voltage out of tolerance - voltage above high shutdown level
Description: Type: AlarmSeverity: CriticalCorrective Action Text: Check battery voltage and battery settings.Description:  The battery voltage is above high shutdown level.

Requirement: Battery voltage out of tolerance - voltage below warning level
Description: Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: Check battery voltage and battery settings.Description: The battery voltage is below warning level.

Requirement: Battery voltage out of tolerance - voltage below shutdown level
Description: Type: AlarmSeverity: CriticalCorrective Action Text: Check battery voltage and battery settings.       Description: The battery voltage is below shutdown level.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: A battery voltage collapse no longer exists.

Requirement: Battery voltage out of tolerance - voltage collapse detected
Description: Type: AlarmSeverity: CriticalCorrective Action Text: Check battery voltage and battery settingsDescription: The battery voltage is below collapse level.
Information about if the batteries are currently being charged, discharged or are resting, must be available to the user as a status and as events in the event log.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The UPS is charging the batteries.
Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The load is drawing more power than the UPS can draw from the input, causing the UPS to draw power from the batteries
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The UPS batteries are resting.
Status indicating if the battery is currently being charged, discharged or is resting.Possible values: Charging, discharging, resting.

When the battery is either fully recharged or fully discharged, this information must be available to the user as events in the event log.- Batteries are fully charged when the estimated charge level is 98% or above.- Batteries are fully discharged when the estimated charge level is 4% or below.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Batteries are fully charged (the estimated charge level is 98% or above)
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Batteries are fully discharged (the estimated charge level is 4% or below)
Float charge is the basic charge function available on all types of batteries and automatically initiated by the charger.

It must be possible for the user to manually initiate float charge if the UPS is currently in boost or equalization charge mode.It must be logged in the event log if manual float charge is activated by the user.

Requirement: Float charge voltage must be configurable
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure the float charge voltage.It must be logged in the event log if the setting is changed by the user.

Setting to configure the battery float charge. Range and default value depends on battery type: Lead-acid:Range: 2.23V to 2.30VDefault: 2.27V/cellNi-Cd:Range: 1.4 - 1.7 V/cellDefault: 1.4V/cellLi-ion:Range: 3.4 - 4.2 V/cellDefault: 4.2V/cell
Activate float charge via button on the display touch screen and/or a command from UPS Tuner.This command aborts an ongoing boost or equalization charge.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Float charge voltage - setting has been changed
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Float charge has been activated by user.

Boost charge mode gives the user a possibility to conduct a fast charge in order to quickly restore a discharged battery. For boost charge to be available boost charge mode must be enabled by the user.In boost charge mode the charge voltage level is set at the defined boost charge level and the boost charge is time limited.
No matter the configuration, boost charging must only be allowed for lead-acid and NiCd batteries.

Requirement: Boost charging allowed must be configurable
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure if boost charge mode is allowed or not.
It must be possible for the user to manually initiate (and abort) a single boost charge to be conducted.It must be logged in the event log if manual boost charge is activated or aborted by the user.

An automatic boost charge function must be available. The automatic boost charge must transfer the charger to boost charger mode after the system has been in battery operation.It must be possible to enable and disable the automatic boost charge mode.It must be logged in the event log if the setting is changed by the user.

Requirement: Boost charge voltage must be configurable
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure the boost charge voltage.It must be logged in the event log if the setting is changed by the user.

Requirement: Boost charge time must be configurable
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure the boost charge time.It must be logged in the event log if the setting is changed by the user.
Enable/disable boost charge mode. This setting indicates if the UPS is allowed to enter boost charge.  Range: Enable/disableDefault value: Disable.

Setting to configure the battery boost charge voltage. Range and default value depends on battery type: Lead-acid:Range: 2.23V to 2.40VDefault: 2.38V/cellNiCd:Range: 1.4 - 1.7 V/cellDefault: 1.45V/cell
Setting for the boost charge timeLead-acid:Range: 1 to 50 hoursDefault value: 8 hours NiCd:Range: 5 to 15 hoursDefault value: 12 hours

Enable/disable that the UPS automatically enters boost charge mode. Rnage: Enable/disableDefault value: Disable. Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: Boost charge mode must be enabled.
Activate Boost Charge via button on the display touch screen and/or a command from UPS Tuner.
Indicates if it is allowed to activate Boost Charge. Used to ""grey out"" button on the display touch screen and UPS Tuner.

Requirement: Boost charge mode enable - setting changed
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Boost charge mode enable - setting has been changed.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Boost charge voltage - setting has been changed
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Boost charge time - setting has been changed

Requirement: Auto boost charge enable - setting changed
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Auto boost charge enable - setting has been changed.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Boost charge has been activated by user.

Equalization charging is to be used when equalizing skew open cell batteries. This is the charge method using the highest possible charge voltage level. When equalization charging is conducted water is evaporated from the open cell batteries which must be replaced when charging is completed.Equalization charge is initiated manually and only available for open cell batteries. After end of equalization charge the system must go back to the default charge mode (float/boost/cyclic).

It must be possible for the user to manually initiate (and abort) a single equalization charge to be conducted.It must be logged in the event log if manual boost equalization is activated or aborted by the user.
Equalization charging must only be allowed for open cell lead acid batteries and NiCd batteries.

Requirement: Equalization charge voltage must be configurable
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure the equalization charge voltage.It must be logged in the event log if the setting is changed by the user.

Requirement: Equalization charge time must be configurable
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure the equalization charge time.It must be logged in the event log if the setting is changed by the user.

Setting to configure the battery equalization charge voltage. Range and default value depends on battery type: Lead-acid:Range: 2.23V to 2.50VDefault: 2.45V/cellNi-Cd:Range: 1.4V to 1.7VDefault: 1.5V/cell
Setting for the equalization charge timeLead-acid:Range: 1 to 48 hoursDefault value: 8 hours NiCd:Range: 1 to 48 hoursDefault value: 8 hours
Activate Equalization charger via button on the display touch screen and/or a command from UPS Tuner.
Indicates if it is allowed to activate Equalization Charge. Used to ""grey out"" button on the display touch screen and UPS Tuner.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Equalization charge has been activated by user.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Equalization charge time - setting has been changed
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Equalization charge voltage - setting has been changed

Cyclic charge mode cycles between periods of float charge and resting. This function will continuously maintain the battery charge status without stressing the batteries by conducting a permanent float charge.When cyclic charging is enabled, a float charge will be conducted until the battery is fully charged. The charger is then transferred to a rest state where the battery is not being charged. After end of rest state the charger conducts a new float charge period.
It must be possible for the user to enable/disable and configure the automatic cyclic charge mode.
Cyclic charging must only be allowed for lead acid and Li-Ion batteries.

Requirement: Battery voltage to exit resting mode
Description: The battery charger must exit resting mode if the battery voltage is equal to or below:Default values:Lead acid: 2.1 V/cellNiCd: 1.3 V/cellLi-Ion: 4.1 V/cell

Requirement: User configurable battery voltage to exit resting mode
Description: The minimum battery voltage, where the battery charger must exit resting mode, must be configurable by the user.
The battery charger must exit resting mode after 48 hours (default value).

Requirement: User configurable time in resting mode
Description: The time, after which the battery charger must exit resting mode, must be configurable by the user.
The battery charger must stay in float mode for one hour (default value) after the battery has been fully charged before transferring to resting mode.

Requirement: User configurable time in float mode
Description: The time the battery charger must stay in float mode after the battery has been fully charged before transferring to resting mode, must be configurable by the user.
Enable/disable that the UPS automatically enters cyclic charge mode. Range: Enable/disableDefault value: Disable.

Requirement: Auto cyclic charge mode float time setting
Description: Setting for tfloat in minutes. See figure for cyclic charge.Setting is only used if Auto Cyclic Charge Mode is set to Enabled.Range: 1 to 1440 minutes. 0 = OffDefault value: 60 minutes.                             {Image: D4956311-3861-4C09-9282-99BA2473C123.bmp}

Requirement: Auto cyclic charge mode resting time setting
Description: Setting for tOff,max in minutes. See figure for cyclic charge.Setting is only used if Auto Cyclic Charge Mode is set to Enabled.Range: 1 to 32767 minutes. 0 = OffDefault value: 2880 minutes. {Image: A44380E3-FC4B-45A6-B4E9-DA5002E7A319.bmp}

Requirement: Auto cyclic charge mode minimum resting voltage setting
Description: Setting for VFloat,min in V/cell. See figure for cyclic charge.Setting is only used if Auto Cyclic Charge Mode is set to Enabled.Lead acid:Range: ???Default value: 2.1 V/cellNiCd:Range: ???Default Value: 1.3 V/cellLi-Ion:Range: 3.0 to 4.2 V/cell.Default value: 4.1 V/cell.{Image: 4C02D2EE-9C8C-4DC1-B10B-828B4D39468C.bmp}

Requirement: Auto cyclic charge mode - setting changed
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Auto cyclic charge mode - setting has been changed.
The current charging mode of the charger must be available to the user as a status and in the UPS event log.
The current operational status of the charger must be available to the user.
The UPS must provide information to the user about the estimated charge time left before the connected energy storage has reached 80% charge level.

The charger must limit the charge current according to the charging conditions.Parameters like - battery Ah rating- configured charge CA rating - configured UPS power rating- configured charger capacity- maximum UPS input current - ambient temperaturemust be taken into account when determining the charge current limit.When the charger enters and exits current limitation it must be logged in the UPS event log.
The charge current rate (CA rate) must be configurable by the user

It must be possible to charge the batteries when the UPS is in static bypass.The battery charge current must always be limited to 10% of system rating up to 90% load and 1% of system rating at 100% load, when the UPS is in static bypass (requested static bypass, ECO mode, ECOnversion mode)

Requirement: Charging from inverter when in static bypass
Description: The UPS must be able to charge the batteries when in static bypass with no mains input available.If the PFC/mains input is not available, the power must be drawn from bypass input through inverter to the DC bus. From the DC bus the charger is then able to transfer the power to the batteries.

The charge voltage reference must be decreased based on the battery temperature within a given temperature interval. When the battery temperature reaches a certain limit, the charger voltage must be decreased by a fixed number of mV pr. cell pr. degree C (number depends on the battery type and charge mode), until the battery temperature reaches 40 degrees C.{Image: C87D5789-917A-4FA8-9038-37E0F9AD1222.bmp}Charge voltage compensation must be implemented in all charge modes and reference voltage levels for lead-acid and NiCd batteries, but not Li-ion batteries.
The temperature compensated charge voltage level must be adjusted according to the battery type:Lead-acid: Float charge: -3.3 mV/cell pr. degree CBoost charge: -5.0 mV/cell pr. degree C

Requirement: User adjustable nominal battery temperature reference
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure the nominal battery temperature, where the temperature compensation of the charge voltage must begin.{Image: D29C5B73-97C7-4648-B14A-46708A460064.bmp}

Nominal temperature given by the battery suppliers for charging voltage. Lead-acid:Range:  0 - 40 degrees CDefault: 25 degrees CNiCd:Range: 0 - 40 degrees CDefault: 25 degrees CLi-ion:Range: -10 - 50 degrees CDefault: 30 degrees C
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Battery temperature reference - setting has been changed

To prevent battery thermal runaway, the charger must turn off if the battery temperature reaches 45°C (45°C or above for 60 seconds), and must not turn on again before the battery temperature drops below 40°C. For Li-ion batteries the charger must turn off at 65°C (65°C or above for 60 seconds), and turn on again when the battery temperature is below 60°C.The levels are fixed and cannot be changed by the user.This feature must only be active when UPS is configured with battery as energy storage type - both for modular battery solution and classic battery solution (VRLA, open cell and Li-ion).

Requirement: Alarm user when the charger is turned off due to high battery temperature
Description: A warning alarm must be posted when the charger is turned off due to high battery temperature.

Requirement: Charger shutdown due to high battery temperature - cleared
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: N/ADescription: The charger shutdown due to a high battery temperature has been cleared.

Requirement: Charger shutdown due to high battery temperature
Description: Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: Check the battery temperature.Description: The charger has been shut down due to a high battery temperature.

Requirement: User notification of reduced charge power
Description: If the UPS reaches charge current limitation due to that the nominal charge power of the UPS has been reduced*, the user must be notified about this via an alarm and event in the event log.*The nominal charge power can be reduced either due to:- The "UPS running on generator" dry contact input is activated, hence the maximum charge power is lowered - The input current of the UPS has reached its maximum limit for example due to low mains, or due to a configured maximum allowed input current.
It must be possible for the user to configure the maximum charging power of the UPS as a percentage of the nominal UPS power rating, and a change of this setting must be logged in the event log.
Setting for the charge current rate in CLead-acid:Range:  0.1 - 0.3Default: 0.25CNiCd:Range: 0.1 - 0.2Default: 0.2Li-ion:Range 0.1 - 1.0Default: 0.7
Setting for the maximum charge powerRange: 5% to 80% in steps of 1%.Default: 20%.
Shows the current mode of the UPS charger. Possible values: Off, Float, Boost, Equalization, Test.
General status of the charger. Possible values: Ok, Inoperable
The charge level of the connected energy storage in %. Unit: %Precision: 0 decimals.
Remaining recharging time in hh:mm to 100% capacity. Unit: hh:mm

Requirement: Battery charger is not in current limitation
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The battery charger is not currently in current limitation.

Requirement: Battery charger is in current limitation
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The battery charger is currently in current limitation.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Charger is off.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Charge voltage is set to float voltage level.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Charge voltage is set to equalization level.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Charge voltage is set to boost charge level.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Changing between charger off and charger float operational mode.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Charger is tested by forcing it to maximum current level.

Requirement: Charge power is no longer reduced
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Maximum battery charge power is available.

Type: AlarmSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: The input for this functionality was activated, or the input current has reached the maximum limit.   Description: The battery charge power has been reduced.

Requirement: Charge current rate (CA rate) - setting changed
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Charge current rate (CA rate) - setting has been changed
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Charge power - setting has been changed
It must be possible to configure the UPS to discharge the batteries to an even lower voltage level than the normally recommended value (event though there is a risk of battery damage).

Requirement: Battery deep discharge allowed must be configurable
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure if battery deep discharge is allowed or not.
It must be logged in the UPS event log if battery deep discharge allowed is enabled or disabled by the user.
Setting to enable and disable if battery deep discharge is allowedRange: Yes/noDefault value: No
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Deep discharge allowed - setting has been changed.

The UPS must monitor the output load and compare it to the nominal available battery capacity. If the current output load will result in a too high battery discharge current (discharge CA-rate) in battery operation, the user must be notified via an alarm.If the UPS is in battery operation, the actual measured battery discharge current must be used to calculate the discharge CA-rate.If the UPS is not in battery operation, the battery discharge CA-rate must be estimated using the current UPS output load and the lowest possible/allowed battery voltage (worst-case scenario where the UPS is in battery operation and the battery voltage is low).

Requirement: Battery capacity is within acceptable level
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The battery capacity is within the acceptable level according to the current UPS output load.

Requirement: Battery capacity is below minimum acceptable level
Description: Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: Change battery configuration and/or increase battery capacity.Description: The battery capacity is below the minimum level according to the current UPS output load. Risk of battery damage.

The UPS must provide a calculation of the estimated remaining runtime (remaining backup time) of the connected energy storage. The remaining runtime must be shown while operating in normal operation and battery operation, and shall be displayed real-time, even under changing load conditions.

Requirement: Support for different energy storage types
Description: The remaining runtime calculation must support different energy storage types, including different battery technologies and batteries from different vendors. Therefore, the parameters and method used for the runtime calculation must be configurable by the user.

The calculated remaining battery runtime must have an accuracy of +/- 5% for battery solutions (both modular and classic) which are sold as standard SKUs by Schneider Electric. On these battery solutions, the remaining runtime calculation has been tested and validated by Schneider Electric on the actual batteries.For batteries where the above is not the case, the accuracy must be +/-10%. In this case the runtime parameters have been calculated by Schneider Eletcric but no test and validation have been done on the actual batteries.For third-party batteries no accuracy is guaranteed.The +/-5% and +/-10% tolerances are related to the “initial guess” at a 100% SOC (State of Charge) and 100% SOH (State of Health). Once the discharge starts, the requirements are (constant power discharge assumed):- The countdown must not count faster than twice real time- The countdown must not count slower than half the real time- The counter should hit “0” when the UPS passes the shutdown voltage (+/-5 to 10 seconds)
The UPS must be able to post an alarm when a certain level of battery runtime is remaining. This level must be confgurable by the user.

Setup for which battery capacity calculation method is used to calculate the battery runtime. Possible values:1:           CA based runtime (CA = Capacity Ah)2:           CW based runtime (CW = Capacity Watt or WPC = Watt per Cell)3:           CA/CW based runtime for Lithium/NiCd batteries or other energi storage (future use) Default value: 1

Setup for the calculation value 1 used in the battery runtime calculation formula. Range: Full 32 bit value, from 0 to 4,294,967,295Default value: 0, (0 = Not set) Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies:- Range check is depending on Runtine Calculation Method- Value use depends on Runtine Calculation Method. Method 1 and 2: Scale Range check is depending on Runtine Calculation Method:1: CA based runtime -   Range is limited to 0.00001 to 429492: CW based runtime -  Range is limited to 0.00001 to 429493: CA/CW based runtime: TBD

Setup for the calculation value 2 used in the battery runtime calculation formula. Range: Full 32 bit value, from 0 to 4,294,967,295Default value: 0, (0 = Not set) Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies:- Range check is depending on Runtine Calculation Method- Value use depends on Runtine Calculation Method. Method 1 and 2: Expo Range check is depending on Runtine Calculation Method:1: CA based runtime -   Range is limited to 0.00001 to 429492: CW based runtime -  Range is limited to 0.00001 to 429493: CA/CW based runtime: TBD

Setup for the calculation value 3 used in the battery runtime calculation formula. Range: Full 32 bit value, from 0 to 4,294,967,295Default value: 0, (0 = Not set)Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies:- Range check is depending on Runtine Calculation Method- Value use depends on Runtine Calculation Method. Method 1 and 2: SlopeRange check is depending on Runtine Calculation Method:1: CA based runtime -   Range is limited to 0.00001 to 429492: CW based runtime -  Range is limited to 0.00001 to 429493: CA/CW based runtime: TBD

Setup for the calculation value 4 used in the battery runtime calculation formula. Range: Full 32 bit value, from 0 to 4,294,967,295Default value: 0, (0 = No set) Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies:- Range check is depending on Runtine Calculation Method- Value use depends on Runtine Calculation Method. Method 1: Not used. Method 2: Energy (W/cell) Range check is depending on Runtine Calculation Method:1: CA based runtime -   Not relevant2: CW based runtime -  Range is limited to 0.00001 to 429493: CA/CW based runtime: TBD

Setup for the calculation value 5 used in the battery runtime calculation formula. This value is for reading out battery type configured in the UPS.Rules:A new battery manufacturer (Vendor) is given a number +100000 to the last entered manufacturer in listAny new battery (Model) must be given a number +10 to the last entered calculation in listThe list itself is maintained in Box as an Excel sheet named ""BatteriesInformations.xlsx"".

Setup for the calculation value 6 used in the battery runtime calculation formula. Range: Full 32 bit value, from 0 to 4,294,967,295Default value: 0, (0 = Not set)Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies:- Range check is depending on Runtine Calculation Method- Value use depends on Runtine Calculation Method. Method 1: Not used. Method 2: Used for the initial guess of the nominal (or measured) constant power discharge performance of a Li-ion battery.Range check is depending on Runtine Calculation Method:1: CA based runtime -   Not relevant2: CW based runtime -  Range is limited to 0.00001 to 429493: CA/CW based runtime: TBD

Requirement: Battery runtime low warning threshold setting
Description: Setting for at which remaining battery runtime value the UPS must post a warning alarm. Value based on the calculated runtime (in seconds) left on the UPS Range: Off, 60 - 6000 sec (1 - 100 minutes) .Default value: 240 sec.
Status of the estimated remaining energy storage runtimeFor remaining runtime > 1 hourUnit: HH:MMExample: 1h 22m For remaining runtime < 1 hourUnit: MM:SSExample: 4m 59s

Requirement: Battery is above minimum acceptable runtime
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The battery runtime is above configured minimum acceptable value.

Requirement: Battery is below minimum acceptable runtime
Description: Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The battery runtime is below configured minimum acceptable value.

Requirement: Battery runtime low warning threshold - setting changed
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Battery runtime low warning threshold - setting has been changed
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Battery runtime calculation - setting has been changed

A function must be available to test and calibrate the battery runtime.In this test the UPS transfers to Battery Operation and the batteries are discharged to 10% remaining capacity. Based on the elapsed time and information about the load, the battery capacity can be calculated and the estimated runtime calibrated.

To start the battery runtime calibration test the following conditions must be fulfilled:No battery test is running.Batteries must be 100% charged.No critical alarms present.The load percentage must be at least 10% and is not allowed to change more than 20% of the starting value during test. (Ex. if load was 30% when starting, it is allowed to vary between 24%-36%).The bypass supply and static bypass must be available (UPS must be able to transfer to requested static bypass).The UPS operation mode must be normal operation, ECO mode or ECOnversion mode.The system operation mode must be inverter on, ECO mode or ECOnversion mode.

The battery condition must be reported to the user. One of the following conditions must be reported depending on the measured voltage of the battery (see requirement for ""Battery condition estimation"" for more details):·        Battery condition OK: Posted as an event if battery capacity is above 75% of nominal.·        Battery condition weak: Shown as an alarm if battery capacity is between 50% and 75% of nominal.·        Battery condition poor: Shown as an alarm if battery capacity is below 50% of nominal.

Requirement: Battery runtime calibration test status reporting
Description: The UPS must report the status of the battery runtime calibration test to the user in the event log (if the test is inactive, running, aborted, completed etc.).
It must be possible for the user to manually initiate and abort a battery runtime calibration test.

Requirement: User reset of battery aging factor
Description: It must be possible for the user to reset the aging factor calculated by the battery runtime calibration test function, for example in the case where old batteries are replaced by new.

Requirement: Battery runtime calibration test start command
Description: Command to start battery runtime calibration via button on the display touch screen and/or a command from UPS Tuner.

Requirement: Battery runtime calibration test start allowed
Description: Indicates if it is allowed to start a battery runtime calibration test.Used to ""grey out"" button on the display touch screen and UPS Tuner.

Requirement: Battery runtime calibration test abort command
Description: Command to abort battery runtime calibration via button on the display touch screen and/or a command from UPS Tuner.

Requirement: Battery runtime calibration test abort allowed
Description: Indicates if it is allowed to abort a battery runtime calibration test. Used to ""grey out"" button on the display touch screen and UPS Tuner.

Requirement: Battery runtime calibration test aging factor reset
Description: Command to reset the aging factor calculated by the battery runtime calibration test function via button on the display touch screen and/or a command from UPS Tuner.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Battery runtime calibration test is inactive.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Battery runtime calibration test is running

Requirement: Battery runtime calibration test aborted due to critical alarm
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Battery runtime calibration test has been aborted due to a critical alarm
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Battery runtime calibration test has been completed.

Requirement: Battery runtime calibration test activated by user
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: User has activated battery runtime calibration test function.

Requirement: Battery runtime calibration test cancelled by user
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: User has cancelled battery runtime calibration test function.

Requirement: Battery runtime calibration test aging factor reset by user
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Battery runtime calibration test aging factor has been reset by user

The UPS must be able to test that it can run in Battery Operation and that the batteries are OK, without any risk of load drop. So, in case the UPS is not able to support the load during battery self-test, it must return to normal operation, with a transfer over forced static bypass if required. During the battery self-test, the UPS transfers to battery operation for testing the capacity and status of the batteries, including fuses, and the battery operation mode in general.

To start the battery self-test the following conditions must be fulfilled:- No battery test is running.- The remaining runtime available must be more than 4 minutes.- Battery breakers are closed.- No critical alarms present.- The batteries must be 50% charged or more.- The bypass supply and static bypass must be available (UPS must be able to transfer to Requested Static Bypass).- The UPS operation mode must be Normal Operation, ECO Mode or ECOnversion Mode.- The system operation mode must be Inverter On, ECO Mode or ECOnversion Mode.
The UPS must report the status of the battery self-test to the user in the event log (if the test is inactive, running, aborted, completed etc.).

It must be possible for the user to manually initiate and abort a battery self-test.Depending on the configuration done by the user, the manual battery self-test must exit either:- When the battery has been discharged by 10% of the total capacity or- After a certain time or when a certain battery voltage has been reached, what ever comes first.

It must be possible for the user to schedule a battery self-test.The user must be able to configure the interval, the start time and start day of the scheduled battery self-test.The scheduled battery self-test must discharge the batteries by 10% of the total capacity and then exit.

Requirement: User configurable battery self-test discharge time
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure how long time the manual battery self-test must run.

Requirement: User configurable battery self-test discharge voltage
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure the battery discharge voltage limit for when the manual battery self-test must exit.

Command to abort battery self-test via button on the display touch screen and/or a command from UPS Tuner.
Indicates if it is allowed to abort a battery self-test. Used to ""grey out"" button on the display touch screen and UPS Tuner.

Setting for the battery discharge voltage limit for when the manual battery self-test must exit. Range (Lead-acid): 1.70V/cell to 2.3V/cellDefault value (Lead-acid): 2.0V/cell Range (Li-ion): 2.1V/cell to 4.2V/cellDefault value (Li-ion): 3.5V/cellRange (NiCd): 0.6V/cell to 1.7V/cellDefault value (NiCd): 1.1V/cell

The UPS must be able to estimate the battery condition during battery test (battery runtime calibration test and battery self-test) and report one of the following conditions as alarms and events, depending on the measured voltage of the battery:·        Battery condition OK: Posted as an event if battery capacity is above 75% of nominal.·        Battery condition weak: Shown as an alarm if battery capacity is between 50% and 75% of nominal.·        Battery condition poor: Shown as an alarm if battery capacity is below 50% of nominal.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Battery capacity is above 75%
Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Battery capacity is between 50% to 75%
Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: Batteries should be replaced.Description: Battery capacity is lower than 50%

Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: Perform a battery runtime calibration test.Description: The battery state is unknown. Either the battery is new or a battery runtime calibration test has been aborted.

To avoid deep discharging the batteries, the UPS must automatically trip the battery breakers after 2 weeks, if system is left with output off and no ability to charge the batteries.It must be possible to enable and disable this feature by the user.

To avoid deep discharging the batteries, when the system is left with output off and no ability to charge the batteries, the UPS must automatically trip the battery breakers, if the battery cell voltage reaches, or becomes below, the low battery shutdown level for 10 minutes.

Requirement: Energy storage automatic disconnect time accelerated test option
Description: It must be possible to speed up the time of the energy storage automatic disconnect for testing purposes.
Automatic battery disconnect function - avoid deep discharge of batteries during idle mode - system installed but no mains available Values: Yes/NoDefault value: Yes

Requirement: Energy storage automatic disconnect time accelerated test command
Description: Command to start/stop the accelerated energy storage automatic disconnect time.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Automatic battery disconnect - setting has been changed
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: Close the battery breakers.Description: To prevent the batteries deep discharging, the battery breakers have been tripped by the system
The UPS must trip the battery breakers in case the battery voltage drops below a certain level. This is required to limit damages in case there is a flashover.
The under-voltage trip level must be at 0.625 x nominal cell voltage:Lead acid: 1.25 V/cellLi-ion: 2.38 V/cellNiCd: 0.75 V/cell

The energy storage under-voltage must have been present for minimum 10 ms and maximum 100 ms. before the battery breakers are tripped, to ensure that a short dip in the voltage does not cause a battery breaker trip .
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: Close the battery breakers.Description: Battery voltage reached collapse level and the battery breakers have been tripped by the system
The UPS must be able to monitor the energy storage temperature.

Requirement: Energy storage temperature monitoring must be configurable
Description: The user must be able to enable and disable the energy storage temperature monitoring.

Requirement: Number of energy storage temperature sensors must be configurable
Description: The user must be able configure which energy storage temperature sensors are used (enable/disable them individually).

Requirement: High and low energy storage temperature warning
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure a low and a high temperature level. The UPS must then warn the user via an alarm, if the energy storage temperature drops below the low temperature level, or rises above the high temperature level.
Setting to enable and disable battery temperature monitoringEnable/disable.Default value: Enable
Setting for which level to warn the user about high battery temperature. Range: 0 to 60 degrees C.Default value: 35 degrees C (90 degree F).
Setting for which level to warn the user about low battery temperature. Default value: 10 degrees C (50 Degree F)Range: 0 to 40 degrees C.
Setting to enable and disable battery temperature sensor 1Enable/disable.Default value: Enable
Setting to enable and disable battery temperature sensor 2Enable/disable.Default value: Disable

Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: Check the battery temperature. A high temperature may decrease the battery lifetime.Description: The battery temperature is above the alarm setting

Description: The UPS must be able to monitor the status (open/closed) of the energy storage breakers present.The current status of the present energy storage breakers must be visible to the user, and a breaker status change must be logged in the event log.

Description: It must be possible for the user to configure which energy storage breakers are present in the UPS system. A configuration change must be logged in the event log.

A combined status indicating if batteries are connected or disconnected. Combines the status of the battery breaker(s) in the system (depending on battery system present) to give one global status indicating if batteries are connected or not. To be used for the BB status in the display and UPS Tuner mimic diagrams.'Possible values: Open/closed

Requirement: Input contact indicating when UPS is on generator
Description: It must be possible to configure an input contact to indicate to the UPS that it is running on generator, which will make the UPS reduce the battery charge current.

Requirement: Maximum battery charge power level when on generator must be configurable
Description: The amount the battery charge power is reduced when on generator must be configurable to 0% (Off), 10%, 25%, 50%, 75% or 100% of nominal charge power level.

Requirement: UPS is on generator - input contact setting
Description: Setting to assign a configurable input contact to indicate that the UPS is on generator.Range: Enable/disableDefault value: Disable

Requirement: Maximum battery charge power level when on generator - setting
Description: Setting to configure the maximum charge current when on generator, as a percentage of the nominal charge level. Range: 0% (charger off), 10%, 25%, 50%, 75% or 100% Default value: 100%

Requirement: Stop battery charger at inoperable room ventilation
Description: The UPS must be able to stop the battery charger and post an alarm based on a dry contact input indicating that the battery room ventilation is inoperable.

Requirement: Input contact indicating if battery room ventilation is inoperable
Description: It must be possible to configure an input contact to indicate to the UPS if the battery room ventilation is inoperable, which will make the UPS stop the battery charger and post an alarm.

Description: It must be possible to configure an input contact to indicate that an external battery monitoring system has detected a fault.

Requirement: Output relay indicating if battery is not working correctly
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure an output relay to activate if the UPS battery is not working correctly.The conditions for activating the ""battery is not working correctly"" dry contact output should be the same as for indicating battery inoperable in the UPS mimic. Meaning one or more of the below conditions are true (depending on which features are available/enabled in the product):- Battery voltage out of tolerance (high and low)- Battery voltage collapse- Battery configuration invalid- Battery capacity is below minimum acceptable level- Battery room ventilation inoperable- External battery monitoring detected fault- Battery fuse blown or battery relay is not working correctly- Battery not connected

Requirement: Battery is not working correctly - output relay setting
Description: Setting to configure an output relay to indicate battery is not working correctly.Range: Enable/disableDefault value: Disable

Description: It must be possible for the user to configure an output relay to activate if the battery is disconnected.
