Description: Setting to configure an output relay to indicate battery is disconnected.Range: Enable/disableDefault value: Disable

Requirement: Battery is disconnected - output relay - setting changed
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Battery is disconnected - output relay - setting has been changed

Requirement: Charge voltage when battery is disconnected
Description: When the battery is disconnected (breaker open or fuses cleared), the charge voltage must be set to a fixed value, to keep voltage on the terminals.The current limitation must be set to the minimum required for obtaining a voltage on the terminals.Levels and limits must be specified in a sub requirement for the product
The UPS must be able to support NiCd batteries as energy storage.

The user must be able to configure the UPS for NiCd batteries.This means that the following basic parameters must be specifically adjusted in ranges and values to support NiCd: - Battery type configurable as NiCd (this is used by the UPS to choose the correct charging algorithm, and default values and allowed ranges of relevant settings etc.).- Number of cells in battery setting range and default value according to NiCd and UPS battery voltage range.- Number of batteries in series setting range and default value according to NiCd and UPS battery voltage range.

The charger for NiCd batteries must have three basic charge cycle steps:- Step 1: Constant current charge at a configurable current level. The charger must change to step 2 when the cell voltage reaches a given limit (the same configurable cell voltage level used for step 2).- Step 2: Constant voltage boost charge at a configurable cell voltage level. The duration of this cycle must be configurable, after which the charger must change to step 3.- Step 3: Float charge at a configurable cell voltage level.A boost charge cycle is required to reach 100% State Of Charge (SOC), but the boost charge cycle can cause battery water consumption. It must ensured that this state is not permanently active.{Image: 63A9C02C-99F0-4E1F-920E-9C9A51D93798.bmp}

Requirement: Charge cycle after a battery discharge period
Description: If the UPS enters a battery discharge period (battery operation), the charger must have a certain behavior depending on which basic charge cycle step it is in, and how long the battery discharge period has been.Battery discharge during basic charge cycle step 1:- Stay in step 1.Battery discharge during basic charge cycle step 2:- If UPS enters battery operation for less than 30 seconds, continue in step 2.- If UPS enters battery operation for more than 30 seconds, restart the charge cycle (change to step 1).Battery discharge during basic charge cycle step 3:- If UPS enters battery operation for less than 30 seconds, continue in step 3- If UPS enters battery operation for more than 30 seconds, restart the charge cycle (change to step 1).TBD: A simple algorithm could be to applied to ensure a short boost charge cycle when the depth of discharge is small (for example only a 1-hour boost charge when SOC is > 95% after a discharge). The difficulty is to define these values and the best solution would be to define the values in cooperation with battery vendors.
It must be possible for the user to perform a manual equalization charge cycle of the NiCd battery at a configurable cell voltage and for a configurable time duration.

Requirement: Charge current rate must be configurable
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure the charge current rate (CA rate) according to NiCd specific ranges.

Requirement: Boost charge voltage must be configurable
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure the boost charge voltage according to NiCd specific ranges.

Requirement: Boost charge time must be configurable
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure the boost charge time according to NiCd specific ranges.

Requirement: Automatic boost charge must be permanently enabled
Description: The automatic boost charge function must be permanently enabled when battery type is configured to NiCd, as this is part of the basic NiCd charge cycle.This means that the user must not be able to disable the auto boost charge mode setting.

Requirement: Float charge voltage must be configurable
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure the float charge voltage according to NiCd specific ranges.

Requirement: Equalization charge voltage must be configurable
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure the equalization charge voltage according to NiCd specific ranges.

Requirement: Equalization charge time must be configurable
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure the equalization charge time according to NiCd specific ranges.
The battery high voltage warning level must be adjusted according to NiCd battery type:NiCd:1.8 V/cell

The UPS must provide a calculation of the estimated remaining runtime (remaining backup time) of the NiCd batteryThe remaining runtime must be shown while operating in normal operation and battery operation, and shall be displayed real-time, even under changing load conditions.
The cyclic charging mode must be disabled and not allowed for NiCd.

Requirement: Static low battery warning and shutdown levels
Description: The low battery voltage warning and shutdown levels must be static (fixed) for NiCd batteries and not dynamic as is the case for lead acid batteries.The values of the static levels must be configurable by the user according to NiCd specific ranges:Range: 0.5-1.1 V/cellDefault: 1.00V/cell
The battery voltage collapse level must be at 0.55 of the nominal voltage:NiCd: 1.2V/cell x 0.55 = 0.66V/cell. The battery voltage collapse clear condition level must be :NiCd: ??
Setting for low battery shutdown level setting in volt/cell.NiCd:Range: 0.5-1.1 V/cellDefault: 1.00V/cell
The UPS must be able to support Li-ion batteries as energy storage.

The extended support for the Li-ion solutions must include: Minimal I/O exchange to interface the UPS and lithium-ion battery including basic surveillance functions, remaining runtime calculation and warning before UPS shutdown.
The following Samsung Li-ion solutions must be supported:- SDI ELPM182
The following LG Li-ion solutions must be supported:- LG-JP3- LG-JP4

Requirement: Support for custom Li-ion battery solutions
Description: It must be possible to support custom Li-ion battery solutions, meaning the relevant parameters must be configurable by the user to comply with the given Li-ion solution.
For the Li-ion solution the nominal battery cell voltage must be as follows:- Samsung SDI ELPM182: 3.8V.- LG JP4: 3.7V.

When the UPS is configured to use a SKU based Li-ion solution, the battery configuration parameters listed below must be fixed to the shown values:{Image: 9F62B5F4-CAD7-496A-8E8A-863454D24486.bmp}Box link: https://schneider-electric.box.com/s/pzp77i2pk4s8olcpbx4t9aif9134lgdcTolerances:Time: +/-1%Voltage: Offset +/- 0.5V, reading +/- 1%Temperature: ?
For the Li-ion solution boost charging is not allowed and must be disabled.
For the Li-ion solution equalization charging is not allowed and must be disabled.

Requirement: No temperature compensation of charge voltage
Description: For the Li-ion solution the charge voltage must not be temperature compensated but instead fixed at the same value in the entire temperature range.

To avoid damaging the Li-ion battery during charging, the charge current must be reduced at low battery temperatures.The reduction of the charging current must start at the value set as “battery temperature reference”. The charge current must be gradually reduced, reaching zero Amps at the value set as “minimum charging battery temperature”.For SDI ELPM182 and LG JP4 the reduction must start at 16°C, and must reach zero Amps at 0 °C.
The UPS must be able to calculate the remaining runtime of the Li-ion battery.

Requirement: Static low battery warning and shutdown levels
Description: The low battery voltage warning and shutdown levels must be static (fixed) for Li-ion batteries and not dynamic as is the case for lead acid batteries.For custom LIB solutions the value of the static low battery shutdown must be configurable. For standard SKUs that value must be automatically selected. The value of the static low battery warning level must be calculated as a function of the low battery shutdown level and nominal voltage:Low battery warning level = Low battery shutdown level + 0.375 x (Nominal voltage – Low battery shutdown level) - Samsung SDI ELPM182: Nominal 3.80V/cell, shutdown level 3.00V/cell, warning level 3.3V/cell- LG JP4: Nominal 3.70V/cell, shutdown level 3.15V/cell, warning level 3.35V/cell
The battery high voltage warning level must be 1.5% higher than the float voltage.

The battery voltage collapse level must be at half of the nominal voltage The battery voltage collapse clear condition level must be shutdown voltage level + 0.15 x (Nominal voltage – Low battery shutdown level) - Samsung SDI ELPM182: Nominal 3.80V/cell, shutdown level 3.00V/cell, collapse level 1.90V/cell, collapse clear level 3.12V/cell- LG JP4: Nominal 3.70V/cell, shutdown level 3.15V/cell, collapse level 1.85V/cell, collapse clear level 3.23V/cell
The UPS must be able to calculate the charge level (state of charge) of the Li-ion battery.

Like for lead acid battery, the UPS must be able to estimate the Li-ion battery condition during battery test and report the conditions OK, weak and poor as alarms and events, depending on the measured voltage of the battery:·        Battery condition OK voltage: ?·        Battery condition weak voltage: ?·        Battery condition poor voltage: ?

The BMS of the Li-ion solution has an over-current protection which will open the battery breaker if an over-current is detected during a specific time duration.A surveillance function must exist in the UPS firmware which ensures that the UPS reacts to a discharge over-current (stops discharging) before the BMS decides to do so, to avoid that the BMS trips the battery breaker.

The BMS of the Li-ion solution has an internal battery temperature monitoring system which will shut down and disconnect the battery should the battery temperature rise above a certain limit.A surveillance function must exist in the UPS firmware which ensures that the UPS reacts to a battery over-temperature before the BMS does, to avoid that the BMS trips the battery breaker.

Requirement: User must be able to enable and disable internal surveillance functions
Description: It must be possible for the user (via UPS Tuner) to enable/disable the two internal surveillance functions for 'high battery current shutdown' and 'high battery temperature shutdown'.

For lithium-ion batteries the battery thermal runaway protection function must have different temperature levels compared to lead-acid batteries. The levels must depend on the specific LIB module. For custom LIB solutions the levels must be configurable. For standard SKUs that value must be automatically selected. - Samsung SDI ELPM182: Charger turned off if the battery temperature is 65 °C above for 60 seconds, and it is turned on again at 60°C (i.e, 0.92 x 65°C)- LG JP4: Charger turned off if the battery temperature is 40 °C above for 60 seconds, and it is turned on again at 37 °C (i.e, 0.92 x 40°C)

When Li-Ion battery systems are used, there could be large differences between the temperature provided by the battery temperature sensor (which is not in direct contact with the battery cell) and the actual cell temperature. A function must exist in the UPS firmware to estimate the cell temperature. The estimation must be made based on the cell load [W/cell], UPS operation mode [charging / discharging], battery model, and temperature provided by the sensor. All the firmware functionalities that make use of the battery temperature must use the estimated value, and that must the value that the HMI shows as battery temperature.

Requirement: User configurable maximum allowed string discharge current
Description: It must be possible for the user (via UPS Tuner) to configure the maximum allowed string discharge current and associated delays for Li-ion batteries.There must be three levels of discharge currents each with an associated delay.

Requirement: Input contact indicating external energy storage monitoring detected minor alarm
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure a dry contact input to indicate that external energy storage monitoring has detected minor alarm.UPS must post a warning alarm if this dry contact input is active.

Requirement: Input contact indicating external energy storage monitoring detected major alarm
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure a dry contact input to indicate that external energy storage monitoring has detected major alarm.UPS must post a critical alarm and turn off the charger if this dry contact input is active.
It must be possible for the user to configure a dry contact input to turn off the charger if activated.

Setting for the CA discharge rate level 2.Range: 0.5-50 C/stringDefault value: 7.7 C/stringRequired check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: The CA discharge rate level 2 must be higher or equal to level 3.
Setting for the CA discharge rate level 2 delay.Range: 0-600000 millisecondsDefault value: 8000If set to 0 the function must be off

Requirement: Energy storage internal surveillance enable setting
Description: Setting to enable and disable the built-in energy storage surveillance functions in the UPS. These surveillance functions are only relevant for Li-ion batteries, so energy storage type must be set to Li-ion before the surveillance functions are actually active (enabled).

Requirement: External energy storage monitoring detected minor alarm - input contact setting
Description: Setting to assign a configurable input contact to post an alarm in case of an external energy storage monitoring detected minor alarm.Range: Enable/disableDefault value: Disable

Requirement: External energy storage monitoring detected major alarm - input contact setting
Description: Setting to assign a configurable input contact to post an alarm and turn off charger in case of an external energy storage monitoring detected major alarm.Range: Enable/disableDefault value: Disable

Different parallel configurations and all requirements linked to parallel system.
It must be possible to connect more UPS units in parallel to supply the same load

Requirement: Parallel address number for each UPS
Description: The user must be able to configure an unique parallel address number for each UPS, and an event must logged if the setting is changed.

Requirement: UPS units present in the parallel system
Description: The user must be able to configure which UPS units are present in the parallel system, and an event must be logged if the setting is changed. This way individual parallel UPS units can be disabled if taken out for service, avoiding having a permanent communication alarm to the UPS taken out for service.

If more than one parallel UPS has wrongly been configured to the same unique parallel address number, it must be detected by the system and the user must be notified via an alarm.If an UPS is powered up into an already running parallel system, and it has the same unique parallel address number as another UPS in the already running parallel system, the UPS powered up must not interfere with the running parallel system and it must not be able to participate in the parallel system (must remain in off operation).

The parallel UPS units must communicate with each other via two fully redundant point-to-point communication busses.If one parallel communication bus is detected as faulty by any of the parallel UPS units, the given UPS must automatically use the other parallel communication bus without impacting the operation of the parallel system.
The communication status of the two parallel busses must be monitored by of each of the parallel UPS units, and be available to the user via alarms/events.

Each UPS in the parallel system must check that its firmware is compatible with the other UPS units in the parallel system.If the is detected as not compatible when the UPS powers up, it must be indicated to the user via an alarm, and the UPS must not be able to participate actively in the parallel system.If the firmware versions of the parallel UPS units are compatible but not same, the user must be notified via an alarm.

Each UPS in the parallel system must check that its nominal power rating is the same as the other UPS units in the parallel system.If the is detected as different when the UPS powers up, it must be indicated to the user via an alarm.

The parallel system must have a floating master.The parallel master UPS must be responsible for controlling the global operation mode of the parallel system, selecting the synchronization source of the parallel system, and the global inverter control and regulation. If the current parallel master UPS is no longer able to act as master (master breakdown) another parallel UPS must be able to become parallel master without impacting the system.It must be evaluated continuesly which UPS is best suited as being parallel master based on conditions like UOB status, UPS operation mode, synchronization source availability and static bypass switch status. If the current master UPS in the parallel system is no longer the best suited as master another UPS must become master without any impact on the system.For example: * An UPS that has UOB open must never become parallel master.  * An UPS that is in inverter operation or static bypass operation must have higher parallel master priority than an UPS that is in off operation.  * An UPS that is able to synchronize to the bypass source must have higher parallel master priority than an UPS that is free running.

Requirement: Detection of more parallel master UPS units (master collision)
Description: If it is detected on the parallel communication bus that more than one parallel master is active at the same time, the user must be notified via an alarm, and the parallel UPS units that are currently acting as masters must jump off the communication line so that a new master selection procedure can be carried out.

Requirement: Notification of no parallel master detected
Description: The user must be notified via an alarm if no master is detected in the parallel system.
The user nust be notified via an event if the parallel master has changed from one UPS to another.

Requirement: Indication of which UPS is parallel master
Description: The user must be be able to see which UPS (UPS number) is currently parallel master via UPS Tuner.
Parallel UPS units must share the output load equally within 3% or better.
It must be possible to parallel UPS units for capacity.
It must be possible to parallel UPS units for redundancy.

It must be possible for the user to configure how many parallel UPS units are used for redundancy (N+0, N+1, N+2, N+3, N+4 etc.).If the output load exceeds the level where the parallel UPS redundancy is lost, it must be alarmed to the user, but the system must not change operation mode or current limit the output, unless an overload condition occurs.

Requirement: Number of redundant parallel UPS units
Description: A value for the current number of redundant parallel UPS units must be made available to the user.

Settings that are required to be the same on all parallel UPS units must automatically be synchronized and kept the same by the system. * At parallel system power-up the parallel master must automatically distribute these settings to all the the other parallel UPS units. The user must be notified via an alarm/event if the parallel settings synchronization at system power-up was completed successfully or not.  * If one or more of these settings are changed by the user on one parallel UPS, the settings must automatically be distributed to the other parallel UPS units.

Requirement: Minimum number of parallel UPS required to supply load
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure the minimum number of parallel UPS units that are required to supply the load. This feature is used to avoid turning on UPS inverter(s) into a load that is bigger than what the inverter(s) can supply without entering overload.The parallel system must not transfer from off to inverter operation before the configured minimum number of parallel UPS units are ready to turn onThe user must be notified via an alarm if there are not enough UPS units which are ready to turn on. . For example, if the minimum number of parallel UPS required to supply load is configured to 2, and the parallel system is in off operation, then when the user must pushes the inverter on button on the first UPS, the system must stay off and an alarm must indicate that there are not enough UPS units ready to turn on. When the user pushes the inverter on button on the second UPS the system must transfer to inverter operation and the alarm must be cleared. More details can be found in the "On button pushed" requirement under parallel "Sequences and behavior".

Requirement: Indication of mixed UPS operation mode in a parallel system
Description: The user must be notified via an alarm if one or more parallel UPS units are operating in battery operation, while others are operating in normal operation

Requirement: Global customer alarm for parallel events
Description: There must be a global customer alarm/event available, which covers the parallel operation related alarms/events which are only shown for service.The following service alarms/events must also post the global parallel customer alarm/event: * UPS parallel address configuration number incorrect  * Parallel master not detected.  * Parallel unit not present.  * Settings not synchronized between parallel UPS units  * Parallel unit is incompatible.

Requirement: Alarm user if IMB is closed in parallel system with MBB
Description: The IMB(s) must not be operated in a parallel system with MBB, however in case one or more IMBs are closed, the system must react accordingly and post an alarm to the user.

Allows transferring a parallel UPS in battery operation into a standby state, if the remaining parallel UPS units in normal operation can supply the load.If an UPS in a parallel system enters battery operation while the other UPS units are in normal operation it shall be put it into a so called "inverter standby" mode if the remaining UPS units can supply the load. This way the batteries of the given UPS will not be drained unnecessarily.An UPS in "inverter standby" must be able to start up and supply the load again if needed due to an increased load, loss of redundancy, or the shutdown of one or more UPS units. The shift out of "inverter standby" must be done without any influence on the load.

Requirement: Into inverter standby due to battery operation
Description: Primary Actor(s)-          Load.-          UPSStakeholders and InterestsLoad              : Wants a stable supply of power.UPS              : Wants to ensure UPS backup as long as possible (avoid unnecessary draining of batteries).Pre conditionsThe parallel system consists of at least two UPS units.Post conditionsThe load is supplied by the parallel UPS system.Main success scenario 1. All UPS units are in normal operation and the parallel system is in inverter operation.  2. One UPS unit shifts to battery operation.  3. The total load on the parallel system is within what the remaining UPS unit(s) can supply.  4. The N+x criteria set will still be met if one UPS is turned off.  5. The given UPS enters inverter standby operation after 15 seconds in battery operation.  6. The remaining UPS units and the parallel system continue in inverter operation.Alternative scenariosScenario 1: 1. All UPS units are in normal operation and the parallel system is in inverter operation.  2. One UPS unit shifts to battery operation.   1. The total load on the parallel system is above what the remaining UPS unit(s) can supply or the N+x criteria set will not be met if one UPS is turned off.   2. The given UPS stays in battery operation. 3. The remaining UPS units and the parallel system continue in inverter operation. Scenario 2: 1. More than one UPS is in normal operation, one UPS is in inverter standby operation and the parallel system is in inverter operation.  2. One UPS unit shifts from normal operation to battery operation.  3. The total load on the parallel system is within what the remaining UPS unit(s) can supply.  4. The N+x criteria set will still be met if the given UPS is turned off.  5. The given UPS enters inverter standby operation after 15 seconds in battery operation.  6. The remaining UPS units and the parallel system continue in inverter operation. Scenario 3: 1. All UPS units are in normal operation and the parallel system is in inverter operation.  2. Two UPS units shift to battery operation.  3. The total load on the parallel system is within what the remaining UPS unit(s) can supply.  4. The N+x criteria set will still be met if two UPS units are turned off.  5. The first UPS of the two in battery operation enters inverter standby operation after 15 seconds in battery operation.  6. The second UPS of the two in battery operation enters inverter standby operation 15 seconds after the first UPS unit entered inverter standby operation  7. The remaining UPS units and the parallel system continue in inverter operation.  Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Requirement: Out of inverter standby due to battery operation
Description: Primary Actor(s)-          Load.-          UPSStakeholders and InterestsLoad              : Wants a stable supply of power.UPS              : Wants to ensure UPS backup as long as possible (avoid unnecessary draining of batteries).Pre conditionsThe parallel system consists of at least two UPS units.Post conditionsThe load is supplied by the parallel UPS system.Main success scenario 1. At least one UPS is in normal operation, one UPS is in inverter standby operation and the parallel system is in inverter operation.  2. The UPS in inverter standby operation is able to return to normal operation.  3. The UPS in inverter standby operation changes to normal operation after 10 seconds.  4. The remaining UPS units and the parallel system continue in inverter operation.Alternative scenariosScenario 1: 1. At least one UPS is in normal operation, one UPS is in inverter standby operation and the parallel system is in inverter operation.   1. The total load on the parallel system increases above what the UPS unit(s) in normal operation can supply or the N+x criteria set is no longer met.   2. The UPS in inverter standby operation changes to battery operation right away. 2. The remaining UPS units and the parallel system continue in inverter operation. Scenario 2: 1. At least one UPS unit is in normal operation, two or more UPS units are in inverter standby operation and the parallel system is in inverter operation.   1. The total load on the parallel system increases above what the UPS unit(s) in normal operation can supply or the N+x criteria set is no longer met.   2. All UPS units in inverter standby operation change to battery operation right away. 2. The remaining UPS units and the parallel system continue in inverter operation.  Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Setting to enable and disable the Advanced Battery Operation Management feature. Possible values:Enable / Disable Default value:Enable Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: Setting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.

Requirement: Advanced battery operation management - setting changed
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Advanced battery operation management - setting has been changed

Primary Actor(s)-          User. Stakeholders and InterestsUser              : Wants to turn on a parallel system that is off and supply the load with UPS backup. Pre conditionsThe parallel system consists of at least two UPS units. Post conditionsThe load is supplied by the parallel UPS system. Main success scenario 1. All parallel UPS units and the parallel system are in off mode  2. User pushes the on button on the first UPS.  3. System checks if the minimum number of UPS units are available - ready to turn on and supply the load. (The minimum number of UPS units required is a setting).  4. The minimum number of UPS units are available.  5. The UPS turns output on. If Mains 2 is available the UPS unit enters forced static bypass operation and then enters inverter operation. If Mains 2 is not available it enters inverter operation.    Alternative scenariosScenario 1: 1. All parallel UPS units and the parallel system are in off mode  2. User pushes the on button on the first UPS.  3. System checks if the minimum number of UPS units are available - ready to turn on and supply the load. (The minimum number of UPS units required is a setting).  4. The minimum number of UPS units are not available.  5. The system stays off. System indicates that not enough UPS units are available.  6. User pushes the on button on the second UPS.  7. System checks if the minimum number of UPS units are available - ready to turn on and supply the load.  8. The minimum number of UPS units are available.  9. The UPS units turn output on. If Mains 2 is available the UPS units enter forced static bypass operation and then enter inverter operation. If Mains 2 is not available they enter inverter operation. Depending on the setting of the minimum required UPS units the user might have to repeat step 3 to 5 several times. Scenario 2: 1. All parallel UPS units and the parallel system are in forced static bypass operation.  2. User pushes the on button on the first UPS.  3. System checks if the first UPS alone can supply the load.  4. The first UPS can supply the load.  5. The parallel system and the first UPS enter inverter operation. Scenario 3: 1. All parallel UPS units and the parallel system are in forced static bypass operation.  2. User pushes the on button on the first UPS.  3. System checks if the first UPS alone can supply the load.  4. The first UPS cannot supply the load alone. System indicates that not enough UPS units are available.  5. All parallel UPS units and the parallel system stay in forced static bypass operation.  6. User pushes the on button on the second UPS.   7. System checks if the UPS units with on button pushed can supply the load.  8. The UPS units with on button pushed can supply the load.  9. The parallel system and UPS units with on button pushed enter inverter operation. Scenario 4: 1. All parallel UPS units and the parallel system are in requested static bypass operation.  2. User pushes the on button on the first UPS.  3. The parallel system and all UPS units enter inverter operation.     Special requirementsNA Technology and data variations listNA Open issuesNA

Primary Actor(s)-          User.Stakeholders and InterestsUser              : Wants to turn off a parallel system that is on.Pre conditionsThe parallel system consists of at least two UPS units.Post conditionsThe load is either supplied through the bypass (Mains 2) or off.Main success scenario 1. All parallel UPS units and the parallel system are in inverter operation.  2. User pushes the off button on the first UPS.  3. The first UPS turns off inverter and no longer supplies the load.  4. User pushes the off button on the second UPS.  5. The second UPS turns off inverter and no longer supplies the load.  6. User pushes the off button on the last UPS.   1. if bypass within tolerance, the parallel system and all UPS units enter forced static bypass operation without break or   2. if not sync to bypass, the parallel system and all UPS units enter forced static bypass operation with a break if user acknowledges it or   3. if bypass not available, the parallel system and all UPS units enter off operation if user ackowledges it.  Alternative scenariosScenario 1: 1. All parallel UPS units and the parallel system are in inverter operation.  2. User pushes the off button on the first UPS.  3. The total load on the parallel system will be larger than what the remaining UPS units still on can supply.  4. If user acknowledges this...   1. if bypass within tolerance, the given UPS turns off and the the parallel system and the remaining UPS units will stay in inverter operation untill overload or   2. if not sync to bypass, the given UPS turns off and the the parallel system and the remaining UPS units will stay in inverter operation untill overload or   3. if bypass not available, the given UPS turns off and the the parallel system and the remaining UPS units will stay in inverter operation untill overload. 5. If user does not acknowledge this all parallel UPS units and the parallel system continiues in inverter operation Scenario 2: 1. All parallel UPS units and the parallel system are in inverter operation.  2. User pushes the off button on the first UPS.  3. The parallel UPS redundancy will be lost.  4. If user acknowledges this...   1. The given UPS turns off and the the parallel system and the remaining UPS units will stay in inverter operation. 5. If user does not acknowledge this all parallel UPS units and the parallel system continiues in inverter operation “Push off button” means pressing the button for more than 3 seconds. Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesBehavior described in alternative scenario 1 has been updated in accordance with how it is actually implemented in GVX, GVS and GVL.

Primary Actor(s)-          User.Stakeholders and InterestsUser              : Wants to turn a parallel system into requested static bypass.Pre conditionsThe parallel system consists of at least two UPS units. Bypass is available and within tolerances to allow shift to requested static bypass.Post conditionsThe parallel UPS system is in requested static bypass and still supplies the load.Main success scenario 1. All UPS units and the parallel system are in inverter operation  2. User selects “UPS into requested bypass” in the display of any of the parallel UPS units.  3. All UPS units and the parallel system change to requested static bypass operation. Alternative scenariosScenario 1: 1. All UPS units and the parallel system are off.  2. User selects “UPS into requested bypass” in the display of any UPS.  3. Only the UPS commanded in to requested static bypass operation changes to requested static bypass operation. Other UPS's will stay in off operation. Scenario 2a: 1. The first UPS is off and the second UPS in inverter operation  2. User selects “UPS into requested bypass” in the display of the UPS in off operation UPS.  3. Both UPS units changes to requested static bypass operation. Scenario 2b: 1. The first UPS is off and the second UPS in inverter operation  2. User selects “UPS into requested bypass” in the display of the UPS in inverter operation UPS.  3. Only the UPS in inverter operation changes to requested static bypass operation. The UPS in off operation other statys in off operation Scenario 3a: 1. The first UPS is in static bypass standby operation and the other UPS in inverter operation  2. User selects “UPS into requested bypass” in the display on the UPS in inverter operation.  3. The UPS in inverter operation changes to requested static bypass operation. The UPS in static bypass standby operation stays in static bypass standby operation Scenario 3b: 1. The first UPS is in static bypass standby operation and the other UPS in inverter operation  2. User selects “UPS into requested bypass” in the display on the UPS in static bypass standby operation.  3. The user is not allowed to make a request to go into reqested static on a UPS in static bypass standby operation. Scenario 3c: 1. The first UPS is in static bypass standby operation and the UPS has SSIB is open. The other UPS in inverter operation and bypass is available on this UPS.   2. User selects “UPS into requested bypass” in the display on the UPS in inverter operation.  3. The UPS in inverter operation changes to requested static bypass operation. The UPS in static bypass standby operation stays in static bypass standby operation Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Requirement: System out of requested static bypass
Description: Primary Actor(s)-          User.Stakeholders and InterestsUser              : Wants to return a parallel system from requested static bypass to inverter on.Pre conditionsThe parallel system consists of at least two UPS units.Post conditionsThe load is supplied by the parallel UPS system.Main success scenario 1. All parallel UPS units and the parallel system are in requested static bypass operation.  2. User selects “UPS out of requested bypass” in the display of any of the parallel UPS units.  3. The parallel system and all UPS units enter inverter operation. Alternative scenarios  Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Primary Actor(s)-       User.Stakeholders and InterestsUser              : .Pre conditionsUPS system must be supplied with power. The MBB is closed and all UOB are closed.Post conditionsNAMain success scenario1.    All UPS units are in maintenance bypass.2.    The system is in maintenance bypass.3.    The MBB is detected as opened on all UPS units in a parallel setup.4.    The UPS units enter forced static bypass operation.5.    The system enters forced static bypass operation.Alternative scenariosScenario 1:1.    All UPS units are in maintenance bypass.2.    The system is in maintenance bypass.3.    The MBB is detected as opened on one or more but not all UPS units in a parallel setup.4.    The UPS unit(s) that detect(s) MBB as open enter(s) forced static bypass.5.    The system continues in maintenance bypass. Special requirements                                                 NATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issues

Primary Actor(s)-       User.Stakeholders and InterestsUser              : .Pre conditionsUPS system must be supplied with power. The MBB is open.Post conditionsNAMain success scenario1.      The SIB is closed and all UOB are closed.2.      All UPS units are in any operation mode except maintenance bypass.3.      The system is in any operation mode except maintenance bypass.4.      The MBB is detected as closed on all UPS units in a parallel setup.5.      The UPS units enters maintenance bypass and activates the static bypass switches.6.      The system enters maintenance bypass.Alternative scenariosScenario 1:1.      The SIB is closed and all UOB are closed.2.      All UPS units are in any operation mode except maintenance bypass.3.      The system is in any operation mode except maintenance bypass.4.      The MBB is detected as closed on one or more but not all UPS units in a parallel setup.5.      The UPS unit(s) that detect(s) MBB as closed enter(s) maintenance bypass and activates the static bypass switches.6.    The UPS units(s) that do not detect MBB as closed enter forced static bypass.7.      The system enters maintenance bypass.Special requirements                                                 NATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Requirement: Into forced static bypass due to output voltage out of tolerance
Description: Primary Actor(s)-          Load.-          UPSStakeholders and InterestsLoad              : Wants a stable supply of power.UPS              : Wants to ensure a stable supply of power to the load.Pre conditionsThe parallel system consists of at least two UPS units.Post conditionsThe load is supplied by the parallel UPS system via Mains 2.Main success scenario 1. All UPS units and the parallel system are in inverter operation.  2. One or more UPS units detect(s) an output voltage error.  3. All UPS units and the parallel system change to forced static bypass operation.Alternative scenariosNASpecial requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Primary Actor(s)-          Load.-          UPSStakeholders and InterestsLoad              : Wants a stable supply of power.UPS              : Wants to ensure a stable supply of power to the load.Pre conditionsThe parallel system consists of at least two UPS units.Post conditionsThe load is still supplied with power.Main success scenario 1. All UPS units and the parallel system are in inverter operation.  2. One UPS unit detects a fault (not an output voltage fault) and needs to enter forced static bypass operation.  3. The total load on the parallel system is larger than what the remaining UPS units can supply.  4. All UPS units and the parallel system change to forced static bypass operation.Alternative scenarios Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Primary Actor(s)-          Load.-          UPSStakeholders and InterestsLoad              : Wants a stable supply of power.UPS              : Wants to ensure a stable supply of power to the load.Pre conditionsThe parallel system consists of at least two UPS units.Post conditionsThe load is supplied by the parallel UPS system.Main success scenario 1. All UPS units and the parallel system are in forced static bypass operation.  2. The fault forcing the forced static bypass operation is no longer present.  3. All UPS units and the parallel system return to inverter operation.Alternative scenariosNASpecial requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Primary Actor(s)-          Load.-          UPSStakeholders and InterestsLoad              : Wants a stable supply of power.UPS              : Wants to ensure UPS backup as long as possible (stay in inverter on mode).Pre conditionsThe parallel system consists of at least two UPS units.Post conditionsThe load is supplied by the parallel UPS system.Main success scenario 1. All UPS units and the parallel system are in inverter operation.  2. One UPS unit detects a fault (not an output voltage fault) and needs to enter forced static bypass operation.  3. The total load on the parallel system is within what the remaining UPS unit(s) can supply.  4. The given UPS enters static bypass standby operation.  5. The remaining UPS units and the parallel system continue in inverter operation.Alternative scenariosScenario 1: 1. All UPS units and the parallel system are in requested static bypass operation.  2. One UPS unit detects a fault (not an output voltage fault) and needs to enter forced static bypass operation..  3. The given UPS enters static bypass standby operation.  4. The remaining UPS units and the parallel system return to inverter operation. Scenario 2: 1. All UPS units and the parallel system are in forced static bypass operation.  2. One UPS unit has a fault (not an output voltage fault) which has forced the system to be in forced static bypass operation..  3. The total  load on the parallel system decreases to what the UPS units with no fault can supply..  4. The UPS units with no fault and the parallel system return to inverter operation.  5. The UPS with the fault enters static bypass standby operation. Scenario 3: 1. All UPS units and the parallel system are in forced static bypass operation.  2. One UPS unit has a static bypass switch fault.  3. The given UPS enters static bypass standby operation. Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Primary Actor(s)-          Load.-          UPSStakeholders and InterestsLoad              : Wants a stable supply of power.UPS              : Wants to ensure UPS backup as long as possible (stay in inverter operation).Pre conditionsThe parallel system consists of at least two UPS units.Post conditionsThe load is supplied by the parallel UPS system.Main success scenario 1. At least one UPS is in inverter operation, at least one UPS is in static bypass standby operation and the parallel system is in inverter operation.  2. The fault forcing the UPS unit(s) in static bypass standby operation is no longer present.  3. The given UPS unit(s) returns from static bypass standby operation to inverter operation.Alternative scenariosScenario 1: 1. At least one UPS is in inverter operation, at least one UPS is in static bypass standby operation and the parallel system is in inverter operation.  2. A fault is detected which requires the parallel system to enter forced static bypass operation.  3. All UPS units (including the one in static bypass standby operation) and the parallel system enter forced static bypass operation. Scenario 2: 1. At least one UPS is in inverter operation, at least one UPS is in static bypass standby operation and the parallel system is in inverter operation.  2. MBB is closed.  3. All UPS units (including the one in static bypass standby operation) and the parallel system enter maintenance bypass. Scenario 3:NA Scenario 4: 1. One UPS unit has a static bypass switch fault or Mains 2 out of tolerance and is in static bypass standby operation. All the other UPS units and the parallel system are in forced static bypass operation.  2. The UPS unit in static static bypass standby operation no longer has a static bypass switch fault or Mains 2 out of tolerance.  3. The given UPS enters forced static bypass operation. Scenario 5: 1. At least one UPS is in inverter operation, at least one UPS is in static bypass standby operation and the parallel system is in inverter operation.  2. Inverter On button is pushed on the UPS in static bypass standby operation.  3. The UPS in static bypass standby operation changes to inverter operation. Scenario 6a: 1. At least one UPS is in requested static bypass operation, at least one UPS is in static bypass standby operation (due to inverter off button pushed) and the parallel system is in requested static bypass operation .  2. Inverter On button is pushed on the UPS in static bypass standby operation.  3. The UPS in static bypass standby operation and the parallel system changes to inverter operation. Scenario 6b: 1. At least one UPS is in requested static bypass operation, at least one UPS is in static bypass standby operation (due to inverter shutdown) and the parallel system is in requested static bypass operation .  2. Inverter On button is pushed on the UPS in static bypass standby operation.  3. The UPS in static bypass standby operation stays in static bypass standby operation and the parallel system changes to inverter operation.  Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Primary Actor(s)-          Parallel system.Stakeholders and InterestsParallel system: Wants to ensure that basic parallel settings are handled correctly.Pre conditionsThe parallel system consists of at least two UPS units.Post conditions.Main success scenario 1. All parallel UPS units are completely off (not powered at all) and all have the default values for 'parallel UPS address number setting' and the 'parallel UPS units enabled/present setting'.  2. All the parallel UPS units are powered up (UOB open on all UPS units)  3. The parallel UPS units check for consistency of the basic parallel settings and detects that they are not consitent  4. The user is notifed about the inconsistency via the alarms 'UPS parallel address configuration number incorrect' and 'General parallel system event'  5. The parallel system cannot start before this is corrected by the user.  6. User configures each UPS to a valid 'parallel UPS address number setting' and the 'parallel UPS units enabled/present setting'  7. The alarms are cleared in all parallel UPS units. Alternative scenariosScenario 1: 1. A parallel system consisting of two parallel UPS units is in inverter operation (with 'parallel UPS address number setting' 1 and 2, and the 'parallel UPS units enabled/present setting' with UPS1-3 enabled).   2. A third UPS with default values for 'parallel UPS address number setting' and the 'parallel UPS units enabled/present setting' is powered up (UOB open)  3. The parallel system checks for consistency of the basic parallel settings and detects that the third UPS is not consistent  4. The user is notifed about the inconsistency via the alarms 'UPS parallel address configuration number incorrect' and 'General parallel system event'  5. The parallel system continues in inverter operation and the third UPS cannot be transferred out of off operation.  6. The user configures the 'parallel UPS address number setting' to 3 and the 'parallel UPS units enabled/present setting' to UPS1-3 enabled on the third UPS.  7.  The alarms are cleared.  8. The user closes the UOB of the third UPS and presses the inverter on button.  9. The third UPS transfers to normal operation and the parallel system stays in inverter operation.Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Requirement: Parallel settings synchronization by parallel master at UPS power-up
Description: Primary Actor(s)-          Master UPS.Stakeholders and InterestsMaster UPS  : Wants to ensure that all settings related to parallel operation are the same in all parallel UPS units after power-up.Pre conditionsThe parallel system consists of at least two UPS units.Post conditionsAll parallel related settings are the same for all parallel UPS units in the system.Main success scenario 1. All parallel UPS units are completely off (not powered at all).  2. All the parallel UPS units are powered up (all breakers closed except MBB/IMB and UOB).  3. UOB is closed on one UPS and this UPS becomes master.  4. The parallel settings of the parallel master UPS are automatically distributed to all the other parallel UPS units. Alternative scenariosScenario 1: 1. One UPS is completely off and the other parallel UPS units and the parallel system are up and running (powered and configured).  2. One UPS is powered up (all breakers closed except MBB/IMB).  3. The parallel settings of the parallel master UPS are automatically distributed to the UPS powered up.Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Requirement: Parallel settings synchronization of settings changed by user
Description: Primary Actor(s)-          User.Stakeholders and InterestsUser  : Wants to ensure that all settings related to parallel operation are the same in all parallel UPS unitsPre conditionsThe parallel system consists of at least two UPS units.Post conditionsAll parallel related settings are the same for all parallel UPS units in the system.Main success scenario 1. All parallel UPS units are completely off (not powered at all).  2. All the parallel UPS units are powered up (all breakers closed except MBB/IMB).  3. A parallel setting that must be kept the same on all parallel UPS units is changed by the user on any of the parallel UPS units.  4. The setting is automatically synchronized and changed on all the other parallel UPS units. Alternative scenariosScenario 1: 1. All parallel UPS units are completely off (not powered at all).  2. All the parallel UPS units are powered up (all breakers closed except MBB/IMB and UOB).  3. UOB is closed on one UPS and this UPS becones parallel master  4. A parallel setting that must be kept the same on all parallel UPS units is changed by the user on any of the parallel UPS units.  5. The setting is automatically synchronized and changed on all the other parallel UPS units.Scenario 2: 1. All parallel UPS units are completely off (not powered at all).  2. All the parallel UPS units are powered up (all breakers closed except MBB/IMB and UOB).  3. A parallel setting that must be kept the same on all parallel UPS units is changed by the user on any of the parallel UPS units.  4. The setting is only changed on the given UPS and not synchronized to the other parallel UPS units.  5. The UOB is closed on the given UPS and this UPS becones parallel master  6. The setting is automatically synchronized and changed on all the other parallel UPS units.Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Requirement: Parallel settings synchronization depending on UPS operation mode
Description: Primary Actor(s)-          Parallel system.Stakeholders and InterestsParallel system: Wants to ensure that all settings related to parallel operation are the same in all parallel UPS units.Pre conditionsThe parallel system consists of at least two UPS units.Post conditionsAll parallel related settings are the same for all parallel UPS units in the system.Main success scenario 1. All parallel UPS units are completely off (not powered at all).  2. All the parallel UPS units are powered up (all breakers closed except MBB/IMB).  3. User pushes the inverter on button on all parallel UPS units .  4. The parallel UPS units transfer to normal operation.  5. User tries to change the settings for nominal system voltage and system frequency on any parallel UPS.  6. The settings are not changed on any of the parallel UPS units. Alternative scenariosScenario 1: 1. All parallel UPS units are completely off (not powered at all).  2. All the parallel UPS units are powered up (all breakers closed except MBB/IMB).  3. User pushes the inverter on button on all parallel UPS units except one.  4. The parallel UPS units on which the inverter on button has been pushed transfer to normal operation.  5. User tries to change the settings for nominal system voltage and system frequency on the UPS that is in off operation.  6. The settings are not changed on any of the parallel UPS units.Scenario 2: 1. One UPS is configured differently than the others with regards to nominal system voltage and system frequency.  2. All parallel UPS units are completely off (not powered at all).  3. All the parallel UPS units are powered up (all breakers closed except MBB/IMB and UOB).  4. The inverter on button is pushed on the parallel UPS which is configured differently than the others with regards to nominal system voltage and system frequency, and the UPS transfers to normal operation.  5. The UOB is closed on all parallel UPS units except the one that is in normal operation.  6. The settings for nominal system voltage and system frequency are not synchronized and changed automatically on the parallel UPS that is in normal operation   7. The UOB is closed on the parallel UPS in normal operation and the UPS transfers to off operation  8. The settings for nominal system voltage and system frequency are now synchronized and changed automatically on the parallel UPS that transferred to off operation.Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Primary Actor(s)-          Master UPS.Stakeholders and InterestsMaster UPS  :.Pre conditionsThe parallel system consists of at least two UPS units.Post conditionsParallel master has changed with any impact on the current operation of the parallel system.Main success scenario 1. The current parallel master is no longer able to act as master.  2. The parallel slave UPS with the highest priority jumps in as master.Alternative scenariosNASpecial requirementsThis requirement is only valid for a parallel system with a Master functionality.Technology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Requirement: Number of redundant parallel UPS units status
Description: The current number of redundant parallel UPS units (based on the load and operational conditions of the parallel system).
The master status of each UPS must be available to the user (in UPS Tuner).

Setting for the UPS number in a parallel configuration Default value: 1Range: Depends on the product, please see product specific requirement.Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: * Every UPS must have a unique number (more than one UPS cannot have the same number).  * The unique UPS number must only be configurable when the UPS is in off operation or maintenance bypass operation  * The unique UPS number must only be configurable to a UPS number which has has been enabled via the "Parallel UPS units enabled/present setting".

Setting for which parallel UPS units are present in the system. Each UPS unit can be selected as present or not present. Default value: UPS 1 enabledRange: Depends on the product, please see product specific requirement. Example (UPS 1, 2 and 4 are present. UPS 3 and 5 are not present): {Image: 466F710A-B3EA-4EF1-92F2-FE2F46150B4B.bmp} Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: * Setting must be kept synchronized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.  * It must only be allowed to disable a parallel UPS if there is no communication with it (example: it is completely off or parallel cables are disconnected), and if the UPS number to be disabled differs from the UPS units own unique number.  * There are no restrictions when it comes to enabling a parallel UPS.

Setting for the parallel UPS redundancy.Default value: N+0Range: N+0, N+1, N+2, N+3, N+4 etc, depends on the product, please see product specific requirement.Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies:Maximum parallel redundancy that can be set must depend on the number of parallel UPS units.Number of parallel UPS units vs maximum parallel redundancy:1:           N+02:           N+13:           N+24:           N+35:           N+4etc.Setting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.

Requirement: Minimum number of parallel UPS required to supply load setting
Description: Setting for the minimum number of UPS units required to supply the load.This number is used in a parallel system to determine when enough UPS units is ready to turn on the output and supply the full load. Range Depends on the product, please see product specific requirement.Default value: 1 Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: Maximum settable value depends on the number of UPS units in parallel for capacity. Setting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.

The UPS must provide a green burn-in mode also called Smart Power Test (SPoT), where it is possible to test the main power components like PFC, inverter, charger and static bypass switch under full load by recycling power from the output to the input of the UPS, thereby limiting the actual power consumption required during the test to a minimum.

It must be possible to turn on the inverter while the UPS is in requested static bypass operation.The output power from the inverter must then be recycled via the static bypass switch to input mains. The power consumption equals the system losses in the inverter and PFC.Requires the output to be connected via bypass to the input mains.{Image: 72DB70B7-B399-4637-AAC8-76EFB15C6877.bmp}

It must be possible to turn on the inverter while the UPS is in requested static bypass operation. The output power from the inverter must then be recycled via the static bypass switch and supply an external DC supply. The power consumption equals the system losses in the inverter, PFC the external DC supply.Requires the output to be connected via bypass to an external DC supply.{Image: 807020F9-8B1E-43C1-AC8B-4C05392D928F.bmp}
When in SPoT in normal operation or battery operation, the output power of the UPS must be adjustable by the user.

Description: Conditions to allow transfer to SPoT in normal operation:- UOB open- UPS in requested static bypass- UIB closed- Input voltage within tolerance- BB(s) open- All inverters and PFCs are operable

Description: Setting for the load power when in SPoT in normal or battery operation.Range:120%, 10 minutes100%, continuouslyDefault value:120%, 10 minutes

It must be possible to turn on the charger while in battery operation. The charge power must then be recycled via the PFC back to the DC bus. The power consumption equals the system loss only in the charger and PFC.Requires the UPS to be in Battery Operation (UIB breaker open).{Image: 79F5018C-37FF-4B8D-8C82-B3543F0CCD8E.bmp}
When in charger SPoT, the charge power of the UPS must be adjustable by the user.

It must be possible to perform a battery discharge test when running in SPoT mode. In this mode power must be taken from the battery and supplied back to the input power grid through the inverter and the static bypass switch.
When in battery discharge SPoT, the UPS must perform a battery runtime calibration test and adjust the estimated runtime accordingly.
When in battery discharge SPoT, the output power of the UPS and hence the power drawn from the battery, must be adjustable by the user (customer and FSR) in steps of 5%.
When in battery discharge SPoT, the battery discharge level % for when to exit the SPoT mode, must be adjustable by the user (customer and FSR).

It must be possible for the FSR to enable and disable if battery discharge SPoT is allowed.When enabled and allowed, it must possible for the customer to perform a battery discharge SPoT. The FSR must always be able to perform the battery discharge SPoT no matter the value of this setting.
It must be possible for the user to manually initiate and abort a battery discharge SPoT.

The UPS must indicate to the user (display / UPS Tuner) if it is currently allowed or not to start a battery discharge SPoT.The following conditions must be fulfilled to be able to start a battery discharge SPoT: * UOB open  * UPS in requested static bypass  * Battery breakers closed  * UIB open (UPS input not connected to mains, PFC in battery operation)

Setting for the battery discharge level of where the UPS must exit battery discharge SPoT.Range: 0-100%Default value: 0%
Setting to enable/disable if the battery discharge SPoT is allowed to be used by the customer.Range: Enable/disableDefault value: Disable

Indicates if it is allowed to activate battery discharge SPoT. Used to ""grey out"" button.

The UPS must synchronize its inverter output to the following sources with the given priority: 1. Parallel master (if the UPS is slave in a parallel UPS system).  2. External synchronization source (if external sync is enabled and force external sync is activated)   3. Bypass input  4. Mains input  5. Free runningNote: If UPS is configured as frequency converter it must never sync to bypass input and mains input.
The UPS must check if a synchronization source is valid and only use it if it is within the defined tolerances.The exact tolerances must be defined for each product separately.

The UPS must determine if a given synchronize source is within tolerance and the inverter PLL is allowed to synchronize to it, based on the table below. RequirementSettingSettingSettingSettingSettingSettingControllerDetection functionalityDetection input data(AC/DC)Detection levelLimit direction(Upper / Lower)Hysteresis (% of nominal value)Alarm on delay [ms]Alarm off delay [ms]Execution frequency [Hz]PLL validity detect3-phase RMSMainsPh-Neu365VrmsUpper+/- 1 %200 ms200 ms1 KHzPMC/UCMainsPh-Neu55VrmsLower+/- 1 %200 ms200 ms1 KHzPMC/UCBypassPh-Neu orPh-Ph365Vrms630VrmsUpper+/- 1 %200 ms200 ms1 KHzUCBypassPh-Neu orPh-Ph55Vrms95VrmsLower+/- 1 %200 ms200 ms1 KHzUCOutputPh-Neu orPh-Ph365Vrms630VrmsUpper+/- 1 %200 ms200 ms1 KHzPMC/UCOutputPh-Neu orPh-Ph55Vrms95VrmsLower+/- 1 %200 ms200 ms1 KHzPMC/UCExt SyncPh-Neu365VrmsUpper+/- 1 %200 ms200 ms1 KHzUCExt SyncPh-Neu55VrmsLower+/- 1 %200 ms200 ms1 KHzUC

Requirement: Info about selected synchronization source must be available to user
Description: The UPS must inform the user about which synchronization source is currently used by the inverter via events in the event log.

Requirement: User must be notified if UPS synchronization is free running
Description: The UPS must inform the user via an alarm in display, UPS Tuner and HTML interface and an event in event log, if the UPS synchronization is in free running mode.Note: If UPS is configured as frequency converter this alarm must not be posted.
When the UPS inverter output is free running (synchronized to its own internal reference), the inverter output frequency must be equal to the configured UPS system frequency (normally 50 or 60 Hz).
The speed of which the inverter output is able to change frequency to synchronize to a source (slew rate) must be configurable by the user.

Requirement: Basic UPS Synchronization to a fixed voltage source
Description: It must be possible for the UPS to synchronize its output voltage to an external voltage sources, like for example a generator.The goal is to enable a STS to shift between the UPS and the generator with a minimum output voltage break time.

Requirement: Advanced dual UPS sync with floating sync master and static bypass standby
Description: It must be possible to syncronize the output voltages between two intelligent sources (UPS units) without the need of using an external synchronization box. The UPS best suited as synchronization source must automatically be selected based on the given circumstances.The goal is to enable a STS to shift between the two UPS units with a minimum output voltage break time.Further more, if the circumstances allow it, the STS must automatically be forced to select an UPS in normal/battery operation over an UPS in static bypass as the output source to the load.
Requirements must be defined.

Requirement: Voltage quality detection on external sync voltage
Description: The UPS must be able to monitor the external synchronization voltage connected to the UPS, and detect if it is not within the defined tolerances. The following parameters must be monitored:- Voltage - RMS for each phase L1, L2 and L3 (used for PLL)- Frequency- Phase sequence- Phase missing

Sets the mode of the external synchronization feature. Possible values: ""Disable"" or ""Fixed Voltage Source Sync"" or ""Advanced Dual UPS Sync"".Default value: DisableRequired check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: Setting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.

Requirement: Force synchronization to external source setting
Description: This setting controls if the UPS is forced to sync to the external source over Mains 2 (always use external source if it is available). Possible values: Enable/disable.Default value: Disable Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: Only valid if External Sync Mode is set as ""Fixed Voltage Source Sync"".

Requirement: UPS is preferred External Sync Sync Source setting
Description: Used in connection with the ""Advanced Dual UPS Sync"" external sync function.Sets whether the given UPS is the preferred sync source if both UPS units are equally suited as external sync master. Only one UPS is allowed to be set as preferred sync source. Selectable values: Yes/NoDefault value: No Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: Only valid if External Sync Mode is set as ""Advanced Dual UPS Sync"". Setting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.

Requirement: Static Bypass Standby function enable setting
Description: Enable/disable the Static Bypass Standby function used in a dual UPS setup like shown below...  {Image: D01182B3-F15A-4F52-B87B-E1D7DDCBDAE8.bmp} The Static Bypass Standby function is used if UPS A or UPS B detects a fault and needs to enter static bypass. If the other UPS can supply the load from its inverter the faulty UPS will not be allowed to enter static bypass but instead change to Static Bypass Standby and turn off its output.This way the STS will be forced to select the UPS in inverter operation as output source to the load. Also if a dual feed load is connected it will only be supplied with power from the UPS running in inverter operation.Only if both UPS A and UPS B can no longer supply power via their inverters it will be allowed to enter static bypass and supply the load with power from Mains 2. Selectable values: Enable/disableDefault value: Disable Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: Only valid if External Sync Mode is set as ""Advanced Dual UPS Sync"". Setting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.

Requirement: User configurable input contacts and output relays
Description: A number of configurable input contacts and output relays must be available to the user. The input contacts must be configurable to indicate a given event which is selectable from a pick list.  The output relays must beconfigurable to activate on one or more events which is selectable from a pick list.

The UPS must provide a number of standard functions for the user configurable input contacts. These are listed as child requirements of this requuirement.Depending on which features are available in the UPS, there will be additional functions available for the user configurable input contacts. The requirements for these additional functions are defined under the given features.
Ground fault present (only for information)
General purpose input used for customer specific functions.
General purpose input used for customer specific functions.

The UPS must provide a number of standard functions for the userconfigurable output relays. These are listed as child requirements of this requuirement.Depending on which features are available in the UPS, there will be additional functions available for the user configurable output relays. The requirements for these additional functions are defined under the given features.
Any type of alarm (critical, warning or informational) is present in the UPS.
UPS has one or more active non-critical alarms (severity level is informational).
UPS has one or more active non-critical alarms (severity level is warning).
UPS has one or more active alarms  with severity level critical.
Any type of alarm (critical, warning or informational) is present in one or more UPS in a parallel installation.
One or more of the UPS in parallel has one or more active non-critical alarms (severity level is informational).
One or more of the UPS in parallel has one or more active non-critical alarms (severity level is warning).
One or more of the UPS in parallel installation has one or more active alarms with severity level critical.
UPS is running in Normal Operation.
UPS is running in Battery Operation.
UPS is running in Static Bypass Operation..
UPS is running in Maintenance Bypass (MBB is closed).
An external fault is active (not a fault inside the UPS).

For GVL, the external fault dry contact output must be activated if one or more of the following conditions are true: * Overload or short circuit on UPS  * Input voltage out of tolerance  * Input frequency out of tolerance  * Input phase missing  * Input phase sequence incorrect  * Neutral displacement detected  * Bypass voltage out of tolerance  * Bypass frequency out of tolerance  * Bypass phase missing  * Bypass phase sequence incorrect  * External battery monitoring detected fault  * Battery room ventilation inoperable  * Ground fault detected  * Ambient temperature high  * Ambient temperature out of tolerance  * EPO switch activated  * External sync voltage out of tolerance  * External sync frequency out of tolerance  * External sync phase missing  * External sync phase sequence incorrect
UOB is open on the given UPS.
When a given function is configured to an input contact, the time from when the input contact is activated to when the function is activated, must be maximum 5 seconds.
When a given function is configured to an output relay, the time from when the function is activated to when the output relay is activated, must be maximum 5 seconds.

The user must be able to configure a separate delay for each relay output (0 to 60 seconds).The delay must only be used when activating the output relay, not when deactivating it.The delay time must be started as soon as the UPS reports the event which is associated to the given output relay.  The delay must be configurable from display and UPS Tuner.  {Image: 137578D8-8960-4D24-987D-4AD2630D9D11.bmp}

It must be possible to configure, if a configurable output relay must be in energized check mode (failsafe mode), meaning the output relay is activated when the events associated with the output relay are not present (normally activated).This configuration must be individual for each output relay via a setting for each output relay.This way, it can be detected if the power supply to the output relays is lost, as all output relays will deactivate and the events associated with the output relays will be indicated as present.

If a critical event occurs, information about UPS voltages and currents contributes to a faster determination of the root cause of a given scenario or event at a customer site. Waveform capturing is therefore useful for diagnosing issues, getting even more detailed information about what might be the cause of a given event, and the reason behind the reaction pattern of the UPS.
A waveform capture must be triggered automatically by a number of predefined events.There must be a link between the waveform capture and which event in the event log that has triggered the capture.
It must be possible for the user to trigger a waveform capture manually.

Generally, the sample rate of the waveforms must be high enough to provide sufficient insight into why the event had occurred and to do failure and root-cause analysis.The sampling rate may differ depending on the source of the measurement. UPS input, output, bypass and DC bus voltages and currents must be sampled with a high frequency equal to the actual sampling frequency of the ADC used for the voltage quality detection, whereas measurements like temperatures can be sampled with a much lower rate.

The waveform capture length must be adequate to provide sufficient insight into why the event had occurred and to do failure and root-cause analysis.For UPS input, output, bypass voltages and currents a waveform capture must as a minimum consist of raw sampled measurement data from one period before, to one period after the event that has triggered the capture (minimum 60 ms. in total, with 30 ms. before and 30 ms. after the event that triggered the capture).
The waveform capture data and related information must be stored as files in non-volatile memory
The captured waveforms must be available to the user as a curve with a value (voltage, current etc) shown over time.
The child requirements lists the possible waveform sources to be captured. Depending on the product all waveforms may not be supported.
Input voltage, all 3 phases
Bypass voltage, all 3 phases
Output voltage, all 3 phases
Output current, all 3 phases
Battery voltage. If split battery, both positive and negative voltage.
DC bus voltage. Depending on the topology, there might be several DC bus voltages.
Ground voltage.The voltage between Neutral and Ground, measured in the UPS. Normally there is no voltage. Only in error scenarios, there would be voltages to capture.
The child requirements lists the possible events that must trigger a waveform capture. Depending on the product all events may not be supported.

The following event related to 'input voltage out of tolerance' must trigger a waveform capture:- Input voltage out of tolerance, high voltage L1- Input voltage out of tolerance, low voltage L1- Input voltage out of tolerance, high voltage L2- Input voltage out of tolerance, low voltage L2- Input voltage out of tolerance, high voltage L3- Input voltage out of tolerance, low voltage L3- Input voltage waveform out of tolerance, L1- Input voltage waveform out of tolerance, L2- Input voltage waveform out of tolerance, L3
The following event related to 'input frequency out of tolerance' must trigger a waveform capture:- Input frequency out of tolerance, high frequency- Input frequency out of tolerance, low frequency

The following event related to 'bypass voltage out of tolerance' must trigger a waveform capture:- Bypass voltage out of tolerance, high voltage L1- Bypass voltage out of tolerance, low voltage L1- Bypass voltage out of tolerance, high voltage L2- Bypass voltage out of tolerance, low voltage L2- Bypass voltage out of tolerance, high voltage L3- Bypass voltage out of tolerance, low voltage L3- Bypass voltage waveform out of tolerance, L1- Bypass voltage waveform out of tolerance, L2- Bypass voltage waveform out of tolerance, L3

The following event related to 'bypass frequency out of tolerance' must trigger a waveform capture:- Bypass frequency out of tolerance, high frequency- Bypass frequency out of tolerance, low frequency

The following event related to 'output voltage out of tolerance' must trigger a waveform capture:- Output voltage out of tolerance, high voltage L1- Output voltage out of tolerance, low voltage L1- Output voltage out of tolerance, high voltage L2- Output voltage out of tolerance, low voltage L2- Output voltage out of tolerance, high voltage L3- Output voltage out of tolerance, low voltage L3- Output voltage waveform out of tolerance, L1- Output voltage waveform out of tolerance, L2- Output voltage waveform out of tolerance, L3- DC voltage detected on output
