Requirement: Transformer present - setting has been changed
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Transformer present - setting has been changed

Requirement: Transformer temperature is too high - input contact - setting changed
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Transformer temperature is too high - input contact - setting has been changed

The UPS must be able to monitor the mains input, the bypass input, and the output of the UPS, and detect if these are not within the defined tolerances. The following parameters must be monitored:- Voltage - RMS for each phase L1, L2 and L3 of  mains input, bypass input and UPS output- Voltage - waveform for each phase L1, L2 and L3 of  mains input, bypass input and UPS output- Frequency of  mains input, bypass input and UPS output- Phase missing for mains input and bypass input- Neutral displacement- DC on output- DC bus low shutdown- DC bus collapse

Requirement: Out of tolerance detection limits must be user configurable
Description: The user must be able to configure the limits for when a voltage is detected as being out of tolerance,

Requirement: Out of tolerance detection must be logged
Description: The user must be notified via events in the event log and alarms in the alarm list, if a voltage is detected as being out of tolerance by the voltage quality detection.

Requirement: Output relay indicating if input is out of tolerance
Description: It must also be possible for the user to configure an output relay to activate if the input is out of tolerance.This covers:- Input voltage out of tolerace (waveform and/or RMS)- Input frequency out of tolerance- Input phase sequence incorrect- Input phase missing

Requirement: Output relay indicating if bypass is out of tolerance
Description: It must also be possible for the user to configure an output relay to activate if bypass is out of tolerance.This covers:- Bypass voltage out of tolerace (waveform and/or RMS)- Bypass frequency out of tolerance- Bypass phase sequence incorrect- Bypass phase missing

Setting for the output voltage tolerance levelRange: +/-3 to +/-10 %Default value: +/-10% Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: Setting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.

Setting for the output frequency tolerance in +/-Hz. Range: 1.0Hz, 3.0Hz and 10.0HzDefault value: +/-10Hz Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: Setting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.Setting must be changeable in Inverter operation, as it must be possible to change the frequency tolerance in a scenario where the UPS is not synchronized to bypass due to a frequency out of tolerance, and the user wants to extend the frequency tolerance to allow the UPS to become sync again without having to go to forced static bypass operation with a break.

Requirement: Input out of tolerance - output relay setting
Description: Setting to configure an output relay to indicate that input is out of tolerance.Range: Enable/disableDefault value: Disable

Requirement: Bypass out of tolerance - output relay setting
Description: Setting to configure an output relay to indicate that bypass is out of tolerance.Range: Enable/disableDefault value: Disable

Requirement: Reset of settings to factory default
Description: It must be possible for the user to do a factory reset of all configurable settings of the UPS, so that these settings return to the defined default values.The factory reset of settings must not reset certain settings like serial and model numbers.A factory reset must also clear the customer view of the UPS and NMC event logs.

Requirement: Reset to factory default settings only allowed from UPS Tuner
Description: It is only allowed to do a reset of settings to factory default from UPS Tuner.

Requirement: Reset to factory default settings allowed
Description: The function reset to factory settings can only be done when the UPS is in initialize state, off operation or in maintenance bypass. If the UPS is in any other operation mode, the command should be rejected.

Requirement: Reset to factory default settings warning
Description: When user chooses to command a reset of settings to factory default, a warning must be shown and user must confirm the action. The user must also be notified that a reboot (complete power down and power up) of the UPS is required.

Requirement: Reset settings to factory default command
Description: Command to reset the UPS settings to the factory default values.

Requirement: Settings reset to factory default by user
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The UPS settings have been reset to factory default by the user.
The UPS must provide a means to update the UPS firmware

Requirement: Firmware update of all controllers from one port
Description: The firmware of all intelligent boards and controllers in the UPS must be updatable from the service port using UPS Tuner.

Requirement: Firmware release in one complete package
Description: The firmware must be released one complete package containing all the firmware images for each controller in the UPS.

Requirement: Progress and status of firmware update available to user
Description: The progress and status of the firmware update procedure must shown in display and UPS display.

Requirement: Firmware update of a parallel system
Description: For a parallel redundant UPS system, it must be possible to firmware update each UPS separately while the load is supplied from inverter (no need to turn off or transfer the load to Maintenance Bypass) as long as the new firmware is compatible with the old one present in the system.If the parallel system is not redundant, it is allowed that the load must be off or in Maintenance Bypass to complete the firmware update, if the controller architecture of the system does not allow otherwise.

Requirement: Limit the time required to be in maintenance bypass during firmware update
Description: If the firmware update procedure requires the system to be in maintenance bypass to complete, the time required to be in maintenance bypass must be minimized.

Requirement: User notification of when to transfer to maintenance bypass during firmware update
Description: If the firmware update procedure requires the system to be off or in maintenance bypass to complete, the user must be notified, when a transfer to off or maintenance bypass is required.
The firmware package must be signed to ensure that only genuine firmware from Schneider Electric can used for the UPS.
It must be possible for the user to about a firmware update in progress but only during download of the firmware package.

A category for collecting the requirements for updating a complete system
The firmware update of the system at customers must only be allowed through the service port using UPS Tuner.

The SLC must check the system firmware package for a correct signing, and discard the file if it is not signed correctly.An event must be logged.If it is signing is correct the installation procedure is allowed to be started.An event must be logged.Sub modules do not have a firmware signing check
Firmware update is only allowed in maintenance bypass operation, off operation or initialize state.

When a system firmware update is performed, only be the modules that have a different firmware version than the new firmware update package must be updated. If a module has the same version as is in the firmware update package it must not be updated.

Requirement: Single UPS vs parallel UPS firmware update
Description: It is not a requirement to be able to update a parallel system from a single connection point. Each individual UPS in a parallel system must be firmware updated separately.
This category is a collection of the FW update requirements for sparepart situations
In order to be able to upgrade automatically when a part is replaced, the SLC must store the firmware images for each controller.For UC it must be the route package containing PMC and SBSC images.
When the UPS boots, it must check the firmware version of the different modules. If a module has been replaced, it must be firmware updated automatically without the need for user intervention.

Requirement: Setting for disabling automatic firmware updates
Description: A setting to disable the automatic update function in the system must be available, to avoid annoyance during development.If automatic sparepart firmware update is disabled no modules must be automatically firmware updated by the system even if they do not have that same firmware version as the system.
If the automatic firmware update function has determined to upgrade a module, and the file is not available, the system must alarm this, and the module must be prevented from starting up.

It must be the responsibility of the superior controller to validate the compatibility of the underlying modules.SLC decides if it is compatible withUC, NMC, HMI, BMCUC decides if it is compatible withPMCSBSCDDU

When validating version number on a sub module the following rules applymajor.minor.deviation.buildMajor numbermust be the same as the parent controller, or "1" (indicating it is a pure platform module)Minor numbermust be identical to the expected number on the parent. It does not have to match the parents numberDeviation numbermust be identical to the expected number on the parent. It does not have to match the parents number. Exception: if the deviation number is 200-255 it is an engineering version and per definition compatibleBuild numberDoes not have to match

Requirement: Automatic sparepart firmware update - setting changed
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Automatic sparepart firmware update - setting has been changed
A category for specific device requirements in relation to FW update
Controllers for power flow control (UC, PMC and SBSC) must have dual image for firmware storage, so one bank is updated while the other is in operation.
When a power flow controller (UC, PMC and SBSC) is rebooted after flashing a new firmware image, and it does not boot correctly, it must reboot again on the factory firmware image.

When a new firmware file is pushed to a device, the device must validate the file before accepting it.If the file is discarded it must be logged.Validation parameters are:It has the correct 0P-number.It has the correct target chip (A2, A4, A5 or A6 device).
* The UPS must include an authentication procedure when connecting to UPS Tuner, to ensure that it is only possible to connect a valid version of UPS Tuner version to the UPS.

When a cable is connected to the service port, it must be required by the user to confirm that he/she is physically present at the UPS (proximity check).The user must go to a dedicated menu in the display and press a button, before UPS Tuner is able to connect to the UPS.The proximity confirmation must be done by the user within 30 seconds after the cable has been connected, else the connection must be rejected.A connection between UPS Tuner and the UPS must have been established within 10 minutes after the proximity check has completed, else the connection is rejected by the UPS.

A password check must be done between the UPS and UPS Tuner to verify that only a valid version of UPS Tuner providing the right password is allowed to connect to, and communicate with, the UPS.If the authentication fails, UPS Tuner must be disconnected by the UPS.

* If the cable is disconnected from the service port the connection to UPS Tuner must be closed right away .  *   * A new connection to the service port must not be allowed within 5 seconds after a time-out, disconnection or failed authentication of UPS Tuner.
To be able to trace who is connected via Tuner, the License number of Tuner must be stored in the service log at connection.
Alarms and event for the UPS Tuner authentication feature

Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: UPS Tuner is connected to the product.Event data must include the license number of the UPS Tuner software connected to the product.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: UPS Tuner is no longer connected to the product.

Requirement: Data dump to USB memory key

Description: It must be possible to do a backup of the settings of the UPS and restore them again both via display and UPS Tuner.

Requirement: Request a dump of settings to USB-key from HMI
Description: It must be possible for the user to request a dump of all settings in the UPS from the HMI.

Requirement: Import settings from USB-key from HMI
Description: It must be possible for the user to import the settings from a USB key

The file must be validated if it fits the unit. This is done by comparing the serial number the file was generated from, with the serial number of the UPS importing.It must also validate the integrity of the file

When importing from a USB key file, it is not allowed to set the following parametersSerial number of UPSModel number of UPSRFID Serial numberApparent Power rating3:3 or 3:1 configurationVoltage range (208/400/480)3 or 4 wire configurationN+1 configuration (Bravo only)

Description: Tuner must have the capability to read a file a customer has stored via USB key

Requirement: Modify and store setting dump file
Description: UPS Tuner must have the capability to modify and store a file, that can be imported into the UPS
The file must contain a checksum or hash value, for verification of the contend is not corrupted or modified by third party.

Requirement: Alarming if file is not valid
Description: It must be indicated by an alarm if the file the system tries to import is not valid.The alarm is reset again when the USB key is removed, or a new file import is started

Requirement: User request to export UPS report
Description: It must be possible for the user to request the UPS to generate an UPS report and store it on a USB key, via a button on the display.

The UPS report must contain enough information to enable remote diagnostics in a customer care center.The following data/information must be collected in the CCC report:- Full UPS event log.- All UPS settings and configuration data.- Waveform capture files.- Statistics data.- LCM data.- All measurement values and status data which are also available in the display and UPS Tuner.- Active alarm list

Requirement: User request to abort UPS report export in progress
Description: It must be possible for the user to abort an UPS report export that is in progress.
While exporting the UPS report the UPS must show the status/progress to the user in the display.

Requirement: Navigate away from UPS report export display screen
Description: While the UPS is exporting the UPS report it must be possible for the user to navigate away from the UPS report export screen in the display and back again.

Requirement: Import UPS report in UPS Tuner
Description: It must be possible to open a UPS report in UPS Tuner and to view all the information contained in the report.

It must be allowed to do live swap of power modules, meaning the power modules are allowed to be replaced while the UPS is in inverter operation (in addition to off operation or maintenance bypass).

Primary Actor(s)-          User.Stakeholders and InterestsUser              : .Pre conditionsPost conditionsUPS must ensure that an inserted module is allowed to actively operate in the system.Main success scenario1.      UPS in inverter operation2.      A power module is inserted and the enable switch is engaged.3.      The power module boots up and performs a self-test.4.      The UC checks for compatibility.5.    The UC allows the inserted power module to actively operate in the system.6.    The inserted power module becomes operable and participates actively in the system (transfers to inverter operation). Alternative scenariosScenario 1:1.      UPS in off operation or maintenance bypass.2.      A power module is inserted and the enable switch is engaged.3.      The power module boots up and performs a self-test.4.      The UC checks for compatibility.5.      The UC allows the inserted power module to actively operate in the system.6.    The inserted power module becomes operable.7.    The user transfers the UPS back to inverter operation and the inserted power module participates actively in the system. Scenario 2:1.      UPS in inverter operation2.      A power module is rebooted (there are two or more power modules in the UPS).3.      The power module boots up and performs a self-test.4.      The UC checks for compatibility.5.      The UC allows the booted power module to actively operate in the system.6.    The booted power module becomes operable.7.    The booted power module participates actively in the system (transfers to inverter operation).

The UPS must include surveillance functionality on main components to ensure that out of range operational conditions or inoperable/faulty components are detected and reported, and that relevant converters are shut down to prevent component failures and failure propagation.

There must be a surveillance function available to detect inoperable PSUs and report it to the user. Only PSU voltages that are actually monitored by either a dedicated voltage monitoring HW circuit or via an ADC, must be monitored and status reported by the firmware. The firmware cannot monitor individual voltages if it gets no information about the status from the HW or has no ADC input to monitor the voltage.
There must be a surveillance function available to detect blown fuses and report it to the user.
There must be a surveillance function available to detect shorted IGBTs and IGBT desaturation, shut down the relevant converters, and report it to the user.
There must be a surveillance function available to detect overheating, shut down the relevant converters, and report it to the user.
There must be a surveillance function available to detect peak currents limits, shut down the relevant converters, and report it to the user.

Requirement: Surveillance of high DC bus voltages
Description: There must be a surveillance function available to detect for high DC bus voltages, shut down the relevant converters, and report it to the user.

Requirement: Surveillance of currents deviating from reference
Description: There must be a surveillance function available to detect if the actual measured current deviates too much from the reference current, shut down the relevant converters, and report it to the user.
There must be a surveillance function available to detect differences between voltage measurements, and report it to the user via alarms and events in the event log.
There must be a surveillance function available to detect if ADCs are not working correctly, and report it to the user via alarms and events in the event log.

The system must give an alarm if the output voltage sense circuit is measuring wrong. The RMS output voltage form the UC must be compared to either a SBS measurement or a PM measurement and post an alarm if they deviate more than 15%.The measurement must be conditioned of having communication between the modules, and the time these need to deviate must be 500 ms. for error and 600 ms. for OK statement.There must be one comparison for each phase, and they must have same reference.

There must be a surveillance function available to detect if communication is lost on each of the individual internal communication busses in the UPS, and report it to the user via alarms and events in the event log.The following must be monitored:- The communication status between UC and SLC- The communication status between HMI and SLC- The communication status between PMCs and UC- The communication status between SBSC and UCThe communication status must be reflected according to the connection status of the individual modules/nodes (also refer to HOW32384):- Disconnected:           Communication lost - disconnected- Connected:               Communication lost - connected- Authenticated:           Communication OK- Authentication failed: Communication not authenticated

Requirement: Clear indication to user when communication is lost to controller
Description: It must be clearly indicated to the user if the communication is lost to a controller.- An alarm must be shown in display and UPS Tuner indicating that the communication is lost to the given controller.- It must be clearly indicated in display and UPS Tuner that any data, measurements etc. coming from the given controller are no longer valid and/or are unknown.
UPS must support connecting temperature and humidity probes to the NMC.- Temperature probe AP9335T.- Temperature/Humidity probe AP9335TH.

Requirement: Notify user if temperature or humidity is above or below the configured thresholds
Description: The user must be notified via alarms in display and UPS Tuner if the temperature or humidity is above or below the user configured thresholds (warning low, critical low, warning high, critical high).

The following probe status must be available in the display:- Probe present- Temperature normal- Temperature warning Low- Temperature critical Low- Temperature warning high- Temperature critical high- Humidity normal- Humidity warning low- Humidity critical low- Humidity warning high- Humidity critical high

The following probe information must be available in the display:- If there is a probe attached to the NMC.- Which type of probe is connected to the NMC (temperature probe or temperature/humidity probe).- The name given to the probe by the customer.
The temperature and/or humidity measured by the probes must be available in the display.

The temperature reported by the probe in degree's Celsius, to a precision of 0.1. Unit: CPrecision: 1 decimalTemperature accuracy ±3ºF (±2ºC), from 32 to 104ºF (0 to 40ºC)Sensor operating temperature 14 to 159ºF (–10 to 70ºC)Measurement must be available for each probe connected.

The UPS must not require the user (customer/FSR) to do a product registration (like done in GVS) and never show any reminder to register the product.

UPS must display a product registration reminder pop-up screen in the display at first startup to remind to register the product.Product registration must be done by FSR using UPS Tuner.It must be possible to "snooze" the reminder.If product is registered, no more reminders must be shown.If snoozed, the reminder must be shown again after a period of 1 week.If snoozed again, it must be shown again after 1 month.If snoozed again, it must be shown again after 3 months.If snoozed again, the reminder must not be shown anymore.{Image: 4E3EDAC7-32A1-4969-893C-DF267A1EE4E0.bmp}For testing purposes, it must be possible shorten the reminder interval.
Settings used for product registration
This setting tells the UPS if the product has been registered or not, and must only be visible and configurable via UPS Tuner.Range: True or falseDefault value: False
Alarms and event for the Product registration feature
Type: AlarmSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: Please register your product.Description: Your UPS is not registered
Type: AlarmSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: .Description: Product registration has been completed successfully

At power up the UPS must show the Energy Star logo in the display for at least 5 seconds.This must only be the case for the SKUs that are on the Energy Star approved list. For GVL all SKUs are Energy Star approved.- A pop-up window must be shown in the display and automatically disappear again after minimum 5 seconds.- The window must first be shown when communication to the SLC is established.

At power-up, the UPS must perform an automatic self-test of the main parts (like power modules, controllers etc.) to ensure the UPS is operational before it is connected to the load.Steps performed during the startup self-test are:- Check of hardware configuration and revisions.- Check of internal communication busses- Check of firmware revisions vs. hardware- Check of source voltages.- Check of DC voltages.- Check of PFC state- Check of surveillance status.- Perform an inverter selftest, generating output voltage locally on the inverter(s).- Check of memory The progress and status of the startup self-test must be available to the user via active alarms and events in the event log.

At power-up, the power module must perform an automatic self-test with the following steps... - Check that power module has initialized correctly.- Check that the power module hardware configuration is correct.- Check that the input voltage sources (mains input and battery) are within tolerance.- Check that precharge has completed.- Start PFC.- Check that DC bus voltages are within tolerance.- Start inverter and check that it operates correctly.- Start fans and check that they operate correctly.- Check if any surveillance detected faults are present.

At boot up the FW must validate the current HW version is the expected and is compatible with the FW version.The check should contain the 0P number of the HW, and if present version number via pins on the HW.If the FW is not compatible with the Hardware, it should stop the execution, and stop triggering the Watchdog.
The power module must indicate its self-test status via a LED on the power module.Self-test running: LED flashing greenSelf-test passed: LED solid greenSelf-test failed: LED flashing red

At boot up the FW must validate the current HW version is the expected and is compatible with the FW version.This check must compare the SBS model number against the hardware revision of the SBS (via pins on the HW).If the FW is not compatible with the hardware, it must stop the execution (stay in self-test step).

The SBS must indicate its self-test status via a LED on the SBS module.Self-test running: LED flashing greenSelf-test passed: LED solid greenSelf-test failed: LED flashing redREJECTED: No SBS status LED in GVL.
At power-up, the SLC must perform an automatic self-test of the main parts to ensure it is operational:

At boot up the FW must validate the current HW version is the expected and is compatible with the FW version.The check should contain the 0P number of the HW, and if present version number via pins on the HW.If the FW is not compatible with the Hardware, it should stop the execution, and stop triggering the Watchdog.
At boot up the SLC must test the memory of the controller.
At boot up the SLC must check the integrity of the file system
At boot up the SLC must check the integrity of the database containing the configuration parameters
At power-up, the UC must perform an automatic self-test of the main parts to ensure it is operational:{Image: 05D0B947-8F39-4806-9E9B-F0A36F57BD42.bmp}
At start-up self-test the UC must perform memory integrity check.

Requirement: UC HW and FW compatibility check
Description: At start-up self-test the FW must validate the current HW version is the expected and is compatible with the FW version.The check should contain the 0P number of the HW, and if present version number via pins on the HW.If the FW is not compatible with the Hardware, it should stop the execution, and stop triggering the Watchdog.

Requirement: Hold back test until configuration is complete
Description: When powering up, the modules should not perform selftest until the settings from the system has been shared, to avoid selftest failing, due to wrong settings.If the system is not configured the first time yet the selftest of modules must be hold back until the correct settings are distributed from these sources.

Description: The port expander must be able to provide status information to UPS, like which channel has a PMC connected, and the communication status.
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: The port expander must be a 10:1 expander. It must however be possible to create a version with less ports populated if necessary (1:6) as example, so the design must cater for this future option.
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: As the CBUS port expander includes firmware (FPGA code), it must be possible to update the CBUS port expander in the field via the same method as used for the other boards. This means using UPS Tuner.The firmware update of the port expander must just be another module in the sequence of modules, that gets updated (PM, SBS, BMC, HMI etc.).
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: Adding a port expander must not change the ability for the UC to communicate with, and firmware update, a PMC. It must be backwards compatible, especially considering spare part handling.In general, it means that an existing PM spare part needs to be able to be put into a system with a port expander and communicate with the UC. As minimum, the identification data (FW version, HW version, Model, etc.) must be available regardless which slot in the port expander the PM is communicating through. The PMC must also be firmware updatable from the UC in this situation.
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: If a UC spare part is inserted, which runs existing Alpha/Bravo spare part code, it is not required that the UC can recognize all PM’s connected to a port expander. It is required that the UC will be able to communicate with the PM connected to the communication slot number 1, which in the protocol is equivalent to if there was no port expander connected, and thereby establish identification.
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: The real time communication delay from UC to PMC has an impact on the performance of the UPS. For every µs of added delay, between 0.4-0.65° of phase margin will be consumed.The maximum acceptable phase margin impact is difficult to quantize, but for comparison it is planned to reconstruct the current loop, to gain 1.5 µsFor the real time communication from PMC to UC, the requirement is a bit more relaxed, as the bandwidth is not so high here, but still it should not add more than a few µs.ISSUE: Need to define the maximum delay allowed.
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich
Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: This category hold the requirements for the internal communication links. They are not necessarily linked to customer requirements, but arise as a consequence of the modules/components are part of a platform
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: It must be so, that all modules/nodes can enter in the system, and then establish connection. There may not exist a specific order, or timing requirement, that forces a module (Module A) to be rebooted, because module B established connection.The system must end in an operational state if all modules a compliant, no matter the booting sequence of timing of the establishing of communication
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: For internal nodes communicating with the SLC via MQTT, the communcation status is defined as 4 statesDisconnectedConnectedAuthenticatedAuthentication failedThis is required forSLC - UC1SLC - UC2SLC - NMC (internal)SLC - NMC2SLC - HMISLC - HMI adaptor for systems which have no MQTT interface to HMI
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: Internal nodes communicating with SLC, must be able to identify themselves, by- FW version- Model number- Serial number- HW versionThis must be possible between any released FW versions of the nodes.
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: For internal nodes connected to the SLC it must always be possible to FW upgrade the node (UC, HMI, NMC), from the SLC. This is regardless of which released FW that is on the SLC and the node
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: When a node gets connected, it must reports its status and error states. It is not necessary to report historical data, only current status.
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: When a node is trying to connect, and times out due to no connection established. It should retry again.After 5 retries (or another reasonable number of retries for the connection), the connection should wait 5-10 minutes and try againIf still no connection, the connection should try once every 5-10 minutes. In this state no loggings should occur to avoid filling logs with unnecessary information. The connection should start logging as soon as it gets a connection.We should never leave the connection in a state that requires recycling of power
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: When communication is established between a parent and a child module, the parent module must determine if the child module is compatible for operation or not.The check will consist of a HW check and a FW check
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: When exchanging information, the parent controller must have a list of compatible Model numbers of the child unit, that it can operate with.Ex.: UC can operate with model numbers:0G-PM20KD and 0G-PM50KDIf it is a unknown module - the child module is per default incompatibleIf a module is deemed incompatible, it will not be allowed working by the parent module
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: The parent module must compare the FW version number to a compatible list of versionsThe rules are listed under the firmware update requirements.If the FW is incompatible the FW update function must be triggered
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich
Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: This category contains the requirements for time handling and synchronization on the different devices.
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: Epoch reference is the 1 January 2000.The traditional epoch from 1970 is not used in this system.
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: The RTC master is the UC
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: In a parallel system, the parallel master is also the RTC master. Parallel slaves will have to adjust their internal RTC to the parallel masters RTC.In the unit, it is still the UC that is the RTC master for all another devices.
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Requirement: Precision of the sync of time
Description: The parallel UC's must sync time within 5ms precision
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: The devices can request a time and date changes, through a time setting datagram. The RTC master will change the time and date, and distribute this through another datagram.It must be logged if the time and date was adjusted.
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich
Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: Command to the RTC master to tell the actual time.The RTC master will update the Time datagram, with time and date
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: Setting to adjust the date and time on the RTC master. This setting datagram should not be stored like other settings.The setting change must be logged
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich
Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

At power-up, the SBS must perform an automatic self-test of the main parts to ensure it is operational before it is connected to the load.Steps performed during the startup self-test are:{Image: 7DEE752D-E11B-4D55-BF46-7DC2ED8AFBFC.bmp} The global status of the self-test must be available to the user via active alarms and events in the event log.

Requirement: Removing the reduction of maximum charge current function
Description: The reduction of the maximum allowed charge current to protect against thermal runaway, must be removed again when the charge mode changes to anything else than float charge (discharging, boost charging, equalization charging etc.)....

Requirement: Maximum current threshold for thermal runaway protection
Description: The maximum allowed charge current must be reduced to:0.1C for lead acid batteries

Requirement: Battery float charge current exceeds expected value
Description: Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: Check batteryDescription: The battery float charge current exceeds the expected value and has been limited to avoid thermal runaway

Requirement: Battery float charge current no longer exceeds expected value
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The battery float charge current no longer exceeds the expected value

Requirement: Reduce maximum battery charge limit to protect against thermal runaway
Description: To protect against thermal runaway, the charging function must reduce the maximum allowed charge current, when the batteries are fully charged."Fully charged" is defined as 1 hour after the charger has been in float charge, with no current limitation, and the state of charge is above 99%
It nust be possible for the user to configure if a common battery is used in the parallel system via UPS Tuner.

Requirement: Battery settings configurability with common battery
Description: When system is configured for common battery only the FSR must be able to configure the battery settings via UPS Tuner, except the general battery settings which must also be available to the customer via the display.

Requirement: Battery settings that must be identical on all parallel UPS units in a common battery configuration
Description: The following battery related settings must be configured identically on all parallel UPS units in a common battery configuration:Specific battery settings only available to FSR when UPS is configured for common battery:- Number of battery strings setting- Battery type setting- Number of batteries in series setting- Number of cells in battery setting- Battery block capacity setting- Battery midpoint present setting- Low battery shutdown level setting- Float charge voltage setting- Boost charge mode enable setting- Boost charge voltage setting- Boost charge time setting- Equalization charge voltage setting- Equalization charge time setting- Battery temperature reference setting- Charge current rate (CA rate) setting- Battery deep discharge allowed setting- Battery runtime calculation method setting- Battery runtime calculation value 1 setting- Battery runtime calculation value 2 setting- Battery runtime calculation value 3 setting- Battery runtime calculation value 4 setting- Battery runtime calculation value 5 setting- Battery runtime calculation value 6 setting- Automatic battery disconnect setting?- Battery temperature monitoring- Maximum allowed string discharge current setting? (Li-ion)- Energy storage internal surveillance enable setting? (Li-ion)- Input ramp-in time setting?General battery settings both available to FSR and customer when UPS is configured for common battery:- Number of battery cabinets setting- Battery cabinet SKU number setting- BB1 present setting- BB2 present setting- High battery temperature level setting- Low battery temperature level setting- Battery runtime low warning threshold setting- Auto boost charge mode setting- Auto cyclic charge mode setting- Scheduled battery self-test interval setting- Scheduled battery self-test time setting- Scheduled battery self-test day of week setting- Charge power setting- Maximum battery charge power level when on generator - setting

The user must configure the battery capacity in each parallel UPS units equal to the total capacity of the common battery.The system must then automatically calculate the actual battery capacity available to each UPS by dividing the total capacity of the common battery by the number of parallel UPS units configured as present.

Requirement: Common battery only allowed for 3-wire battery
Description: Common battery in parallel system is only allowed for a 3-wire battery configuration (split battery).This means that none of the standard classic battery cabinet SKUs can be used as common battery.

Requirement: Battery runtime calibration test must be disabled
Description: The battery runtime calibration test function must be disabled when simplified common battery in parallel system is enabled.The reason is that this test will not work correctly. Even if test is started on all parallel UPS units at the same time, one UPS might exit before another and start charging the battery. This will interfere with the test on the other UPS units.

Requirement: Common battery only allowed for classic battery solutions
Description: Only classic battery solutions are allowed to be used as common battery for a parallel system. Modular battery solutions are not supported.

Requirement: Individual battery breaker for each UPS
Description: There must be one individual battery breaker for each UPS connected to the common battery.

Requirement: Individual battery temperature sensorfor each UPS
Description: There must be one individual battery temperature sensor for each UPS connected to the common battery.

The standard battery LCM (life cycle monitoring) feature must be handled individually on each parallel UPS with common battery. There is no synchonization of battery LCM data between UPS units in the simplified common battery feature.

The standard battery CBLCM (condition based life cycle monitoring) feature must be handled individually on each parallel UPS with common battery. There is no synchonization of battery CBLCM data between UPS units in the simplified common battery feature.

Setting to configure if a common battery is used in a parallel system.Range: Enable/disableDefault value: DisableRequired check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: Setting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Common battery - setting has been changed

Requirement: Simplified common battery in parallel system
Description: The UPS must support to operate with one common battery in a parallel system configuration, so that all the parallel UPS units share the same battery. For the simplified common battery feature:- The charge current, state of charge, remaning runtime and charger operation mode must be controlled, calculated and set individually by each parallel UPS as if they where running on individual batteries.- The system must not check that all relevant battery settings are the same on all parallel UPS units. It is up to the user to verify this manually.
Common battery in parallel system must be allowed for a 2-wire battery configuration

For the Li-ion solution the maximum battery discharge CA-rate setting must be set to 7.98C.
The maximum discharge CA-rate must be user configurable to take into account different types and brands of batteries.
Setting to configure the maximum battery discharge CA-rate allowed. An alarm is posted of this discharge CA-rate is above this threshold. Range: 1C - 10CDefault value: 6C

Requirement: Maximum battery discharge CA-rate - setting changed
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Maximum battery discharge CA-rate - setting has been changed.

The battery voltage configuration check must evaluate the battery voltage the first time it is applied after a start-up. If the configuration is changed afterwards, the evaluation must only be done if control system is rebooted.

Whether or not a battery is present is determined by having a voltage of 250V (equals 1.3V/cell in a 32 block system).For lead acid the correct voltage for accepting the configuration :The battery voltage must be above 1.9V/cellThe battery voltage must be below 2.30V/cell

It must be possible for the user to acknowledge and override the warning, if the battery voltage is too high after start-up.Background:The battery voltage is checked, if it is above a threshold level, otherwise it is considered a wrong configuration. This works fine if the battery is in resting mode, or have been float charged just before a restart. If the battery was boost charged, and the unit rebooted, the voltage could be too high for a period, and blocking to accept the battery voltage. In this case it should be possible for the user,via the HMI to override the warning an proceed.

Requirement: Double confirmation for overriding battry blocking
Description: It must be confirmed twice before a overriding of the battery blocking is accepted

Requirement: Logging of the override function for blocking batteries
Description: It must be logged that the user accepted to override the blocking of batteries

Requirement: Battery voltage does not match battery configuration
Description: Type: AlarmSeverity: CriticalCorrective Action Text: Check and correct battery settingsDescription: Battery voltage does not match the battery configuration settings
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text:Description: Battery voltage matches the battery configuration settings

Requirement: Battery voltage configuration check override by user
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: User has accepted to manually override the battery voltage configuration check

The UPS must have a function that evaluates the battery voltage and compares it to the battery configuration, before the battery relays in the power modules are activated.This function is only required for lead-acid battery configuration.

Requirement: Reduce battery charge current when on generator
Description: It must be possible to make the UPS reduce the charge power when it is supplied from a generator.
List of supported UPS power frame types:Valid model numbers are:GVLFRM200K500D

It must be possible to populate 3 Cbus channels on the UC with port expanders. There is no requirement for being able to connect 4 or 5.NOTE: This is an architecture requirement, needs to be moved out of GVL. Actually only 2 is a requirement for GVL.

Requirement: Parallel UPS address number setting range
Description: Maximum number of parallel UPS units in GVL is 5, meaning the parallel UPS address number setting range is:  Range: 1 to 5.

Requirement: Parallel UPS units enabled/present setting range
Description: Maximum number of parallel UPS units in GVL is 5, meaning the parallel UPS units enabled/present setting range is:  Range: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 present

Requirement: Parallel UPS units enabled/present setting range
Description: Setting for the parallel UPS redundancy. Maximum number of parallel UPS units in GVL is 5, meaning the maximum allowed redundant UPS units must be 4.Default value: N+0Range: N+0, N+1, N+2, N+3, N+4N+0 is only allowed for a parallel system of 4 UPS units or below (5 parallel UPS units for power is not allowed).

The local temperature of the SBS (heatsink and PCB) must be monitored, and the user must be notified via alarms/events if the temperature arises above a certain limit:- High fault threshold: 90 degrees C.- High warning threshold: 65 degrees C.- High recovery threshold: 50 degress C.

Description: Setting to indicate the bonding configuration between neutral and ground of the UPS.Range:""Neutral bonded directly to ground internally in the UPS""""IT Earthing System (N to PE impedance installed)"" Default value: Neutral connected directly to ground. Setting must only be availlable if ""AC wiring configuration"" is set to ""4-wire or 3-wire solid grounded"".Setting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup. Setting is only configurable when the UPS AND the System are in Off Operation or Maintenance Bypass

Description: The UPS must check that the battery configuration is within the minimum and maximum supported battery voltage of the UPS:Total battery voltage = number of batteries in series * number of cells in battery * cell charge voltage.(cell charge voltage must take into account float, boost and equalization charge mode) The allowed battery voltage range depends on the UPS system voltage and power rating as described in requirement, but as only the 50kW PM is supported in GVL, the supported nominal battery voltage is limited to 480V-576V (40-48 blocks):{Image: A23EEA7E-7379-444C-AC67-B2D930E21D02.bmp}

Primary Actor(s) -          UPS.Stakeholders and InterestsUPS              : Behavior when UPS core control stops responding.Pre conditionsThe UPS is either in off, normal or bypass operation and batteries are connected.Post conditionsUPS must supply conditioned power to load if possible.Main success scenario  1. UPS is in inverter operation or requested static bypass operation or ECO mode or ECOnversion mode (the bypass input voltage is within configured bypass voltage tolerance on all three phases).  2. UPS core control stops sending heartbeat request messages on UEP protocol to SBS for 150ms.  3. UPS is transferred to emergency static bypass operation.  4. SBS will timeout communication and start broadcast heartbeats to core control.  5. If UPS core control reestablish communication successful, UPS will return to inverter operation.Alternative scenariosScenario 1a: 1. UPS is in inverter operation.  2. The bypass input voltage is below configured bypass voltage tolerance on all three phases (UPS configured to allow transfer to static bypass with bypass out of tolerance)  3. UPS core control stops sending heartbeat request messages on UEP protocol to SBS for 150ms.  4. UPS is transferred to emergency static bypass operation.  5. SBS will timeout communication and start broadcast heartbeats to core control.  6. If UPS core control reestablish communication successful, UPS will return to inverter operation.Scenario 1b: 1. UPS is in inverter operation.  2. The bypass input voltage is below configured bypass voltage tolerance on all three phases (UPS configured to not allow transfer to static bypass with bypass out of tolerance)  3. UPS core control stops sending heartbeat request messages on UEP protocol to SBS for 150ms.  4. UPS stays in inverter operation, but SBS is transferred to off operation.  5. SBS will timeout communication and start broadcast heartbeats to core control.  6. If UPS core control reestablish communication successful, UPS will stay in inverter operation, SBS will transfer to ready state.Scenario 2: 1. UPS is in forced static bypass operation.  2. UPS core control stops sending heartbeat request messages on UEP protocol to SBS for 150ms.  3. UPS is transferred to emergency static bypass operation.  4. SBS will timeout communication and start broadcast heartbeats to core control.  5. If UPS core control reestablish communication successful, UPS will return to inverter operation if possible else it will return to forced static bypass operation.Scenario 3: 1. UPS is in off operation.  2. UPS core control stops sending heartbeat request messages on UEP protocol to SBS for 150ms.  3. UPS stays in off operation and does not transfer to emergency static bypass operation.  4. SBS will timeout communication and start broadcast heartbeats to core control.  5. If UPS core control reestablish communication successful, UPS will stay in off operation.

Input pictogram Red (must be shown with black color on the display mimic in GVL):- Mains input out of tolerance (frequency, voltage) or- UIB openGreen:- If not redOff (also shown in black):- If not red or greenBypass pictogram  Red (must be shown with black color on the display mimic in GVL):- Bypass input out of tolerance (frequency, voltage) or- SSIB open or- Inverter is not able to synchronize to bypassGreen:- If not redOff (also shown in black):- If not red or green or- If transfer to static bypass is disabled by userOutput pictogram  Red (must be shown with black color on the display mimic in GVL):- Load disconnected (UOB/SIB open) while UPS is not in off operation or- Output out of tolerance (frequency, voltage) while load is connected and UPS is not in off operationGreen:- If not red and- UPS is not in off operationOff:- If not red or green (UPS off operation)

When battery is disconnected the charge voltage must be set to nominal cell voltage: (2.0V/cell for lead acid, 3.75V/cell for Li Ion, 1.2V/cell for NiCd)The maximum charge current must be limited according to the nominal UPS power rating:380/400/440/415/480V systems:<200kW (4 PMs or below): 4A200kW> (5 PMs or more): +1A for each additional PM present. Some examples: - UPS with 10 PMs, maximum charge current when battery is disconnected must be 10A.  - UPS with 5 PMs, maximum charge current when battery is disconnected must be 5A.  - UPS with 2 PMs, maximum charge current when battery is disconnected must be 4A.

Requirement: Battery types supported for common battery
Description: Both VRLA and Li-ion must be supported for common battery in a parallel system.

The battery condition must be reported to the user, but only if the battery self-test mode is configured as 'capacity'.One of the following conditions must be reported depending on the measured voltage of the battery (see requirement for "Battery condition estimation" for more details):·        Battery condition OK: Posted as an event if battery capacity is above 75% of nominal.·        Battery condition weak: Shown as an alarm if battery capacity is between 50% and 75% of nominal.·        Battery condition poor: Shown as an alarm if battery capacity is below 50% of nominal.

Requirement: User configurable minimum scalable nominal power rating
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure the minimum nominal power rating of a scalable UPS via UPS Tuner.This value defines the minimum number of power modules that must be present and available in the UPS. If there are not enough power modules present to fulfil the configued minimum nominal power rating an alarm must be posted to the user.

Requirement: Minimum scalable nominal power rating setting
Description: Setting to configure the minimum scalable nominal power rating of the UPS Range: 200, 250, 300, 350, 400, 450 kWDefault value: 200 kW

Requirement: Minimum scalable nominal power rating - setting changed
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Minimum scalable nominal power rating - setting has been changed
It must be allowed to charge from bypass, when the operation mode is requested static bypass, ECO mode or ECOnversion.

Description: It must be possible to perform all the required NPI firmware related tests at the standard voltages/frequencies of 400/480V and 50/60Hz.
It must be possible to control and get data from the subassembly/UPS system being tested without having to disassembling it, meaning an external test interface connection must be available.

Requirement: Subassembly status flag available via test interface
Description: It must be possible to read all fault flags/states from the test interface on subassemblies (power module, static bypass switch and controller box)

Requirement: Ability to clear fault flags/states via test interface
Description: It must be possible to clear any active fault flags and states in subassemblies  (power module, static bypass switch and controller box) via the test interface using a single command.

Requirement: Ability to read and write product information via test interface
Description: It must be possible to read internal parameters like operation mode, and write configuration data and product information like serial numbers in subassemblies  (power module, static bypass switch and controller box) via the test interface.

Requirement: Ability to read one general fault status flag via test interface
Description: It must be possible to read one general subassembly (power module, static bypass switch and controller box) fault status flag via the test interface, indicating the fault status of the subassembly for example using an error code or similar.

Requirement: No calibration must be required during test
Description: It must not be required to do any manual calibration of currents and voltages during test. If required, self(auto)-calibration is OK

To keep manufacturing testing independant of product releases, a specific NPI FW must be made available, or a special test mode must be available in the product FW. The final product customer FW is added after the test is done.

It must be possible to set the UPS into a special NPI test mode.When in this mode certain test functions will be enabled and available for NPI. These features are liste as child requirements to this requirement.It must not be possible to enable NPI test mode at a customer site.

Requirement: Charge battery with battery breakers open/not present
Description: It must be possible to charge the battery even if battery breakers are indicated as open and/or configured as not present. During NPI test, battery is connected without battery breakers and it is not possible to manually add jumpers on the BB AUX inputs on the UPS.So, when in NPI test mode, the UPS must always simulate BB1 as present and closed, and use the battery parameters configured for BB1. BB2 must be simulated as not present and open.
It must be possible to enable and disable NPI test mode via UPS Tuner, but only if the user has a R&D license for UPS Tuner and if the serial number of the UPS is SJxxxxxxxx.

Input LED Red:- Mains input out of tolerance (frequency, voltage) or- UIB open or- PFC inoperable/shutdown or- PFC is off and UPS is not in ECOnversion modeGreen:- If not red and- PFC is in normal operationOff:- If not red or green (PFC is off)Bypass LED Red:- Bypass input out of tolerance (frequency, voltage) or- SSIB or BF2** open or- SBS inoperable or- SBS is activated with a faultGreen:- If not red and- SBS is activatedOff:- if not red or green (SBS deactivated)Battery LED Red:- Battery inoperable* or- All battery breakers open / battery not connectedGreen:- If not red and- PFC in battery operationOff:- if not red or greenInverter LED Red:- Inverter inoperable/shutdownGreen:- If not red and- Inverter onOff:- if not red or green (inverter off)Output LED Red:- Load disconnected (UOB/SIB open) while UPS is not in off operation or- Output voltage out of tolerance while load is connected and UPS is not in off operationGreen:- If not red and- UPS is not in off operationOff:- if not red or green (UPS off operation)*Battery inoperable means one or more of the following conditions are true: - Battery voltage out of tolerance (high and low)- Battery voltage collapse- Battery configuration invalid- Battery capacity is below minimum acceptable level- Battery room ventilation inoperable- External battery monitoring detected fault- Battery fuse blown or battery relay is not working correctly- Battery not connected**Only if a BF2 actually exists and is present.
The UPS name must be shown to the user on the display, web interface and in UPS Tuner.
The UPS name must be configurable by user via the display (and UPS Tuner) if the user want to name the UPS differently than the default UPS name.
UPS name setting.Range: String of 22 charactersDefault value: The default UPS name defined as: Galaxy VL [UPS power rating]
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: NPI test mode - setting has been changed
Setting to enable and disable the NPI test mode.Possible values: Enable/disableDefault value: Disable

The controller box must have an enable switch which controls if the controller (UC and SLC) must be enabled or disabled. - Before the controller box is removed, the enable switch must be set to 'disabled' to shut down the controller.- When the controller box has been inserted, the enable switch must be set to 'enabled' to start up the controller.

Requirement: Controller box enable switch status must be available to the user
Description: The current status of the controller box enable switch must be available to the user, and it must be logged in the event log when the controller box is enabled and disabled.

Requirement: Inverter on button status when controller box is disabled
Description: When the controller box is disabled it is not possible to turn on the inverter, hence the inverter on button shown in display and UPS Tuner must be "grayed out" to make this clear for the user.

Primary Actor(s)-          User.Stakeholders and InterestsUPS              :     Pre conditions-Post conditions- Main success scenario1. UPS is in any operation mode except off operation and maintenance bypass.2. Bypass is available (bypass voltage within tolerance, inverter sync to bypass, SBS ready)3. User sets the controller enable switch to 'disable'.4. UPS transfers to forced static bypass.5. Controller box can be removed (when controller box is removed UPS will transfer to emergency static bypass). Alternative scenario 11. UPS is in any operation mode except off operation and maintenance bypass..2. Bypass voltage is out of tolerance and inverter is sync to bypass (transfer to static bypass with bypass out of tolerance is allowed)3. User sets the controller enable switch to 'disable'.4. UPS transfers to forced static bypass.5. Controller box can be removed (when controller box is removed UPS will transfer to emergency static bypass).Alternative scenario 21. UPS is in any operation mode except off operation and maintenance bypass..2. Bypass voltage is out of tolerance and inverter is not sync to bypass (transfer to static bypass with bypass out of tolerance is allowed)3. User sets the controller enable switch to 'disable'.4. UPS transfers to forced static bypass with a break.5. Controller box can be removed (when controller box is removed UPS will transfer to emergency static bypass).Alternative scenario 31. UPS is in any operation mode except off operation and maintenance bypass..2. Bypass voltage is out of tolerance (transfer to static bypass with bypass out of tolerance is not allowed)3. User sets the controller enable switch to 'disable'.4. UPS transfers to off operation.5. Controller box can be removed (when controller box is removed UPS will stay in off).Alternative scenario 41. UPS is in any operation mode except off operation and maintenance bypass..2. Bypass is not available3. User sets the controller enable switch to 'disable'.4. UPS transfers to off operation.5. Controller box can be removed (when controller box is removed UPS will stay in off).Alternative scenario 51. UPS is in any operation mode except off operation and maintenance bypass..2. User sets the controller enable switch to 'disable' and removes the controller box right away3. UPS will transfer to emergency static bypass if possible or else turn off (bypass not available)Alternative scenario 61. UPS is in off operation.2. User sets the controller enable switch to 'disable'.3. The UPS stays in off operation.4. Controller box can be removed.Alternative scenario 71. UPS is in maintenance bypass.2. User sets the controller enable switch to 'disable'.3. The UPS stays in maintenance bypass.4. Controller box can be removed.- For the main success scenario and alternative scenarios 1 and 2: If controller box is disabled but not removed, and then enabled again, the UPS will return to inverter operation if possible.- For the alternative scenarios 3, 4 and 6: If controller box is disabled but not removed, and then enabled again, the UPS will stay in off operation.- For the alternative scenario 7: If controller box is disabled but not removed, and then enabled again, the UPS will stay in maintenance bypass.- While the controller box is disabled it is not possible to turn on the inverter (inverter on button will have no action).Special requirementsNA Technology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Primary Actor(s)-          User.Stakeholders and InterestsUPS              :     Pre conditions  Post conditions. Main success scenario1. UPS is in emergency static bypass2. Controller box is inserted.3. UPS transfers to forced static bypass.4. User sets the controller enable switch to 'enable'.5. UPS transfers from forced static bypass to inverter operation. Alternative scenario 11. UPS is in emergency static bypass2. Controller box is inserted.3. UPS transfers to forced static bypass.4. User sets the controller enable switch to 'enable'.5. UPS is not able to operate in inverter operation due to some reason.6. UPS stays in forced static bypass. Alternative scenario 21. UPS is in emergency static bypass2. IMB/MBB is closed.3. Controller box is inserted.4. UPS transfers to maintenance bypass.5. User sets the controller enable switch to 'enable'.6. UPS stays in maintenance bypass.Alternative scenario 31. UPS is in off operation2. Controller box is inserted.3. User sets the controller enable switch to 'enable'.4. UPS stays in off operationSpecial requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Controller box has been disabled by user

The power module  must have an enable switch which controls if the power module must be enabled or disabled. - Before the power module is removed, the enable switch must be set to 'disabled' to shut down the power module.- When the power module has been inserted, the enable switch must be set to 'enabled' to start up the power module.

When a power module is disabled, the power supply to the power module is turned off by hardware and the power module is powered down. This is not controlled by firmware.- Disabling a power module corresponds to a power module shutdown, and the UPS firmware must be able to handle this according to the requirements listed under 'Power module fault tolerance'.- Enabling a power module corresponds to powering up a power module, however the UPS firmware must be able to handle this according to the requirements listed under 'Power module hot swap' (disabling and enabling a power module corresponds to a power module swap).
See WHAT40944.

If a power module fan becomes inoperable (either not spinning at all or spinning at a too low speed) three times within less than an hour (changes between inoperable and operable) all fans must be locked at full speed and fan inoperable must be reported as an alarm.This alarm can only be cleared by rebooting (power cycling) the power module.

Requirement: User configurable UPS product family name
Description: The UPS product family name must be configurable via UPS Tuner. In case SLC is replaced by a spare part it must be possible to set the correct UPS product family name.

The tolerance of the standard measurements must be what is listed below:Voltage tolerance: Offset +/- 0.5V, reading +/- 1%Current tolerance: Offset +/- 1.5A per power module, reading +/- 3% (*)Power tolerance: Offset +/- 0.6kVA per power module, reading +/- 3% (*)Frequency tolerance: Reading +/- 0.3 HzLoad: Offset +1 / -2.Power Factor (PF): Reading +/-6% (PF must never be shown as higher than 1)Peak current tolerance: Offset +/- 1.5A per power module, reading +/- 6% (**)(*) Tolerance at loads (and charge current/power) higher than 20% of configured system size (>20% load). Below 20% load the reading is allowed to be >3%.(**) Tolerance at loads (and charge current/power) higher than 50% of configured system size (>50% load). Below 50% load the reading is allowed to be >6%. Width (time duration) of peak must be minimum 1 ms. Peaks with a time deration below 1 ms cannot be measured correctly due to the sampling rate.

With battery deep discharge enabled, the low shutdown voltage must be set at the following fixed levels (dynamic shutdown voltage level is disabled) depending on the battery type:Lead-acid: 1.6 V/cellLi-ion: 2.45 V/cellExample for lead-acid battery illustrated with blue line on below figure:{Image: 0E6BE4AC-57FC-427E-A696-C3777969BE66.bmp}
The low battery voltage shutdown level must be dynamic based on the CA discharge rate.
It must be possible for the user to configure the power rating of the installation via UPS Tuner.
Setting to configure the power rating of the installation.Possible values:Depends on product, see child requirement. Default value:Depends on product, see child requirement.

Requirement: Sparepart firmware update of live swap power module
Description: If a power module is live swapped (power module replaced while UPS is supplying the load in inverter operation or ECOnversion mode), the UPS must check the firmware version of the replaced power module, and if it is not correct according to the system firmware version, it must be firmware updated automatically without the need for user intervention.

Requirement: Power module live swap sparepart firmware update
Description: Primary Actor(s)-          User.Stakeholders and InterestsUser              : .Pre conditionsPost conditionsUPS must ensure that an inserted module is automatically firmware updated if needed before it is allowed to actively operate in the system.Main success scenario1.      UPS in inverter operation2.      A power module is inserted and the enable switch is engaged.3.      The power module boots up and performs a self-test.4.    The power module does not have the correct firmware version according to the system.5.    The power module stays inoperable.6.    The SLC initiates a sparepart firmware update and the UC updates the firmware of the given power module.7.    The sparepart firmware update of the power module completes successfully.8.    The UC allows the inserted power module to actively operate in the system.9.    The inserted power module becomes operable and participates actively in the system (transfers to inverter operation). Alternative scenariosScenario 1:1.      UPS in off operation or maintenance bypass.2.      A power module is inserted and the enable switch is engaged.3.      The power module boots up and performs a self-test.4.    The power module does not have the correct firmware version according to the system.5.    The power module stays inoperable.6.    The SLC initiates a sparepart firmware update and the UC updates the firmware of the given power module.7.    The sparepart firmware update of the power module completes successfully.8.      The UC allows the inserted power module to actively operate in the system.9.    The inserted power module becomes operable.Scenario 2:1.      UPS in ECOnversion mode2.      A power module is inserted and the enable switch is engaged.3.      The power module boots up and performs a self-test.4.    The power module does not have the correct firmware version according to the system.5.    The power module stays inoperable.6.    The SLC initiates a sparepart firmware update and the UC updates the firmware of the power module.7.    The sparepart firmware update of the power module completes successfully.8.    The UC allows the inserted power module to actively operate in the system.9.    The inserted power module becomes operable and participates actively in the system (transfers to ECOnversion mode) Scenario 3:1.      UPS in requested static bypass, forced static bypass or ECO mode.2.      A power module is inserted and the enable switch is engaged.3.      The power module boots up and performs a self-test.4.    The power module does not have the correct firmware version according to the system.5.    The power module stays inoperable.6.    The SLC initiates a sparepart firmware update and the UC updates the firmware of the power module.7.    The sparepart firmware update of the power module completes successfully.8.    The UC allows the inserted power module to actively operate in the system.9.    The inserted power module becomes operable.

Requirement: Hysteresis of installation overload warning alarm
Description: The installation overload warning alarm must have an hysteresis so that:- The alarm is activated when the output load on the UPS exceeds the value of the configured installation power rating by +10% or maximum 50kW which ever comes first.- The alarm is deactived when the output load on the UPS decreases down to the value of the configured installation power rating.

At start-up self-test the UC must check if any surveillance detected faults are present, and if so, fail the self-test.The surveillance detected faults include:- UC internal PSU inoperable- UC ADC is not working correctly
If a battery self-test has not completed within 1 hour, for example due to very low output load on the UPS, it must automatically exit.
The automatic boost charging mode must be time limited and the time must start counting from when the charger exits current limitation.
The maximum automatic boost charge time limit must be equal to either the user configured time + 2 hours, or 8 hours whatever is lowest, and must be counting from when boost charge is entered.

Requirement: Exit automatic boost charge if charger is not in current limitation after a certain time
Description: To avoid boost charging fully charged batteries the UPS must exit automatic boost charging mode if the charger is not in current limitation within the first minute of boost charging.

SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: Power module shall support battery configurations with and without midpoint.The defined voltage levels are for the full battery string.A battery solution with midpoint shall be symmetrical for both sides.  Acceptable battery configurations for ?25kW (200-220V) output power:System voltage configuration200V208V220VNominal output power?25kWNominal battery voltage supported384V-480V (32-40, 12V blocks)  Maximum charge voltage 600V  Minimum end-of-discharge voltage (100% load) 307V        Acceptable battery configurations for 50kW (380-480V) output power:System voltage configuration380V400V415V440V480VNominal output power50kWNominal battery voltage supported480V-576V (40-48, 12V blocks)Maximum charge voltage 720VMinimum end-of-discharge voltage (100% load) 384VAcceptable battery configurations for ?40kW (380-480V)utput power:System voltage configuration380V400V415V440V480VNominal output power?40kWNominal battery voltage supported384V-576V (32-48 blocks, 12V blocks)Maximum charge voltage 720VMinimum end-of-discharge voltage (100% load) 307VNote:Other battery types might be supported if the charge/discharge voltages are within the supported range. Constraints apply to the minimum battery voltage during overload in battery operation. This shall be considered during evaluation of alternative energy storage solutions. The battery voltage supported is linear related to the Nominal Output power, so any derating of this will increase the support for less batteries. IE a nominal output of 43kW will give suppport for 35 Blocks of battery. Minimum allowable battery count is 32 blocks 12V

Description: The battery current limiter is only intended to limit the absolute maximum DC battery current in PM (not considering ripple). Other constraints, such as system or battery size might limit the current further.Set PM battery current limiter to 196A (this shall be the maximum Iref that can be requested)Furthermore, it must be ensured that below current levels / time durations are not exceeded:  * Up to 127A is allowed continueusly  * Between 127A and 160A is allowed for 60 seconds. A 1:5 counter shall be implemented --> 60s above the limit requires 5min "cool off" time (below 127A).  * Above 160A is allowed for 4 seconds. A 1:20 counter shall be implemented --> 4s above the limit requires 80s "cool off" time (below 127A).When one of the overload timers reach their limit, power module shall turn off inverter and report "Shutdown due to high battery current".  Above limitations are valid for all voltage ratings and also for software de-rated versions.
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: The charging current is ultimately limited by the maximum power module charger current as defined below.Other constraints, such as available power from PFC, battery size and other system limitations might limit the charge power to a lower level.  The maximum charge current must be limited according to below table:Charger current limiter*System configuration200V208V220V380V400V415V440V480V25kW (200-220V) / 50kW (400-480V) rating42A70A20kW (200-220V) / 40kW (400-480V) rating34A56A15kW (200-220V) / 30kW (400-480V) rating26A42A10kW (200-220V) / 20kW (400-480V) rating17A28A*The current limiter is set to limit the available charging power to 80% of nominal output power at the highest nominal battery voltage. Examples: * 50kW PM (400-480V) is able to charge with 50kW x 80% / 576V =70A (rounded up to whole number)  * 25kW PM (200-220V) is able to charge with 25kW x 80% / 480V =42A (rounded up to whole number)_______________________________________________________________________________________________Calculations to support during verification process:Based on the PFC input current/power limiter, below charging power is available at full load:         Available charging power at 100% load vs. mains voltage (25/50kW PM)*System configuration200V208V220V380V400V415V440V480VNominal output power25kW50kWAvailable charging power at 100% load, high mains (+15%)5.4kW5.4kW5.5kW11.6kW11.7kW11.8kW11.8kW12.0kWAvailable charging power at 100% load, nominal mains4.9kW5.4kW5.5kW7.6kW10.7kW11.8kW11.8kW12.0kWAvailable charging power at 100% load, low mains (-15%)0.5kW0.9kW0.9kW0.0kW1.7kW2.5kW2.6kW2.7kW*Above values should be considered a guideline, since actual UPS efficiency will impact the values slightly    Based on the charger current limiter, below charging power is available at < 15% load: Available charging power at < 15% load and (-15 to +15% mains) vs. battery voltageSystem configuration200V208V220V380V400V415V440V480VNominal output power25kW50kW384V battery voltage (32 blocks)16.1kW16.1kW16.1kWONLY SUPPORTED FOR ?40kW PM RATING480V battery voltage (40 blocks)20.2kW20.2kW20.2kW33.6kW33.6kW33.6kW33.6kW33.6kW576V battery voltage (48 blocks)NOT SUPPORTED40.3kW40.3kW40.3kW40.3kW40.3kW

When DC-bus level is below limit, switching is again allowed (from next 24kHz switching cycle).  System voltage setting200V208V220V380V400V415V440V480VNominal output power25kW50kWBooster/charger DC-bus high shutdown level 390V390V390V450V450V460V470V480V
