Description: A peak current limiter must be implemented, in order to protect the hardware in case of failures.Peak current limiter must run in FPGA and use the current measurement which is sampled at 192kHz.The FW must immediately stop booster/charger switching if a single current measurement is above the limit defined below.When the current falls below the peak current limit, switching is again allowed (starting from next 24kHz switch cycle).Software de-rated versions shall use same limits.Battery boosterSet battery booster peak current limit to 304A(Maximum DC battery current is 196A. At 420V battery voltage (210V per side), 422V DC-bus and 196A, the peak inductor current is simulated to 290A. 5% margin is added to allow for variations in inductor DC-bias performance and temperature degradation (290A x 105% = 304A))* Battery charger   Set battery charger peak current limit to 151A(Maximum DC battery charge current is 70A. At 470V battery voltage (235V per side), 470V DC-bus and 70A, the peak inductor current is simulated to 108A. 40% margin is added to allow for variations in inductor DC-bias performance and temperature degradation: 108A x 140% = 151A))*  *The DC-DC converter current measurement range is up to 311A when used for booster and 155A when used for charger (limited by ADC), so peak current limits shall be below these levels. If any of the peak current limits are exceeded one or more times for 100 consecutive 1ms intervals, the charger/booster shall immediately be turned off.
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich
Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: Battery relay shall be closed if all below criterias are fulfilled: 1. Pre-charge complete*                                                                    2. NOT VQDMainsFault  OR  NOT VqdBattFault                      3. BATT_VOL_POS_PRI - BATT_VOL_NEG_PRI > 100V **         4. BATT_VOL_POS_PRI > 30V **         5. BATT_VOL_NEG_PRI < -30V **Immediately when the battery relay is requested to close, a voltage tracking function shall be started to ensure that the voltage across the relays are within below defined limits: * BATT_VOL_POS_PRI < BATT_VOL_POS +50V  AND  BATT_VOL_POS_PRI > BATT_VOL_POS -50V (voltages should be within 50V of each other) *** * BATT_VOL_NEG_PRI > BATT_VOL_NEG -50V  AND  BATT_VOL_NEG_PRI < BATT_VOL_NEG +50V (voltages should be within 50V of each other) ***___________________________________________________________________________________________________*Criteria for preChgComplete *  DC_BUS_VOL_POS  + 60V > MAINS1_VOL_Lx_PRI for more than 100ms contineous         AND *  DC_BUS_VOL_NEG - 60V < MAINS1_VOL_Lx_PRI for more than 100ms contineous          AND *  DC_BUS_VOL_POS  + 30V >  BATT_VOL_POS_PRI  for more than 100ms contineous        AND *  DC_BUS_VOL_NEG - 30V < BATT_VOL_NEG_PRI for more than 100ms contineous        ** The battery relay must only be allowed to be closed when the measured battery voltage is sufficiently high.  This is to prevent blown power module in case of reverse polarity on batteries (battery voltage of correct polarity must be present before relay is closed), and also to avoid DC voltage on the battery terminals even though the charger is off (linked to JIRA issue ALPHA-1393).A total battery voltage of 100V is chosen as limit, as this is the lowest voltage that power module PSU is able to start from.Each side of the battery should be more than 30V - this requirement is to ensure that there are no grounding / termination fault on the battery.  *** ´The voltage across each battery realy may not exceed 50V at the time where relay is closed. This is to avoid a large inrush current in the battery filter capacitors which may damage the battery relays. To ensure this will require "tracking" of the primary side battery voltage. The battery booster will have to be operated in order to lower the BATT_VOL_POS/NEG voltages to a sufficient level. The traching shall be started once the close criterias 1-5 are fulfilled, and relay should be requested to close simultanious with the start of the tracker function (the ~5ms it takes for the relay to close is more than enough for the voltage tracking to be completed).
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: When all of below criterias are fulfilled: * Battery relay already closed  * All converters are off (Inverter, PFC, battery charger, battery booster)  * DC_BUS_VOL_POS + |DC_BUS_VOL_NEG| < (Low battery shutdown)  Do 1. Prevent all converters from turning on until step 8.   2. Stop HF_SUPPLY  3. Wait 50ms  4. Open battery relay  5. Prevent battery relay from closing again for the next 10 seconds. When the 10 seconds have passed, the normal turn-on criterias still have to be fulfilled before closing  6. Wait 100ms  7. Start HF_SUPPLY again  8. Allow all converters to turn on again
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: A survaillance function must be implemented for the positive and negative side battery converter. The survaillance shall compare the value of BATT_CUR__xxx_REF with the measured value of BATT_CUR_xxx for both sides individually.The value for the measured current shall be calculated based on the averaged current (average of last 8 sample points at 192kHz), in order to cancel out the ripple current.   The maximum allowed difference between the reference and the measured current is 10A.If the values differs with 10A or more for 1s consecutive, shut down the Charger/Booster.  The function shall be identical for software de-rated versions (same limit).
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Requirement: Current compensation factor for display reading
Description: This requirement describes a compensation factor which shall be added to the measured power module input current for the purpose of RMS input current and peak input current calculation. RMS currents and peak currents are used for display readings, and this requierement is related to ALPHA-5163 and ALPHA-3679 issues. Furthermore, the size of the input filter capacitor is defined, which shall be used to calculate the filter current, which shall be added to measured input current.Compensation factor:The measured power module input current used for RMS current calculation and peak current calculation shall be multiplied with a factor of 1.04. This is to compensate for magnetic fields in the 50kW power module that affects the current sensor.Note 1: This factor shall only be added for RMS and peak current calculation purpose and shall not be used for regulation purpose, input current limiter etc.Note 2: The factor shall only be added for the 50kW power module since the 20kW power module does not have the same effect.Filter current compensation:To compensate for the input filter current internally in the power module (which is not measured by the current sensor in the power module), the instantaneous filter current shall be calculated and added to the measured current. Thereby the filter current will be included in the RMS calculation and the peak current calculation.The size of the input filter capacitance in each power module is 31µF.Note 1: The detailed method for calculation of instantaneous filter current is out of scope of this requirement, but a calculation similar to the example shown below shall be implemented.Note 2: The filter current will only be present when the backfeed contactor is closed. Therefore it shall be ensured that the filter current is only included when the backfeed contactor is closed._____________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________Example of filter current calculation (for illustrative purpose only):{Image: F3CCAB37-8276-4C2A-883E-978658A22926.bmp}
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: The DC-bus setpoint will be the maximum value of multiple inputs such as:-System voltage configuration-Battery voltage-Peak AC input voltage as defined belowBesides the nominal setpoint, the PFC will also have a maximum DC-bus / shutdown level for protection. The DC-bus should be regulated according to below figure*.  Up to 392V peak (277VRMS), the DC-bus headroom should be 30V.Between 392V peak and 450V peak, the headroom should be linearly reduced from 30V to 10V.  Additional 5V shall be added at sync error**.The maximum allowed DC-bus setpoint, regardless of all inputs is defined below: System voltage200V208V 220V 380V 400V 415V 440V 480V  Max DC-bus setpoint340V340V340V 400V410V420V440V460V DC-bus shall be controlled based on the measured peak AC voltage for each phase with respect to power module Neutral/midpoint and not from a phase-phase measurement, according to HOW32755.* In situations where both the charger and the inverter are off, the DC-bus shall not be regulated based on Peak AC input voltage (linked to AGILIS-3842 Jira issue).** Sync error is when the output is not synced with Mains1, Mains2 or an external source.{Image: 952B28B8-B9AA-4727-A075-A38191D7821B.bmp}
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Requirement: Input voltage measurement for DC setpoint
Description: It is important to control DC-bus based on the measured peak AC voltage for each phase with respect to power module Neutral and not from a phase-phase measurement.
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: A protection feature must be implemented in FW, immediately disabling all PFC switching if below DC-bus levels are exceeded for either the positive or negative DC-bus. Must be executed at at least 6kHz.When levels are exceeded, the backfeed contactor shall open according to HOW32757, and UPS shall go to battery operation or bypass. System voltage setting200V208V220V380V400V415V440V480VNominal output power25kW50kWPFC DC-bus high shutdown level 390V390V390V450V450V460V470V480V
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: A peak current limiter must be implemented, in order to protect the hardware in case of failures.Peak current limiter must run in FPGA and use the current measurement which is sampled at 192kHz.The FW must immediately stop PFC switching if a single current measurement is above the limit defined below.When the current falls below the peak current limit, switching is again allowed (starting from next 24kHz switch cycle). Set PFC peak current limit to 230A(peak AC input current = 129A + up to 46A ripple = 175A30% margin is added: 175A x 130% ~ 230A The 230A peak current shutdown limit is valid for all system voltage configurations and also for software de-rated power modules.If the peak current limit is exceeded one or more times for 3 consecutive 1ms intervals, the PFC shall immediately be turned off and backfeed contactor shall be opened (see below example). Peak current detected:                    x    x          x             x                                                      x                          Do not turn off PFC (peak current limit not exceeded in 3 concecutive 1ms intervals)|------1ms------|------1ms------|------1ms------|------1ms------|                    Peak current detected:                    x                         x        x               x                                                             Turn off PFC (peak current limit exceeded one or more times in 3 concecutive 1ms intervals)|------1ms------|------1ms------|------1ms------|------1ms------|
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: A survaillance function must be implemented for each input phase which can detect if the measured current is significantly smaller than the current reference.Note: Linked to issue (ALPHA-2733) where PFC draws current on only two phases with no warning in log or display. The survellance function is implemented as shown below: IF(PfcCurRefLx > 20A OR PfcCurRefLx < -20A)IF(|Mains1CurLx| < 10A)Count up by 5ELSECount down by 1 When the counter reaches a value corresponding to ~600ms, the PFC is shut down.If 3 failures occur within 90s, the PFC is locked.  The function shall be identical for software de-rated versions (same limits).
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich
Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: Mains 1 (backfeed contactor) shall be closed if below criterias are fulfilled:  * PreChgComplete*                                                                               AND * NOT SurvPfcShutdown                                                                       AND            * NOT VqdMainsFault (rms,wave,freq,NeuDisp) for 3s continuously     After backfeed is requested to close, a 60ms delay must be added before PFC starts switching, to compensate for the mechanical delay in the contactor according to HOW32733. ____________________________________________________________________________________*Criteria for preChgComplete   *  DC_BUS_VOL_POS  + 60V > MAINS1_VOL_Lx_PRI for more than 100ms contineous          AND * |DC_BUS_VOL_NEG| + 60V > MAINS1_VOL_Lx_PRI for more than 100ms contineous          AND *  DC_BUS_VOL_POS  + 30V >  BATT_VOL_POS_PRI  for more than 100ms contineous         AND * |DC_BUS_VOL_NEG| + 30V > |BATT_VOL_NEG_PRI| for more than 100ms contineous
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: Mains 1 (backfeed contactor) shall be opened if one or more of the following criterias are fulfilled: * SurvPfcShutdown*                                                            OR  * VqdMainsFault (rms,wave,freq,NeuDisp)                                                                                              * SurvPfcShutdown * PFC peak current limiter  * PFC DC-bus high shutdown  * PFC input current imbalance
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: The backfeed protection is realized with relay with a mechanical operation time.Operating times for Omron G7EB-1A / Zettler AZSR190T backfeed relay (Used in Alpha 2.2 PM update):Open time: Max 10msClose time: Max 40msOperating times for LC1D65A6BD backfeed contactor (initially used in 0G-PM50KD):16...24 ms opening42.5...57.5 ms closingSince LC1D65A6BD has longer open/close times, these should be used in FW. No changes required when changing to new relay type.
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich
Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: Crest factor should be set to 2.5 and the level must be set individually for each system voltage configuration as defined below.The "Peak output current out of PM" shall be the  maximum Iref that can be set in regulation.System voltage configuration200V208V220V380V400V415V440V480VNominal output power25kW50kWNominal RMS output current72,2A69,4A65,6A76,0A72,2A69,6A65,6A60,1APeak output current out of PM180,4A173,5A164,0A189,9A180,4A173,9A164,0A150,4ASoftware de-rated versions must be downscaled accordingly (always nominal RMS output current x 2.5)
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: A peak current limiter must be implemented, in order to protect the hardware in case of failures/overcurrents.The peak current limiter must run in FPGA and use the fast current measurement which is sampled at 192kHz.There will be two shutdown levels: Level 1 which is based on the actual measured current, and level 2 which is based on an digital output from the hall sensor (active low when I > ~440A).The peak current limiter must run individually for each phase.For software de-rated power modules, keep the same peak current shutdown levels as defined below for the 50kW PM.          System voltage configuration200V208V220V380V400V415V440V480VNominal output power25kW50kWLevel 1 peak current shutdown based on INV_CUR_Lx measurement360A360A360A360A360A360A300A275ALevel 2 peak current shutdown based on INV_CUR_Lx_OCD_ACT_L signal440A +/- 10% (hardware defined by LEM HO-150-NP hall sensor)If a positive peak current is measured (Level 1), turn off S5 and S7 IGBTs immediately for the specific phase. When the measured current falls below the peak current threshold, switching is again allowed, starting from next 24kHz switch cycle.If a negative peak current is measured (Level 1), turn off S6 and S8 IGBTs immediately for the specific phase. When the measured current falls below the peak current threshold, switching is again allowed, starting from next 24kHz switch cycle. If a positive or negative peak current is already measured (Level 1) AND INV_CUR_L1_OCD_ACT_L (Level 2) goes LOW, then immediately turn off the remaining IGBT's so that S5,S6,S7,S8 are off for the specific phase. When either the Level 1 or the Level 2 fault is cleared , switching is again allowed, starting from next 24kHz switch cycle.If only a Level 2 fault occurs while a Level 1 fault is not present, do nothing. The intended behavior is summarized in below truth table: Truth table   Level 1Level 2 S5 IGBTS6 IGBTS7 IGBTS8 IGBT Positive current above threshold HIGHOFF OFF  Negative peak current HIGH OFF OFF Positive peak current LOWOFFOFFOFFOFF Negative peak current LOWOFFOFFOFFOFFBelow Level 1 threshold HIGH    Below Level 1 threshold LOW     The level 2 fault signal is held LOW for ~1ms by the hall sensor. Thereby a level 1 fault can be cleared while a level 2 fault is still present. In this case, if the level 1 threshold is again exceeded (while a level 2 fault is already present), it is important to ensure that all four IGBTs are not just turned off at the same time.There must be a ~500ns delay in the turn-off sequence, so that e.g. S5/S7 are turned off first (if a positive peak current is measured) and then the reamining switches S6/S8 are turned off ~500ns later.  If a failure is detected one or more times for 3 consecutive 1ms intervals, the inverter shall be turned off  (see below example). Both a Level 1 AND a Level 2 failure must be present at the same time before it is counted as a failure. The surveillance must run individually on each phase.  Peak current detected:                    x    x          x             x                                                      x                          Do not turn off inverter (a failure is not detected in 3 consecutive 1ms intervals)  |------1ms------|------1ms------|------1ms------|------1ms------|                    Peak current detected:                    x                         x        x               x                                                             Turn off inverter (a failure is detected in 3 consecutive 1ms intervals)|------1ms------|------1ms------|------1ms------|------1ms------|
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: The DC-bus setpoint will be the maximum value of multiple inputs such as:-System voltage configuration-Battery voltage-Peak AC input voltage- Vout (in bypass only)  DC-bus setpoint1. DC-bus setpoint should be System voltage configuration (peak voltage) + 30VExample: For a 400V system configuration: 231VRMS x SQRT(2) +30V = 357V DC2. When system is in Bypass (or requested to transfer to bypass): DC-bus setpoint should be peak measured output voltage (Phase-Neutral) + 20V3. Sync error*:  + Additional 5VMaximum allowed DC-bus setpoint is 460V according to HOW32718*Sync error is when the output is not synced with Mains1, Mains2 or an external source.
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: DC-bus high shutdown level A protection feature must be implemented in FW, immediately disabling all Inverter switching if below DC-bus levels are exceeded for either the positive or negative DC-bus. Must be executed with at least 6kHz.The survaillance must run individually on each DC-bus. * When Inverter DC-bus shutdown level 1 is exceeded, the inverter current reference must be limited to a crest factor of 1.4 and if level 1 is exceeded for more than 300ms consequtive, switching shall be stopped and inverter shall be shut down.  * When Inverter DC-bus shutdown level 2 is exceeded, switching shall immediately be stopped and inverter shall be shut down.System voltage setting200V208V220V380V400V415V440V480VNominal output power25kW50kWNominal inverter DC-bus shutdown level (25°C heatsink temp)480V480V480V480V480V480V490V500V Temperature compensation based on measured heatsink temperature The inverter DC-bus shutdown level should be varaible, based on the coldest measured heatsink temperature. This is to compensate for actual breakdown voltage of the IGBTs, which changes with temperature.Temperature compensation shall only affect the inverter shutdown limit - not the other converters. Change the DC-bus shutdown level with 0.5V/°C (based on coldest measured heatsink temperature) as shown in figure below.Outer limits: 5°C to 45°C or -10V to +10V maximum deviation from the nominal shutdown levelExample: At 440V system voltage, the nominal DC-bus shutdown level at 25°C heatsink temp is 490V. At ?5°C heatsink temp. the shutdown level will be 480V. At ?45°C heatsink temp. the shutdown level will be 500V.{Image: C9AC3802-4D8A-4C43-88FA-28BBFA4491BF.bmp}
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: System voltage setting200V208V220V380V400V415V440V480VNominal output power25kW50kWOverload NORMAL operation, 10 Minutes125%Overload NORMAL operation, 60 Seconds150%Overload NORMAL/BATTERY operation, <100 ms*250%Overload BATTERY operation, 60 Seconds125%125% @ Vbatt ? 408V**  Overload BATTERY operation, 3 Seconds150%150% @ Vbatt ? 403V****     Given by settling time in RMS control loop**   Battery voltage must be ? 408V during 125% overload, when module is configured for 50kW output power (due to battery current limiter). Description: Inverter relay shall be closed if below criterias are fulfilled: * NOT Inverter survaillance shutdown  * Inverter selftest passed  * Inverter ON                                                                  Before the relay is closed, the inverter shall always synchronize with the output voltage, if output voltage is already present.
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: Inverter relay shall be opened if one or more of below criterias are fulfilled: * Inverter survaillance shutdown*  * Single UPS operation mode set to OFF**  * Parallel UPS operation mode set to OFF or static switch standby*** Inverter survaillance shutdown shall include at least:  * Inverter high DC-bus shutdown           * Inverter peak current limiter            * Output current imbalance                      * Inverter low DC-bus shutdown          ** This is partly to avoid DC on output in situations where the inverter is off and the output is left floating, and partly to avoid large capacitive load from the PM output filter connected to the output in situations where the inverter is off. Linked to JIRA issue ALPHA-1393. In cases of inverter relay open is caused by inverter surveillance fault the inverter converter must stop switching prior to opening the relay.In situations where the inverter can operate during inverter relay open the voltage level across the inverter relay must be synchronized.These situations are:-        UPS operation mode set to off.-        Lost communication with UC.
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: A survaillance function must be implemented for each inverter output phase. The survaillance shall compare the RMS value of INV_CUR_REF_Lx with the RMS value of INV_CUR_Lx for each phase.The RMS value for the measured current shall be calculated based on the averaged current (average of last 8 sample points at 192kHz), in order to cancel out the ripple current.    The maximum allowed difference between the reference and the measured current is 10A.If the values differs with 10A RMS or more for 1s consecutive, shut down the Inverter.  The function shall be identical for software de-rated versions (same limit).
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: The FAN PWM duty-cycle is determined as the maximum of five seperate inputs: * Speed vs. max RMS current * Speed vs. max heatsink temperature * Minimum duty-cycle  * FAN speed survaillance * Start and stop sequence Speed vs. max RMS current%duty_vs_RMS_max = A(x+k*Ta)^2 + B(x+k*Ta) + C  Where A, B, C and k are fixed parameters and x and Ta are variables.A = 0.004B = 0C = 15k = 1x = maximum RMS current in any converter (PFC, INV, battery charger/booster)Ta = Ambient temperature [degC] (AIR_INLET_TEMP_SNS) The function is plotted below: {Image: FE5E5B5C-A219-45D4-83E6-BE222C00BD00.bmp}
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: The FAN PWM duty-cycle is determined as the maximum of five seperate inputs: * Speed vs. max RMS current * Speed vs. max heatsink temperature * Minimum duty-cycle * FAN speed survaillance * Start and stop sequenceSpeed vs. max heatsink temperature%duty_vs_Th_max = T2*Th + T1Where T1 and T2 are fixed parameters and Th is variable.T1 = -50T2 = 2Th = Maximum heatsink temperature [degC] - (average value over last 5s to cancel noise)The function is plotted below:{Image: 7CDB2127-06FB-482F-817F-C51A520DCBD6.bmp} Since this is a closed loop regulation, there is a risk of instability in the system (due to measurement delay from heatsink to temperature sensor).  To slow down the responce, it shall be ensured that the FAN speed is allowed to increase instantly when the heatsink temperature increases, whereas FAN speed is only allowed to drop by a rate of 0.1% per second.
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: The FAN PWM duty-cycle is determined as the maximum of five seperate inputs: * Speed vs. max RMS current * Speed vs. max heatsink temperature * Minimum duty-cycle * FAN speed survaillance * Start and stop sequence  Minimum duty-cycle The minimum allowed FAN duty-cycle at any time shall be 20%.
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: The FAN PWM duty-cycle is determined as the maximum of five seperate inputs:  * Speed vs. max RMS current * Speed vs. max heatsink temperature * Minimum duty-cycle * FAN speed survaillance * Start and stop sequence FAN speed survaillanceThe used FAN, p/n 490-9148 has a guaranteed performance down to 30% duty-cycle.It will be able to operate down to a lower duty-cycle of 20% as shown below, once it is already spinning: {Image: 8FEE07A2-29AB-4AF6-9FCA-A526ACE5E0DB.bmp}Down to 20% duty-cycle can be acceptable at very low load, or at low ambient temperature.To avoid that the FANs unintentionally stop due to wear-out, a survaillance function must be implemented.Survaillance 1 (duty-cycle < 30%):IF          FAN duty-cycle < 30%           AND           min measured FAN Tacho deviates more than 35% from expected value for 10s consecutiveTHEN          Increase minimum FAN duty-cycle to 30%.        The survaillance shall use the lowest measured FAN Tacho value for the 3 FANs. If the lowest Tacho value deviates with more than 35% from expected value (based on curve fit) for 10s consecutive, minimum duty-cycle setpoint shall be increased to 30% (so that the minimum FAN speed cannot become lower than 30% again until PM is power cycled).No warning or log entry shall be made for this.  Survaillance 2 (duty-cycle ? 30%): IF          FAN duty-cycle ? 30%           AND           min measured FAN Tacho deviates more than 25% from expected value for 10s consecutive THEN          Increase FAN duty-cycle to 100% and report FAN failure. If the FAN RPM at 100% duty-cycle becomes OK again (within 25% deviation), duty-cycle is allowed to return back to the original setpoint two times. On the third time, occuring within 1 hour, duty-cycle shall be locked at 100% until next time PM is power cycled.
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: The FAN PWM duty-cycle is determined as the maximum of five seperate inputs:  * Speed vs. max RMS current * Speed vs. max heatsink temperature * Minimum duty-cycle * FAN speed survaillance * Start and stop sequenceStart and stop sequenceDuring initial power module power-up, it shall be ensured that FANs only start when the DC-bus is sufficiently high (to allow PM startup at very low Mains), and furthermore, a sufficiently high PWM duty-cycle shall initially be set to ensure that FANs start spinning correctlty.FANs shall be started when one or more of below criterias are fulfilled: * Mains 1 Backfeed contactor closed                                                                        * Battery relay closed                                                                                                * Power module controller has been powered for more than 3 minutes consecutive, regardless of selftest status The FANs shall be started/enabled with the FAN_EN digital output.  FAN duty-cycle during startup: * Once the FANs are requested to start up (as described above), the PWM duty-cycle shall be set to minimum 50% for the first 10s (to ensure start-up)After the first 10s, FAN speed shall be controlled based on other inputs such as max RMS current / max heatsink temperature as separately defined.  FANs shall be stopped when: * Once the FANs are powered up, they shall not be stopped again (they will only stop once the PM PSU dies).
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich
Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: The 50kW power module contains 16 heatsink temperature sensors. The used sensor is a 10k? NTC thermistor, NTCLE413E2103F---L.The sampled voltage vs. temperature is defined below. Sufficient filtering / averaging shall be implemented to cancel out noise. Measurement range shall be between -20C and +125CNTCLE413E2103F---LB25/85 (K): 3435TemperatureR_NTC, datasheetV_ADC-20°C68260 ?0.5815V-15°C53762 ?0.7154V-10°C42636 ?0.8690V-5°C34038 ?1.0418V0°C27348 ?1.2325V5°C22108 ?1.4388V10°C17979 ?1.6574V15°C14706 ?1.8843V20°C12094 ?2.1155V25°C10000 ?2.3462V30°C8311 ?2.5725V35°C6941 ?2.7909V40°C5825 ?2.9982V45°C4911 ?3.1925V50°C4158 ?3.3723V55°C3536 ?3.5370V60°C3020 ?3.6865V65°C2589 ?3.8213V70°C2228 ?3.9419V75°C1925 ?4.0495V80°C1668 ?4.1449V85°C1451 ?4.2294V90°C1267 ?4.3040V95°C1109 ?4.3698V100°C974 ?4.4277V105°C858 ?4.4788V110°C752 ?4.5268V115°C651 ?4.5730V120°C551 ?4.6201V125°C445 ?4.6709V{Image: 6548DF9C-0661-45B8-A4FF-502AFE2A9F04.bmp}High temperature warning: The power module shall report a high temperature warning if the hottest heatsink exceeds 80degC. High temperature shutdown: The power module shall turn off if the hottest heatsink temperature exceeds 90degC.         If the hottest heatsink temperature drops below 80degC for 30s, it is allowed to turn back on again.If three shutdowns occur within one hour, the PM shall be locked at the third event (only cleared when the PM is power cycled).  Temperature sensor fault detection: * If up to four sensors report either -20C (lower measurement limit) or +125C temperature (upper measurement limit), the specific sensors shall be ignored and the module shall report sensor error (warning only).  * If five or more sensors report either -20C (lower measurement limit) or +125C temperature (upper measurement limit), the module shall report “Power Module temperature sensor board inoperable”. Module shall shut down.
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: A temperature sensor is placed in the front of the power module interface board (close to the FANs). Temperature will be very close to the actual inlet temperature.The sense signal is named AIR_INLET_TEMP_SNS.Three active part numbers are on AML (p/n 1PRT000069). Description: An Alpha 2.2 120-150kW systems must be populated with "Alpha 2.2" or newer 50kW PM's. Refer to HOW39921 for an overview of PM revisions.If an Alpha 2.2 120-150kW system is being populated with one or more "old" power modules (earlier than Alpha 2.2 revision), the customer should be warned about it through an alarm. System is allowed to operate. Proposed alarm text:"Incompatible Power Module revision"  Justification:A system with 3x50kW old PM's in parallel cannot pass class C2 EMC limits. Customer should be warned about an illegal configuration. Old (Alpha 1) and new (Alpha 2.2) PM's can only be distinguished through PCB revision resistors or serial number as they have same SKU number.
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: The default UPS name must be formatted as follows:[Product name] [UPS power rating]where:- [Product name] is ""Galaxy VL""- [UPS power rating] is the nominal power rating of the UPS. For a scalable UPS this value must be based on the actual number of power modules populated in the UPS.

Primary Actor(s)-          User.-          UPS.Stakeholders and InterestsUser              : Wants to have the load protected and be informed of any errors in the system.UPS              : Wants to avoid damaging the load.Pre conditionsThe UPS is powered on.Post conditionsThe load is protected from damage due to a DC voltage.Main success scenario 1. UPS is running in inverter operation.  2. Mains 2 within tolerance.  3. UPS detects a DC voltage on the output.  4. System transfers to forced static bypass operation.  5. UPS alarms the user about the error. Alternative scenariosScenario 1: 1. UPS is running in inverter operation.  2. Mains 2 not available or static bypass swich faulty.  3. UPS detects a DC voltage on the output.  4. System turns off and drops the load.  5. UPS alarms the user about the error Scenario 2: 1. UPS is running in requested static bypass operation.  2. UPS detects a DC voltage on the output.  3. UPS transfers to inverter operation.  4. UPS alarms the user about the error (UPS transfers back to inverter operation caused by a output waveform out of tolerance as this detector is faster than the DC on output detector. This means there will be no DC voltage detected on output alarm but only the output waveform out of tolerance alarm).  Scenario 3: 1. UPS is running in forced or emergency static bypass operation.  2. UPS detects a DC voltage on the output.  3. UPS turns off and drops the load.  4. UPS alarms the user about the error Scenario 4: 1. UPS is running in inverter operation.  2. Mains 2 out of tolerance.  3. UPS detects a DC voltage on the output.  4. System transfers to forced static bypass operation.  5. UPS alarms the user about the error.   Special requirementsDC voltage means voltage coming from shorted power circuit causing DC bus voltage on output or half wave due to one thyristor not conductingTechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Requirement: Battery self-test aborted due to timeout
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Battery self-test has been aborted due to timeout

Requirement: Parallel breaker status inconsistency no longer detected
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text:Description: The status all common parallel breakers is detected to be the same on all parallel UPS

The inverter shall be turned off if the DC-bus drops 25V below the nominal peak output voltage for 20ms consecutive. Furthermore the inverter relay shall be opened.If the PFC is off (PFC and battery booster), the inverter shall be turned off immediately once the DC-bus drops 25V below the nominal peak output voltage.Levels are defined in below table for each system voltage.System voltageLow DC-bus shutdown level200V138V208V145V220V155V380V285V400V302V415V314V440V334V480V367V Justification:The inverter has to be turned off in a controlled manner in situations where the DC-bus is dropping below the level needed for output voltage generation.This could be e.g. if batteries are not available and the load exceeds the input power (PFC in current limiter). It could also be if mains is unavailable and batteries becomes fully discharged (no sources available).
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Requirement: Enabling NPI test mode via Abus CAN interface
Description: It must be possible to enable and disable NPI test mode by sending a telegram on the Abus CAN interface but only using test equipment (device type) and if the serial number of the UPS is SJxxxxxxxx.

Requirement: Charge power limitation due to load and temperature
Description: The maximum charge power must be limited according to the output load on the UPS and the ambient temperature.At an inverter load from 40% to 100%, the charger must be limited from 80% to 20% of the system rating.In case of high ambient temperature (>40°C) at an inverter load from 20% to 80%, the charger must be limited from 80% to 20% of system rating.The relation between maximum charge power, output load and ambient temperature is illustrated below:{Image: 2DD88FFE-7228-498B-B15A-D1C78DF29027.bmp}
The temperature compensated charge voltage level must be adjusted according to NiCd battery type:NiCd: Float charge: -2.0 mV/cell pr. degree CBoost charge: -2.0 mV/cell pr. degree C

Requirement: ECOnversion minimum output load power factor
Description: A minimum output load power factor of 0.5 on each phase is required before the UPS is allowed to transfer to ECOnversion.When in ECOnversion, the UPS must transfer back to inverter operation if the output load power factor drops below 0.4, on one or more of the phases.

Requirement: UPS output load power factor is high enough to allow ECOnversion
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: UPS output load power factor is high enough to allow ECOnversion

Requirement: UPS output load power factor is too low to allow ECOnversion
Description: Type: AlarmSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: Ensure UPS output load power factor is high enough or disable ECOnversionDescription: UPS output load power factor is too low to allow ECOnversion

New 0G-PM50KD2 SKU number is used to identify 2. generation 50kW PM with relay backfeed and improved EMI performance.Alpha 1 and all Bravo systems can operate with old/new version and combination of old and new versionAn Alpha 2.2 120-150kW and Charlie GVL systems must be populated with "0G-PM50KD2" (Alpha 2.2) or newer 50kW PM's. Refer to "Board revision tracking" requirement for an overview of PM revisions. If a Charlie system is being populated with one or more "old" power modules (earlier than Alpha 2.2 revision), the user must be warned about it through an alarm only and system is allowed to start-up and operate. If an Alpha 2 system is being populated with one or more "old" power modules (earlier than Alpha 2.2 revision), the user should not be warned about it.Justification:A GVL system prepopulated with 4xPM 2nd. generation and additional added  6xPM old version cannot pass class C2 EMC limits. Customer should be warned about an illegal configuration.A GVS Alpha2.2 system prepopulated with 1xPM 2nd. generation and additional added 2xPM old version will have limited to none impact on EMI performance.PM's can either be distinguished through PCB revision resistors or the programmed 0G numbers.
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Requirement: UPS is fixed external sync. master setting
Description: Enable/disable a UPS in each block to be assigned to be fixed external sync. master. It is therefore sufficient to only wire the sync status connection signals to one of the parallel UPS units in each block as illustrated below…{Image: 76C4275A-E32D-47BC-882E-AC9A1A8D46CD.bmp}The above illustrated setup does not provide any redundancy when it comes to external synchronization. If the fixed external sync master UPS breaks down the external sync feature is lost.This might not be any problem if the paralleling is done for power and not redundancy. The automated parallel master UPS selection procedure will always ensure that the UPS connected to the external sync source signals is prioritized highest as master. The slave UPS(s) will use the Pbus to sync to the master. Selectable values: Enable/disable (only one UPS in a bitfield)Default value: DisableRequired check of setting and/or configuration dependencies:- Only valid if External Sync Mode is set as ""Advanced Dual UPS Sync"".- Parallel system must automatically prevent that more than one UPS is set as fixed external sync. master by the user.

Requirement: User configurable low battery shutdown level in two points
Description: The low battery shutdown level must be configurable in two points. In each of the two points both the shutdown voltage level and the CA rate must be configurable. The ranges of these settings must depend on the battery type.The low battery warning level must be calculated based on the low battery shutdown level with an offset of +0.1V/cell.The UPS must stop discharging the battery when the low battery voltage shutdown level has been reached for 5 consecutive seconds. Below figure illustrates the low battery shutdown and warning levels for a lead acid battery.  {Image: 62E70829-A2A1-4EFF-BDE8-965BC0515AC3.bmp}

Requirement: Trip bypass backfeed breaker in case of inoperable PSU(s)
Description: In case one or more of the +5V, -5V, +15V and -15V PSUs are detected as inoperable/out of tolerance, the bypass backfeed breaker must be tripped as the ADC of the SBSC does not work without these PSUs meaning SBSC cannot measure voltages and detect a bypass backfeed scenario.

Requirement: Current compensation factor for display reading
Description: This requirement describes a compensation factor which shall be added to the measured power module battery current in relation to Jira issue ALPHA-7994. The factor shall be used for display reading compensation only.Compensation factor:The measured power module battery current  must be multiplied with a factor of 1.04. This is to compensate for magnetic fields in the 50kW power module that affects the current sensor. Note 1: This factor shall be used for display reading only and shall not be used for regulation purpose, battery current limiter etc. as these values are already tuned according to requirements.Note 2: The factor shall only be added for the 50kW power module since the 20kW power module does not have the same effect.
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Description: The UPS must monitor the ambient temperature and post an alarm and an event in the event log if the ambient temperature arises above 50 degrees C.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Ambient temperature is OK.
Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Ambient temperature is out of tolerance.

Requirement: User must be notified about ambient temperature and output load derating
Description: The following alarms and events must be posted in connection with the output load de-rating as a function of ambient temperature: {Image: 0CE4AE7A-B2FE-4D14-A71D-9B8D8375AB34.bmp} - When the ambient temperature exceeds 50 degrees C, the alarm "Ambient temperature out of tolerance" with severity level warning must be posted (including an event in the UPS event log). This alarm is covered by the "Ambient temperature surveillance" feature.- When in the "overload due to high ambient temperature" area, the alarm "Overload on UPS due to high ambient temperature" with severity level warning must be posted (including an event in the UPS event log).- When in overload (over 100%), an alarm with severity level warning must be posted (including an event in the UPS event log). This alarm is covered by the "Overload handling" feature.- When ambient temperature exceeds 40 degrees C, the alarm "Ambient temperature high" with severity warning must be posted in the UPS event log.- When ambient temperature falls below 40 degrees C, an event (alarm cleared) must be posted in the UPS event log.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Ambient temperature is no longer high.
Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Ambient temperature is high.

Requirement: Overload on UPS due to high ambient temperature no longer present
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The load no longer exceeds the rated capacity when running with high ambient temperature, or the ambient temperature is no longer high.

Requirement: Output load de-rating as a function of ambient temperature
Description: The maximum acceptable output load on UPS must depend on ambient temperature.Refer to APC Design Standard #165 - 3 Phase UPS Design Rule for Load de-rating as a function of ambient temperature.

Requirement: Derating of PFC AC current at high temperature
Description: When the ambient temperature reaches 43 degrees C the AC current limitation threshold of the PFC stage must be reduced from 100% to 75% and the alarm for "PFC AC current limit threshold lowered due to high temperature" must be posted.When the ambient temperature drops to 41 degrees C the threshold must be increased to 100% again, and the alarm for "PFC AC current limit threshold lowered due to high temperature" must be cleared again.

Spare part firmware update operation mode
Description: UPS must be in off operation or maintenance bypass operation to allow a spare part firmware update of the following modules:- UC, NMC, display, BMC, SBSC, DDUSpare part firmware update of the following modules is allowed in any UPS operation mode:- PMC, second optional NMC

Requirement: Surveillance of SBSC output and bypass voltage measuring circuit
Description: The SBS must monitor if its output and bypass voltage measuring circuits are working correctly.
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Requirement: Trip bypass backfeed breaker in case of output voltage sense circuit is not working correctly
Description: In case it is determined that the output voltage sense circuit on the SBSC is not working correctly, the bypass backfeed breaker must be tripped as the SBSC cannot measure voltages correctly and detect a bypass backfeed scenario. - UC must provide an output voltage VQD status to the SBSC. If UC detects the output voltage as OK on all three phases it must report output voltage OK to the SBSC, else it must be reported as not OK.- UC must provide an inverter operation status to the SBSC. If UPS (or any UPS in a parallel system) is in battery operation (including battery test) or in normal operation it must report inverter operation to the SBSC.- SBSC must use this status from UC to detect if its output sense circuit is working correctly. If SBSC detects the output voltage as not OK on one or more phases while UC reports output voltage OK and is in inverter operation for a period of 5 seconds, SBSC must trip the bypass backfeed breaker.
SY Model Type: Unitary,Integrated Parallel (IP),Parallel with Centralized Static Swtich

Requirement: Settings not allowed to be reset
Description: The following settings must not be reset to default by a reset settings to factory default command:- Serial number of UPS- Frame type- UPS product family name

Requirement: UC controller box enable switch status must be available to the user
Description: The current status of the UC controller box enable switch must be available to the user, and it must be logged in the event log when the UC controller box is enabled and disabled.

Requirement: Inverter on button status when UC controller box is disabled
Description: When the controller box is disabled it is not possible to turn on the inverter, hence the inverter on button shown in display and UPS Tuner must be "grayed out" to make this clear for the user.

Primary Actor(s)-          User.Stakeholders and InterestsUPS              :     Pre conditions-Post conditions- Main success scenario1. UPS is in any operation mode except off operation and maintenance bypass.2. Bypass is available (bypass voltage within tolerance, inverter sync to bypass, SBS ready)3. User sets the controller enable switch to 'disable'.4. UPS transfers to emergency static bypass.5. Controller box can be removed. Alternative scenario 11. UPS is in any operation mode except off operation and maintenance bypass..2. Bypass voltage is out of tolerance and inverter is sync to bypass (transfer to static bypass with bypass out of tolerance is allowed)3. User sets the controller enable switch to 'disable'.4. UPS transfers to emergency static bypass.5. Controller box can be removed.Alternative scenario 21. UPS is in any operation mode except off operation and maintenance bypass..2. Bypass voltage is out of tolerance and inverter is not sync to bypass (transfer to static bypass with bypass out of tolerance is allowed)3. User sets the controller enable switch to 'disable'.4. UPS transfers to forced static bypass with a break.5. Controller box can be removed (when controller box is removed UPS will transfer to emergency static bypass).Alternative scenario 31. UPS is in any operation mode except off operation and maintenance bypass..2. Bypass voltage is out of tolerance (transfer to static bypass with bypass out of tolerance is not allowed)3. User sets the controller enable switch to 'disable'.4. UPS transfers to off operation.5. Controller box can be removed.Alternative scenario 41. UPS is in any operation mode except off operation and maintenance bypass..2. Bypass is not available3. User sets the controller enable switch to 'disable'.4. UPS transfers to off operation.5. Controller box can be removed.Alternative scenario 5NAAlternative scenario 61. UPS is in off operation.2. User sets the controller enable switch to 'disable'.3. The UPS stays in off operation.4. Controller box can be removed.Alternative scenario 71. UPS is in maintenance bypass.2. User sets the controller enable switch to 'disable'.3. The UPS stays in maintenance bypass.4. Controller box can be removed.- For the main success scenario and alternative scenarios 1 and 2: If controller box is disabled but not removed, and then enabled again, the UPS will return to inverter operation if possible.- For the alternative scenarios 3, 4 and 6: If controller box is disabled but not removed, and then enabled again, the UPS will stay in off operation.- For the alternative scenario 7: If controller box is disabled but not removed, and then enabled again, the UPS will stay in maintenance bypass.- While the controller box is disabled it is not possible to turn on the inverter (inverter on button will have no action).Special requirementsNA Technology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Controller box is inserted.3. User sets the controller enable switch to 'enable'.4. UPS transfers to forced static bypass.5. UPS transfers from forced static bypass to inverter operation. Alternative scenario 11. UPS is in emergency static bypass2. Controller box is inserted.3. User sets the controller enable switch to 'enable'.4. UPS transfers to forced static bypass.5. UPS is not able to operate in inverter operation due to some reason.6. UPS stays in forced static bypass. Alternative scenario 21. UPS is in emergency static bypass2. Requirement: UC controller box enable switch status
Description: Status of the controller box enable switch.Possible values: Enabled/disabled
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: UC controller box has been enabled by userInstance must indicate which UC
Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: NADescription: UC controller box has been disabled by userInstance must indicate which UC

The UC controller box must have an enable switch which controls if the UC must be enabled or disabled. - Before the controller box is removed, the enable switch must be set to 'disabled' to shut down the controller.- When the controller box has been inserted, the enable switch must be set to 'enabled' to start up the controller.The UC controller box enable switch directly controls the 24V power to the UC.

Primary Actor(s)-       User.Stakeholders and InterestsUser              : .Pre conditionsUPS system must be supplied with power. The UIB is closed.Post conditionsNAMain success scenario1.    The UPS is in any operation mode but requested static bypass operation (including ECO mode and ECOnversion).2.    The UIB is detected as opened.3.    The UPS continues in the same operation mode. The UPS does not use the status of the UIB to determine if Mains 1 is available or not but instead checks the Mains 1 input itself.Alternative scenariosScenario 1:1.    The UPS is in requested static bypass operation (including ECO mode and ECOnversion) and system is dual mains (has a SSIB present).2.    The UIB is detected as opened.3.    The UPS continues in the same operation mode. The UPS does not use the status of the UIB to determine if Mains 1 is available or not but instead checks the Mains 1 input itself.Scenario 2:1.    The UPS is in requested static bypass operation (including ECO mode and ECOnversion) and system is single mains (has no SSIB present).2.    The UIB is detected as opened.3.    The UPS returns to inverter operation.Special requirements                                                 NATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Requirement: Notify user if high efficiency mode has been disabled by system
Description: If high efficiency mode has been disabled by the system an alarm must be posted informing the user about it. The user must be able to disable this alarm via a setting. If the alarm is disabled an event must still be logged if high efficiency mode has been disabled by the system.

Requirement: User re-enable of high efficiency mode when it has been disabled by system
Description: It must be possible for the user to re-enable high efficiency mode again if it has been disabled by system using the ""High efficiency mode setting"".

Requirement: User configurable maximum number of transfers in and out of high efficiency mode
Description: The user must be able to configure how many times the UPS is allowed to transfer in and out of high efficiency mode within 24 hours before the system disables high efficiency mode.

Requirement: Info about number of transfers left before high efficiency mode will be disabled by system
Description: The user must be able to see how many transfers to high efficiency mode are left before high efficiency mode will be disabled by system.

Requirement: High efficiency mode disabled by system
Description: To prevent too many micro discharges of the UPS battery when exiting ECOnversion, the system must automatically disable ECOnversion mode and ECO mode (high efficiency mode) if UPS exits and enters high efficiency mode more than a configurable number times within a 24 hours interval.

Requirement: High efficiency mode disabled by system alarm setting
Description: Setting to configure if an alarm must be shown if high efficiency mode has been disabled by the system.Range: Enable/disableDefault value: Enable

Requirement: Number of high efficiency mode transfers left
Description: Status that shows how many transitions in and out of high efficiency mode are left before high efficiency mode will be disabled by the system.Range: 0 to 10.

Requirement: High efficiency mode no longer disabled by system
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: High efficiency mode is no longer disabled by the system

Requirement: High efficiency mode disabled by system
Description: Type: AlarmSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: Enable high efficiency mode again or disable it permanentlyDescription: High efficiency mode has been disabled by the system

Requirement: High efficiency mode disabled by system with no alarm
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: Enable high efficiency mode again or disable it permanentlyDescription: High efficiency mode has been disabled by the system This is the ""event"" version of the alarm with the same name. If alarming is disabled this event must be posted instead when high efficiency mode has been disabled by the system.

Requirement: Maximum number of transfers to high efficiency mode - setting changed
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Maximum number of transfers to high efficiency mode - setting has been changed

Requirement: High efficiency mode disabled by system alarm - setting changed
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: High efficiency mode disabled by system alarm - setting has been changed

Requirement: High efficiency mode disabled by system
Maximum number of transfers to high efficiency mode setting
Description: Setting for the maximum allowed number of transfers in and out of high efficiency mode within 24 hoursRange: 0 to 10 (0 means high efficiency mode cannot be disabled by system, no matter the number of transfers in and out of high efficiency mode within 24 hours)Default value: 10

Requirement: User configurable if high efficiency mode can be disabled by system
Description: It must be possible for the use to configure if high efficiency mode can be disabled by the system or not.This way the user can force the system to keep going back into high efficiency mode no matter how many times it has transfered in and out high efficiency mode within 24 hours.

Requirement: Monitoring of a load bank breaker (LBB)
Description: The UPS must be able to monitor the status (open/closed) of a load bank breaker (if present).The current status of the present breaker must be visible to the user, and a breaker status change must be logged in the event log.
Setting for whether circuit breaker LBB, is present or not. Range: Yes/NoDefault value: No
Type: AlarmSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Load bank breaker LBB is closed
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Load bank breaker LBB is open
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: LBB present - setting has been changed

Requirement: Efficiency gain between normal operation and ECOnversion
Description: The average efficiency gain of running in ECOnversion instead of normal operated must be fixed to a value of 2%.This number is based on the actual efficiency measurements and is a conservative average of all the combinations of system voltages, system power ratings and output loads levels tested.
The user must be able to configure the currency of the displayed cost savings.
The user must be able to configure the electricity cost per kWh.
The currency in which the cost saving must be shown.Range: EUR, USD, CNY, GPB, INR, CAD, RUB, custom.Default value: USD
The cost of electricity per kWh.Range: 0.00 to ??Default value: ??

Requirement: Calculation of energy savings using ECOnversion
Description: The purpose of this feature is to provide the user (customer) with clear indication and calculation of how much energy and thereby money is or can be saved by using ECOnversion instead of normal operation.• The UPS must provide a calculation of how much energy and money has been saved by operating in ECOnversion instead of normal operation.• The UPS must provide a way for the customer to simulate how much energy and money could have been saved by enabling and running in ECOnversion instead of normal operation.

Requirement: Average output active power while in ECOnversion since last reset
Description: The average active output power per phase (for 3:1 single phase only L1 is used) while in ECOnversion, since first start-up.

Requirement: Average output active power while in normal operation since last reset
Description: The average active output power per phase (for 3:1 single phase only L1 is used) while in normal operation, since first start-up.

The UPS must provide a graphical view of the alarm status of the power modules in the UPS

Requirement: Physical representation of UPS and power module location
Description: The graphical view of the power module alarm status must be a representation of the actual physical layout of the UPS so that it is easy to locate physically which power modules have alarms present.

The alarm status of each power module must be indicated by a colored icon and must follow the general severity levels of alarms which are informational, warning and critical.The alarm status indicated for a power module must reflect the highest severity alarm present for the given module. Meaning if for example there are both a warning alarm and critical alarm present for the module, the alarm status indication of the module must be critical. When no alarms are present in a module it must be marked via a green “tick mark” icon.

Requirement: Indication of power module not present
Description: If a given power module is not present in the UPS, this must be indicated by graying out the given module.

Requirement: Link between active alarms list and power module status viewm
Description: It must be possible to locate the detailed list of alarms for each power module in the active alarms list of the UPS and the severity of these must match what is indicated on the graphical view.
Alarm status of a power module.Range: NoAlarms, InformationalAlarm, WarningAlarm, CriticalAlarm.

Setting for the CA discharge rate level 1.Range: 0.5-50 C/stringDefault value: 8.4 C/stringRequired check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: The CA discharge rate level 1 must be higher or equal to level 2.
Setting for the CA discharge rate level 1 delay.Range: 0-600000 millisecondsDefault value: 1000If set to 0 the function must be off
The UPS must provide information to the user about the estimated charge level (state of charge SOC) of the connected energy storage.
Setting for the CA discharge rate level 3 delay.Range: 0-600000 millisecondsDefault value: 50000If set to 0 the function must be off

Requirement: Enable power module shutdown due to desat event
Description: If NPI test mode is enabled, the power module must always shut down if a desat event is detected.

Setting for the CA discharge rate level 3.Range: 0.5-50 C/stringDefault value: 7 C/stringRequired check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: The CA discharge rate level 3 must be higher or equal to the value of the setting for ""single rating maximum allowed string discharge current""

Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Exit high efficiency mode based on bypass voltage THD - setting has been changed

Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Maximum allowed bypass voltage THD for high efficiency mode - setting has been changed

Requirement: Output voltage sensing circuit not working correctly
Description: Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Output voltage sensing circuit is not working correctly on UC or PMC

Requirement: Output voltage sensing circuit is OK
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Output voltage sensing circuit is OK
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The configured internal power module redundancy is obtained
Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: Add more power modulesDescription: The configured internal power module redundancy is lost because there are not enough power modules available

The UPS Operation Mode indicates in which mode the UPS itself is operating. It does not necessary reflect by which operation mode the load is supplied. If the UOB is open (and/or the SIB in a parallel system) the UPS Operation Mode can be different from the operation mode supplying the load.The current UPS operation mode must be available to the user as a status in the HMI (display, UPS Tuner, web interface etc.), as active alarms, and in the event log for operation mode changes.
The UPS is doing basic initialization of the system.
Operation mode where the UPS is not supplying the load. It will be ready to start due to a user request and supply the load
Operation mode where the UPS delivers conditioned power to the output from the DC source (battery, flywheel etc.) using the inverter.
Operation mode where the UPS delivers conditioned power to the output from input mains voltage using the inverter.
Operation where the UPS is in static bypass due to either a critical event that prevents it from running on inverter or due to a user request forcing the inverter to be off.

Operation mode where the UPS is in static bypass due to a user request. This mode is only allowed if the UPS is able to run in Inverter On mode and bypass is OK. If a critical event is detected (bypass voltage out of tolerance, bypass static switch inoperable, output voltage out of tolerance or another critical UPS event) the UPS will immediately change to inverter operation mode or Forced Static Bypass mode.

Operation mode where the Maintenance Bypass Breaker (MBB) is closed and the load is supplied with unconditioned power from the bypass input. The load is powered but not protected. When in this mode the bypass static switch will be kept activated if possible.
Operation mode where the UPS is in static bypass due to a core control failure. The bypass static switch activates autonomously in this operation mode.

The UPS has a mains input out of tolerance and is ready to enter Battery Operation but awaits permission from the system. UPS output is off. Mode used for Advanced Battery Operation Management in parallel operation.

The UPS has a critical event and is ready to enter Forced Static Bypass Operation but awaits permission from the system. UPS output is off. Mode used in parallel operation and if using the ""Advanced Dual UPS Sync with Static Bypass Standby"" mode.
The UPS delivers conditioned power to the output from the DC source (battery, flywheel, etc.) using the inverter.

The inverter is turned on while the UPS is in Requested Static Bypass operation. The output power from the inverter is recycled via bypass to input mains. The power consumption equals the system losses in the inverter and PFC. Requires the output to be connected via bypass to the input mains

The charger is turned on while in Battery Operation. The charge power is recycled via the PFC back to the DC bus. The power consumption equals the system loss only in the charger and PFC. Requires the UPS to be is in Battery Operation (UIB breaker open).

ECOnversion Mode allows the system to supply the active part of the load through the bypass. The inverter is kept running in parallel with the bypass source and supplies the reactive part of the load. The input power factor of the UPS is, regardless of the load power factor, maintained close to unity as the reactive part of load is significantly reduced in the UPS input current. In case if an interruption to the utility/mains supply, the inverter immediately maintains the output voltage so that breaks or drops during this transfer are practically eliminated.

The ECO Mode allows the system to be configured to use requested static bypass, with the load supplied through the bypass, as the preferred operation mode under predefined circumstances. The main advantage of is a reduction in the consumption of electrical power. In case of interruption to the utility/mains supply, the UPS tranfers to inverter operation for a continuous supply of the load. The load may experience a short duration interruption of power (4 to 8 ms) during this transfer.

The system operation mode on the other hand indicates by which operation mode the load is supplied. The UPS operation mode and the system operation mode are used for both single and parallel systems.The current system operation mode must be available to the user as a status in the HMI (display, UPS Tuner, web interface etc.), as active alarms, and in the event log for operation mode changes.
Operation mode where the system does not supply the load. The system will be ready to start due to a user request and supply the load.

Operation mode where the system delivers conditioned power to the output either from input mains voltage, or from the DC source (battery, flywheel etc.), using the inverter. This is a common term covering both battery operation and normal operation.
Operation mode where the system is in static bypass due to either a critical event that prevents it from running on inverter or due to a user request forcing the inverter to be off.

Operation mode where the UPS is in static bypass due to a user request. This mode is only allowed if the UPS is able to run in Inverter On mode and bypass is OK. If a critical event is detected (bypass voltage out of tolerance, bypass static switch inoperable, output voltage out of tolerance or another critical UPS event) the UPS will immediately change to inverter operation mode or Forced Static Bypass mode.

Operation mode where the Maintenance Bypass Breaker (MBB) is closed and the load is supplied with unconditioned power from the bypass input. The load is powered but not protected. When in this mode the bypass static switch will be kept activated if possible.
This mode is used in connection with the ""Advanced Dual UPS Sync with Static Bypass Standby"" mode.

ECOnversion Mode allows the system to supply the active part of the load through the bypass. The inverter is kept running in parallel with the bypass source and supplies the reactive part of the load. The input power factor of the UPS is, regardless of the load power factor, maintained close to unity as the reactive part of load is significantly reduced in the UPS input current. In case if an interruption to the utility/mains supply, the inverter immediately maintains the output voltage so that breaks or drops during this transfer are practically eliminated.

The ECO Mode allows the system to be configured to use requested static bypass, with the load supplied through the bypass, as the preferred operation mode under predefined circumstances. The main advantage of is a reduction in the consumption of electrical power. In case of interruption to the utility/mains supply, the UPS tranfers to inverter operation for a continuous supply of the load. The load may experience a short duration interruption of power (4 to 8 ms) during this transfer.
Operation mode where the PFC is initializing.
Operation mode where the PFC is off.
Operation mode where the PFC is in battery operation.
Operation mode where the PFC is in normal operation.
Operation mode where the inverter is initializing.
Operation mode where the inverter is off.
Operation mode where the inverter is turned off and the voltage on the output filter is forced to zero.
Operation mode where the inverter is in normal operation.

Requirement: Inverter transfer to requested bypass operation
Description: Operation mode where the inverter is in transfer to requested bypass mode. The UPS is transferring from inverter on to requested static bypass and the inverter output voltage level is adapted to the bypass voltage level before entering requested static bypass.
Operation mode where the inverter is in bypass operation mode. Inverter is tracking bypass voltage level ready to conduct a smooth return to inverter operation
Operation mode where the inverter is in SPoT operation. Current is looped from inverter through bypass and back into PFC.

Operation mode of the UPS:Off OperationNormal OperationBattery OperationForced Static Bypass OperationRequested Static Bypass OperationMaintenance BypassEmergency Static Bypass OperationStatic Bypass StandbyInverter StandbyPower Saving ModeSPoT (inverter)SPoT (charger) SPoT (battery)Battery TestECO ModeECOnversion Mode
Operation mode of the system:Inverter OperationRequested Static Bypass OperationForced Static Bypass OperationOff OperationMaintenance BypassECO ModeECOnversion ModeStatic Bypass Standby Operation

The system operation mode must indicate by which operation mode the load is supplied.Normally this will be the same operation mode as the actual internal operation mode of the UPS system. However, in the case where the UPS system is not connected to the load (UOB and/or SIB is open), the load can either be in off operation or maintenance bypass operation, depending on the state of the MBB, while the system can be in any operation mode.So, when the load is not connected to the UPS (SIB/UOB open) the system operation mode shown to the user must be corrected and show either off operation or maintenance bypass operation depending on the state of the MBB.Corrected operation mode of the system:Inverter OperationRequested Static Bypass OperationForced Static Bypass OperationOff OperationMaintenance BypassECO ModeECOnversion ModeStatic Bypass Standby Operation
Operation mode of the PFC:PFC initializationPFC off operationPFC battery operationPFC normal operationIf UPS has more power modules, the PFC operation status must be available for each power module

Operation mode of the PFC:Inverter initializationInverter off operationInverter zero inverter output operationInverter normal operationInverter transfer to requested bypass operationInverter bypass operationInverter SPoT operationThe inverter operation status must be available on system level, and ff UPS has more power modules, also for each power module.
Type: Event.Severity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The load is supplied from the inverters of the unit. The UPS takes the power from the utility.
Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: NADescription: On battery power in response to an input power problem or due to a transfer out of ECOnversion.

Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The UPS load is supplied through Maintenance Bypass Breaker (MBB).
Type: AlarmSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: On battery power in response to a test of the performance of the batteries.
Type: AlarmSeverity: CriticalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The output power is turned off.
Type: AlarmSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The UPS is initializing.

Description: Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The UPS is ready to enter static bypass but awaits permission from the system. UPS output is off.
Type: AlarmSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The UPS is ready to enter battery operation but awaits permission from the system. UPS output is off.

Description: Type: AlarmSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The UPS has entered Power Saving Mode. All converters are stopped but the UPS is ready to restart without manual operation.

Requirement: UPS operation mode - Inverter SPoT mode
Description: Type: Event.Severity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The UPS is in Inverter SPoT mode (the inverter is turned on in normal operation while the static bypass switch is on. The output power from the inverter is recycled via bypass to UPS input).

Requirement: UPS operation mode - Charger SPoT mode
Description: Type: Event.Severity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The UPS is in Charger SPoT mode (the charger is turned on while in Battery Operation. The charge power is recycled via the PFC back to the DC bus).

Requirement: UPS operation mode - Battery SPoT mode
Description: Type: Event.Severity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The UPS is in Battery SPoT mode (the inverter is turned on while the static bypass switch is on, feeding power from the battery back to the mains grid).
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The UPS has entered ECO Mode and the load is supplied via the static bypass switch.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The UPS has entered ECOnversion Mode.
Type: AlarmSeverity: CriticalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The system output power is turned off.

Requirement: User configurable ECOnversion minimum output load level
Description: It must be possible for the user (FSR) to configure (via UPS Tuner) a minimum output load level in percent of the UPS power rating to allow ECOnversion. The load must be active power (kW not kVA).The UPS output load must be over the configured minimum level on each phase before the UPS is allowed to transfer to ECOnversion.When in ECOnversion, the UPS must transfer back to inverter operation if the output load drops below the configured level (minus 2% hysteresis) on one of the phases.

Requirement: ECOnversion minimum output load level setting
Description: Setting for the minimum UPS output load to allow ECOnversion operation.Note: If setting is configured to a value above approximately 103%, it is the same as disabling ECOnversion (ECOnversion is not possible with UPS output overload).Range: 5% to 110%, in steps of 1%Default value: 110%
